HEADLINE: Madrid Journal; 
Trying to Quiet Another City That Barely Sleeps

BYLINE:  By EMMA DALY 

DATELINE: MADRID, Oct. 6 

 BODY:
With the roar of traffic in the very heart of Madrid it is hard to make out the murmur of voices coming from a group huddled on the pavement, but as the volume increases the babble rises to an incomprehensible if audible peak and then fades into shushing, followed by a staccato chorus: "Listen. To. Your. Noise. Control. Your. Noise."
 This brief performance, repeated several times over by half a dozen actors in exaggerated makeup is part of a municipal campaign to silence residents in a city that may sleep (sometimes during the day) but rarely shuts up. 
 Madrid's noise ordinance, instituted last year, defines five "acoustic zones." Sound levels in mainly residential areas, known as "type II" zones, should not exceed 65 decibels during the day and 55 decibels at night. "Type III" zones, commercial areas with bars and restaurants, carry limits of 70 decibels by day and 60 decibels at night, but data from the city's sound-monitoring stations show that sound levels routinely exceed 70 decibels in both areas around the clock. 
The city's two-year campaign is aimed mostly at 9- to 14-year-olds, on the theory that -- besides being some of the greatest offenders -- they are most receptive to education and might even nag their parents into changing their bad habits. But for the first few days, adults were also targets.
"Some people respond to us by making even more noise, but most have been very nice," said Alberto Diaz, one of the actors, as he handed out balloons bearing the campaign logo "Control Your Noise."
"They're not sure what the solution is, but they all know that noise is a problem," Mr. Diaz said, struggling to be heard over the sound of a street-cleaning machine and the trilling of passing cellphones.
The main sources of acoustic pollution in central Madrid -- which, like most European cities, was designed and built long before the advent of motor vehicles -- are traffic, public works and the chatter of people, mostly at the tops of their voices. 
The shrieking car alarms that are a target of an anti-noise campaign in New York City are not an issue here: the problem of stationary cars is usually that they are double- or triple-parked, causing congestion, hard feelings and, inevitably, honking.
On main roads, the thunder of traffic penetrates even offices and homes with double windows, while at traffic lights, horns will inevitably sound to signal green a nano-second after the lights change -- even at 4 a.m. on Sunday, when traffic jams are quite common in central Madrid. 
Add a construction boom, coupled with an urban renewal plan that is replacing bridges over the streets with tunnels, and a continuing project to lay underground cable, and one result is a chorus of jackhammers. 
But what really makes this city -- and makes it noisy -- is life lived out of doors, especially in summer. Sidewalk cafes, children's playgrounds, park benches are all packed with people, young and old, until the small hours. Most are speaking loudly, if not actually shouting, to be heard over the music, traffic or the sounds of other people.
A new European Union directive requires all large cities to cut noise levels by five decibels between 7 p.m. and 11 p.m., and by 10 decibels between 11 p.m. and 7 a.m., but Madrid will be unable to comply. "To cut noise levels by five decibels, a third of the population would have to go indoors," said Placido Perera, director of Madrid's acoustic control unit. "The levels were set mainly by the Germans and Danes, who are all at home by 5 p.m. because it's so cold." 
In addition to education, the campaign is trying to lower the volume by persuading people to make modest lifestyle adjustments, like wearing slippers at night and refraining from slamming doors or using washing machines after 11 p.m.
This effort has been greeted with bemusement or angry derision by many citizens, especially those tortured by the "botellon" -- the teenage culture of gathering in squares and on sidewalks to party.
"They have the nerve to tell us how to quiet down when they don't even respect their own laws," fumed Carlos Delgado, who lives in a neighborhood known for its happening night life.
Mr. Perera's office sits on Plaza Barcelo, a favored teenage hangout. A new municipal law bans open-air drinking, but residents complain that it is rarely enforced. 
"It's pathetic," Mr. Delgado said crossly. "They went to the school in Plaza Barcelo to tell the kids not to shout at home when they know that they are out at 5 a.m. on a Friday night in the same square throwing firecrackers."
The botellon culture is indeed a target for reform. Jose Luis Blanco, who is coordinating the anti-noise campaign, said the young people were very receptive to the message that "it is possible to hang out with your friends in the park without shouting."
The anti-noise campaign will visit more than 320 local schools, and next year, Mr. Blanco and his team of actors plan to branch out to bars. "We will try to persuade people that it is possible to speak more quietly, that there's no need to shout at 2 a.m.," he said, even if they are drunk.
Mr. Perera said that the campaign was meant to be a long-term re-education process, and that the city was also restricting late-night bar licenses, subsidizing the soundproofing of affected houses and calming traffic by widening sidewalks and restricting parking.
In November, parking meters will go into operation around central Madrid. But most people here say they are more likely to set off a rebellion -- as a similar plan did some years ago -- than to solve the noise problem. This is, after all, a city where residents consider it their constitutional right to double-park.

HEADLINE: A Neighborhood Clinic Helps Fill the Gap for Latinos Without Health Care 

BYLINE:  By LYNETTE CLEMETSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 

 BODY:
MariBel Garcia lives near several good doctor's offices and hospitals, but as far as she is concerned they might as well not be there at all. Her housecleaning and restaurant jobs have never provided health insurance. Few local facilities have Spanish-speaking staff members. Even making an appointment, given her limited English skills, is a daunting, often humiliating, experience.
 "They don't understand my language, my culture, my issues," said Ms. Garcia, 40, who came to the United States from El Salvador 15 years ago and is now a legal resident. "I would rather wait and see a doctor on a visit to El Salvador than go through that difficulty." 
 Although Ms. Garcia recently got insurance through a new city program for the poor, she prefers to rely solely on La Clinica del Pueblo, a scrappy but welcoming neighborhood clinic in the heart of Washington's Latino community that operates primarily in Spanish and treats anyone regardless of legal status or ability to pay.
In Latino enclaves nationwide, facilities like La Clinica are filling gaps in the health care system that sometimes leave Hispanics feeling shut out. The number of Americans without health insurance rose significantly last year, new census figures show, to 14.6 percent. An estimated 30 to 37 percent of Hispanics living in the United States are uninsured, the figures indicate, the largest percentage of any ethnic group.
For immigrant communities in particular, neighborhood clinics address a number of barriers to health care. The majority of Latinos who are uninsured are working poor, juggling part-time jobs that do not provide benefits. Those in poverty are often barred from aid as a result of 1996 welfare changes, which cut access for new immigrants to programs like Medicaid and the Children's Health Insurance Program.
Some forms of public assistance have been reinstated since 1996, and additional restorations, such as the Immigrant Children's Health Improvement Act, are pending before the Senate. But figuring out who qualifies for assistance in immigrant families, which often have members of varying legal status, is difficult.
Many of those who qualify for aid are afraid to apply, fearful that being perceived as a burden on society will hurt their residency or citizenship applications.
Ms. Garcia had all of those concerns when she first used the Washington clinic more than 10 years ago. "I don't know what we'd do without La Clinica," said Ms. Garcia, whose entire family has used the clinic for everything from routine checkups to emergency care.
Housed in an old Presbyterian church turned multipurpose community center a few miles north of the White House, La Clinica del Pueblo is not known by many outside the neighborhood.
But ask nearly any neighborhood resident and he or she will automatically point the way -- past the street vendors selling fresh sliced mangoes, through the double doors papered with colorful fliers, up the dimly lighted stairway -- to the main reception area abuzz with activity. 
Started with a volunteer doctor in 1983 to serve the influx of Central Americans into Washington, La Clinica initially was open only on Tuesday nights. Today, with a $4 million operating budget provided by the city and federal governments and by private donors, the clinic operates full time with 46 staff members and more than 100 volunteers, all of whom speak more than one language. Of the roughly 500 patients who file in and out each week more than 90 percent are uninsured. 
"We've always had to come through the back door of the health system," said Dr. Juan Romagoza, La Clinica's executive director. "So here we open the door as wide as possible." 
Government and mainstream health care institutions are becoming more appreciative of community facilities like La Clinica. Chronic illnesses like heart disease and diabetes are increasing rapidly among Latinos, as are socially transmitted diseases like H.I.V. and hepatitis. Poor access to primary care, health care officials realize, will result in greater long-term costs to the system.
In August, President Bush announced a plan to pay for 1,200 new community health care centers over the next five years.
"It's fundamental to the entire health system, and to the economy, to improve the health status of Hispanics in the U.S.," said Dr. Elena Rios, president of the National Hispanic Medical Association, a Washington-based organization of Hispanic doctors. 
One of the programs being expanded by La Clinica and other centers is the "promotores de salud" or "health promoter" program. The program trains community members to be lay health workers who circulate through neighborhoods espousing the benefits of healthy habits and preventative care. 
The centerpiece of La Clinica's promotores program is "Domingos saludables" or "healthy Sundays." The once-a-month health fair, usually held at neighborhood churches, offers free blood pressure, glucose and cholesterol testing, nutrition and exercise guidance and counseling on substance abuse, mental health care and H.I.V. prevention.
Rebeca Munoz, a dental assistant who stocked hospital supply rooms in her native El Salvador before coming to the United States in 1994, works several nights a week as a promotora in H.I.V./AIDS prevention.
"It's not like doctor and patient," said Ms. Munoz, 49, a soft-spoken wife and mother of four who spends hours at self-service laundries, parks and bus stops talking to people about safe sex and intravenous drug use. "We respect the people, and they respect us. Everyone is just talking in Spanish, and soon people are not afraid. It's like family."
Similar health promoter programs operate in other cities, including Chicago, El Paso and Providence, R.I. 
"We've seen that these people have enormous credibility in their communities," said Yanira Cruz, director of the Institute for Hispanic Health at the National Council of La Raza, a Hispanic advocacy agency that is helping La Clinica pay for a new promotores position dedicated to diabetes. 
In April, La Clinica received a $900,000 grant from the District of Columbia Department of Housing and Community Development to renovate a 12,000-square-foot facility a few blocks from the existing clinic. Dr. Romagoza is thrilled, but he says the growing support given to clinics such as his does not lessen the need for federal and state agencies and local hospitals and doctors to better serve changing populations.
MariBel Garcia could not agree more. She hopes to become a citizen, and, she adds, she intends to vote.
"The politicians, the leaders, they want to ignore us," she said. "They think they can speak a slogan in Spanish and this is enough -- but it is not enough for me. They have to pay attention to our issues." In the meantime, La Clinica, she knows, is there.

GRAPHIC: Photos: La Clinica del Pueblo in Washington treats anyone regardless of legal status or ability to pay. MariBel Garcia, foreground above, her daughter Miriam Garcia and her granddaughter Jasmine Orellana are patients. (Photographs by Susana Raab for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
If Nobody Lifts An Umbrella, Can It Rain?

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
YOU can tell that Election Day is just a month away, with the major candidates for governor competing energetically over such matters as who can raise and spend more (Gov. George E. Pataki) and who can suffer the most self-inflicted wounds (Comptroller H. Carl McCall, virtuoso of that fine political art of writing for jobs).
 Would that the candidates lavished as much attention on a matter that touches every New Yorker more directly: the budget. It is suffering in the weakened economy, and the state has few resources left to make up for dropping revenues. Mr. Pataki, betting that the economy would recover, spent nearly all of the state's rainy-day fund to buffer the impact of Sept. 11. Critics have noted that the strategy is in line with the state's well-worn tradition of upbeat election-year budgets. 
 The governor seems to have gambled badly. The economy is still slow, Wall Street is still in trouble -- so much that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is finally weighing tax increases -- and a transit-fare increase is looming.
At the same time, the state's revenues are falling, with personal-income-tax collections declining for the second year running, down by 21 percent through August, compared with the same period last year. And income-tax collections have dropped even more steeply in the city.
The state relied so heavily this year on one-time revenues by spending about 80 percent of its reserve funds that it is not at all clear how New York will close a budget deficit that the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, recently predicted could be as high as $10 billion. The subject seems worth a public airing. But the public has little concept of how the candidates would address the problem. "I think they just can't talk about it until the election," said Frank Mauro, director of the Fiscal Policy Institute. "They are saying this year's budget is balanced. The response is, it is very precariously balanced." Another budget analyst predicts the coming of "a perfect storm -- enormous deficits in all parts of government. And nobody talks about it."
The one exception is the Independence Party candidate, Tom Golisano, the wealthy businessman who is running as an outsider, and so has made an issue of Albany's budget woes. Mr. Pataki disputes the severity of the problem, and Mr. McCall, while acknowledging the difficulties, is only mildly critical and has not made the budget the centerpiece of his campaign.
Perhaps neither major candidate wants to face uncomfortable questions, among them the prospect of tax increases and agency cuts, and whether it would help if the governor froze spending immediately. Standard & Poor's recently said the state had done well covering revenue gaps to date, drawing on those depleted reserves. And now? "We're not saying there's no challenge now, and not just for New York," said Robin Prunty, director of the company's public finance department.
Nor are the challenges in New York limited to Albany -- thanks to Albany. The state took a large portion of the city's new cigarette tax, contending that the higher fee would hurt sales and therefore reduce state tax revenues. The Pataki administration is using part of a federal welfare surplus for state budget relief, rather than letting localities spend the money. And local and county governments are, through Medicaid payments, financing part of the raises that Mr. Pataki granted to the politically potent hospital workers union. 
The governor and legislative leaders could already be confronting the fiscal problem. But that would mean acknowledging it before Election Day. Before the perfect storm breaks over the state capital.

UNFINISHED BUSINESS -- A recent column puzzled over the failure of an independent consultant, McKinsey & Company, to interview former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani about its analyses of the city's emergency response on Sept. 11. Those studies praised the heroism of the Police and Fire Departments that day, but also found serious organizational and communications flaws.
Mr. Giuliani has disputed some findings and argued that if he had been queried he could have corrected, or at least addressed, them. Why wasn't he questioned?
McKinsey declined to comment. Officials of the Police and Fire Departments said the reviews, undertaken at their request, analyzed the nuts and bolts of department operations, not administrative leadership, so interviews were limited to hundreds of police and fire personnel.
Those officials said on Friday that while they still thought the approach was right on the merits, they also wished in hindsight that Mr. Giuliani had been interviewed, if only to try to avoid inviting his disapproval.

HEADLINE: Enthusiasm By Democrats Over Elections Is on the Wane 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Democratic leaders who two months ago predicted a strong showing in Congressional elections this fall have markedly scaled back their views, saying their hopes had been dimmed both by a concerted White House effort to focus attention on Iraq and by disarray in their own party over how to respond to the threat of war.
 Democratic leaders said they were far from giving up on winning control of the House and holding on to or expanding their lead in the Senate. They pointed to polls showing voters were upset about the economy and the overall direction of the nation. 
 But in a series of interviews, Democrats said the party's fortunes had shifted measurably since the optimistic days of last summer, when some party leaders were saying they might take back the House and expand their one-seat Senate margin. 
Democratic leaders said they believed party candidates had been hurt by the visible emergence of a powerful antiwar Democratic lobby, including the visit by three Democratic members of Congress to Baghdad last week that Republicans noted with more than a little glee.
Party leaders also noted the contrast between the public displays of division by Democrats arguing over when to have a vote, and what the resolution should say, with the relatively solid front presented by Republicans, whose dissent of last summer appears to have vanished. 
"It's gone from robust optimism six weeks ago, eight weeks ago, to some real pessimism," said Senator Evan Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, in assessing his party's prospects.
In Georgia, Senator Zell Miller, a Democrat who is often critical of his party, said the Democrats were allowing themselves to be outmaneuvered on the Iraq issue and in the debate on a homeland security bill.
"It could not have happened at a worse moment," he said. "I am feeling a lot less optimistic than I was two weeks ago. This is a total disconnect with the American people."
The expressions of concern came at what Democratic and Republican officials described as a pivotal time in the midterm Congressional campaigns. The middle of October has traditionally been the time when many voters begin tuning in for the first time on campaigns that have been going on all summer.
Democrats expressed hope that the agreement reached by some senior Democrats to support Mr. Bush's Iraq resolution could help remove it from the political arena. Democrats said they were eager to return to campaigning. 
"What they have successfully done is distract people off our issues," Terry McAuliffe, the national Democratic chairman. "It is our job to get us back on message, and I believe that in the last three weeks it will go back to the economy." 
Representative Martin Frost of Texas said: "I'm still very optimistic. I may be running contrary to some other people. There is no way the Republicans can recover from the state of the economy."
But that optimism was in short supply in some Democratic circles. Some party members argued, with frustration, that the campaign had been complicated as much by what the Republicans had done in pushing the Iraq resolution as by the way Democrats had responded.
"Karl Rove has got to be doing somersaults," said Chris Lehane, a Democratic consultant who was the spokesman for Al Gore's presidential campaign in 2000, referring to Mr. Bush's top political adviser. "While I respect everybody's views, the continuing debate on Iraq plays right into Karl Rove's hands."
The discussion in the Democratic Party about Iraq has been vibrant, reflecting ideological fissures between the party's left wing and moderates who, over the years, have argued that moving the party to the center was vital to maintaining its electoral viability. Some moderates said they thought images of prominent members of the party's liberal wing attacking Mr. Bush on the Iraq could be a setback.
"The greatest sin of the left wing of the Democratic Party is that they make it easier for George Bush and the Republicans to win because they present an argument that the bulk of the country doesn't agree with," said Representative Adam Smith of Washington.
Of particularly concern to some Democrats was the visit of a three-member Democratic delegation to Baghdad, where Representative Jim McDermott of Washington suggested that Mr. Bush might be misleading Americans as he made the case against Saddam Hussein.
"He combined the judgment of Neville Chamberlain before World War II and Jane Fonda in Hanoi," Representative Chet Edwards of Texas, who faces a tough re-election battle, said of Mr. McDermott.
Mr. McDermott offered no regrets. "I think people want candidates who say what they think and will stand for it," he said, "and I think the Democratic Party is better off when everybody is doing that."

HEADLINE: The Hudson at Risk 

 BODY:
This time of year most lawns suddenly sprout election placards. But in Columbia County, N.Y., the election placards stand alongside signs that say either "Stop the Plant" or "Support the Plant." The plant is a proposed coal-burning cement manufacturing facility that would be built, if approved, along the Hudson River near the city of Hudson and the town of Greenport. In effect, St. Lawrence Cement, which is owned by the Swiss company Holcim, would create an industrial city on the waterfront, including 40 acres of buildings, a 1,200-acre open-pit limestone mine, a new dock, a two-mile-long conveyor belt and a smokestack that would stand 400 feet high. The plant is inappropriate, and Gov. George Pataki and his environmental conservation commissioner, Erin Crotty, must stop it. 
 Opposition to this plant has been growing steadily among environmentalists and local residents. Their biggest worry is the huge plume that would pour out of the smokestack, a plume containing 20 million pounds of pollution a year, including high concentrations of fine particulate matter and other health hazards. Beyond that, a cement kiln happens to work very well as a hazardous waste incinerator, and St. Lawrence Cement has insisted on obtaining a permit to use the plant as an incinerator. The company says it does not plan to burn waste. But if the chance exists, it may well be seized. 
 Last December, an administrative law judge in the state's Department of Environmental Conservation ruled that further hearings were needed before the department could decide whether St. Lawrence Cement's application could move ahead. The hearings would examine basic issues like the problem of emissions and the potential effect of the plant on fish life, on traffic, on local historical and cultural resources and on the esthetic quality of the region. St. Lawrence Cement appealed to Commissioner Crotty, asking her, essentially, to skip the hearings and jump to the next stage in permitting the plant. 
At the very least, Ms. Crotty should insist that full hearings proceed, as dictated by state law. This plant is wildly out of scale for its setting, and important questions about the potential effect of its emissions and its daily operations have not been answered. Supporters argue that the plant will create jobs, but even St. Lawrence Cement has estimated that when its old Catskill plant closes, the net increase in jobs will be just one. The plant would also have a negative effect on an area that has been revitalized by its scenic, cultural and historic resources. The economic future of the Hudson River depends on them, not on cement.
Ms. Crotty will presumably have to take into account the views of her boss, Mr. Pataki, but there is no obvious reason why the governor would want this plant. Mr. Pataki has painstakingly built a strong environmental record, particularly when it comes to the Hudson, and this plant is fundamentally inconsistent with his hopes for the river. Mr. Pataki and his fellow Northeastern governors have made a point of trying to get coal-burning power plants in the Midwest to cut their emissions. To build a coal-burning cement plant right on the Hudson makes no sense at all.
The governor of Maine, Angus King, has expressed his concerns, as has the Connecticut attorney general, Richard Blumenthal. Mr. Pataki should listen to them and, most of all, to the concerned citizens of the Hudson Valley.

HEADLINE: A Little Off the Bottom Line; 
As Hard Times Linger, Customers Spend Less at the Hair Salon

BYLINE:  By DAISY HERNANDEZ 

 BODY:
Jessica Guzman is serious about her hair. Every two months, she takes a day off work to get her dark curls lightened by the colorist that she has seen for the last two years. She spends over an hour -- and close to $200 -- at the salon.
 But one recent morning, Ms. Guzman was sitting in the reception area at Vidal Sassoon on Fifth Avenue and 14th Street, waiting to get rid of her hair's highlights. Her hair is important, she said, but so is her pocketbook. 
 "With highlighting, you always have to maintain," Ms. Guzman said. "That's why I'm trying to go back to black. I can save $200 every couple of months."
Faced with a sluggish economy, more New Yorkers are rethinking their spending on their hair. Many are choosing to cut their hair less often. Some are considering the difference between the $105 haircut and the $35 one. Others, like Ms. Guzman, are ridding themselves of high-maintenance services. It has created a pattern around the city: from $12-a-buzz-cut barber shops to $300-a-visit salons, those who take care of hair are seeing less of their clients.
It was with his most loyal customers that Orin Saunders, the manager of Locks N Chops on West 34th Street, noticed something was awry. His salon has a steady clientele for his services styling black hair into Nubian twists and African locks that cost anywhere from $70 to more than $100. When he noticed a slew of cancellations, he began calling his regular customers. They admitted that they were taking care of their hair at home while job-hunting.
It was even harder with customers who used to come in twice a month for a $20 haircut.
"When the economy makes that dip, that client who came every two weeks comes every three weeks," Mr. Saunders said. "The haircut is where you lose it first."
At Vidal Sassoon, some customers are waiting up to nine weeks (instead of the usual six) between haircuts, according to Claudia Weldon, the salon's manager. She and her staff immediately felt the impact of the jobs lost in downtown Manhattan, Ms. Weldon said, because many of their clients worked in the financial district and came for haircuts on their lunch breaks.
Those who do come now are watching their spending, she said, and skipping the "little treats" like deep conditioning treatments.
"Right now I think so many people lost their jobs, so they're very picky," Ms. Weldon said. "If you go back to last year, people were spending their money right and left."
Brandi Grooms, 25, a photography student at the School of Visual Arts, admitted that she had more dreams for her hair than her budget allowed. Wearing a black choker necklace and a series of earrings on both lobes, Ms. Grooms carefully studied the catalogs of short haircuts at the Michael Giovan Salon on Third Avenue and 18th Street. Cuts here start at $30. 
Ms. Grooms said she hadn't cut her hair since February. She wanted to wait until moving to New York from Little Rock, Ark. So for a week, she had been making the rounds at city salons. One gave her a quote of $95 for a haircut.
"I wasn't ready to spend that kind of money," Ms. Grooms said. "I don't have a job yet." She has also decided that she cannot afford the highlights she wanted for her light brown hair.
Paying for a haircut, unlike other personal care like manicures, is not discretionary spending because a haircut is a necessity, according to Barbara Byrne Denham, chief economist and publisher of The New York Stat, a newsletter on the local economy. For this reason, the industry suffers from a "substitution effect" -- if times are tough, consumers substitute a less expensive option until the economy picks up again.
Downtown, at Astor Place Hairstylists, where a buzz cut costs $12, business has been steady. But haircutters and clients alike point out that the neighborhood is not hopping the way it once was. The Wiz electronics store around the corner is going out of business, and the shoe stores on Eighth Street have lost customers.
One barber thinks the economy and the general mood of the city are tied to his personal paycheck. "People get more haircuts when they're happy," said Joseph Kleynberg, who works at Astor Place. "When people make money, they want to look good."
But even when people have less spending money, hair does not lose its importance, according to Nancy Etcoff, author of "Survival of the Prettiest: The Science of Beauty," and a faculty member at Harvard University's medical school.
"Hair is the Swiss army knife of beauty tools," she said. "It conveys so much. It conveys health. It conveys sex appeal. But it also conveys taste. It's one of the ways we reinvent ourselves."
Yet reinvention has a price tag, especially at a luxury salon. At the John Barrett Salon on Fifth Avenue and 58th Street, where cuts start at $100 and cost $350 with the master himself, customers have been cutting back on their appointments in the past year. But these high-end customers have been spending more with each visit, according to Deborah Hardwick, the salon's co-owner. A customer treating herself to a morning with a stylist or colorist might add, for example, a manicure and a pedicure.
The salon has also experienced a decline in visits by its international and national clientele, whether because of a slower economy or a reluctance to travel by airplane. Even some customers who live in Texas and consider Mr. Barrett's New York City salon their salon are coming three times a year instead of the regular six.
In Gramercy Park, Antoni Marra, a barber with his own one-man shop, has lost customers, too. "Some of my customers moved out," he said. "They don't want to live in Manhattan. They have houses in Florida." 
Those who rent houses in Italy are another story. According to Olga Plitt, manager at another Vidal Sassoon salon, on Fifth Avenue and 57th Street, she saw more of her clients this summer. Those who once rented homes in Europe spent this summer nearby. "A lot of people are staying local," she said.
Ms. Denham of the newsletter said she watches nail salons as one quirky but important economic indicator, because she says thinks they constitute completely discretionary spending. In this economic downturn, she said, nail salons are not suffering as badly as they did in the downturn of the early 1990's -- perhaps, she said, because this time, many of the jobless are high-earning, white-collar workers who can still afford an $8 nail job. 
Ms. Weldon, the Vidal Sassoon salon manager, is optimistic that things will pick up. "I've had two or three people call," she said. "They said, 'I got a job, so I can come back now.' "

HEADLINE: Judging McCall By the Numbers: Scrutinizing A Pension Fund 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
The charge is one of the nastiest anyone can make against a political candidate in upstate New York: he blew a chance to create jobs.
 That is what Gov. George E. Pataki is saying about H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller and Democratic candidate for governor. Without explicitly conceding that upstate has been ailing economically, Mr. Pataki has been pounding Mr. McCall for failing to invest much of New York State's enormous pension fund there. 
 Mr. McCall's campaign has responded by invoking the vagaries of venture capital, the demands of due diligence, the fetters of fiduciary responsibility. 
But what it really boils down to, Mr. McCall's supporters say, is that creating jobs in upstate New York, however necessary, was not Mr. McCall's responsibility. It was Mr. Pataki's.
"The governor's job is to do economic development," said Steven Greenberg, the spokesman for the McCall campaign. "The comptroller's job is to manage the pension fund."
Mr. McCall would like to be judged mainly on his stewardship of the New York State Common Retirement Fund, which supports hundreds of thousands of retired state and local government workers and must support hundreds of thousands of them in the future.
The fundamental question about Mr. McCall's record is whether the fund -- at $105 billion, the second largest in the country -- has been managed well and invested wisely. Mr. McCall, of course, says it has been.
But so do other people who know and who care: union leaders, retirees, government officials, taxpayers and an array of pension experts. Mr. McCall "has endeared himself to our members based on the way he's run the pension fund," said Danny Donohue, president of the Civil Service Employees Association, which represents many of the state and local government workers covered by the pension fund. The union endorsed Mr. McCall in July.
The Business Council of New York State is also satisfied with the way the fund has been managed, said David F. Shaffer, president of the Public Policy Institute, the research arm of the business group.
And in the pension fund world, New York has a strong reputation. "McCall has been fairly responsible on the investment side -- he gets good investment advice," said Michael J. Clowes, editorial director of Pensions & Investments, the leading publication on pension investing.
Moody's Investors Service recently noted that the fund uses conservative accounting, has had strong results despite the sagging stock market, and "enjoys a solidly funded status" -- pension speak for having enough money to pay retirees' benefits.
Of course, the outlook will worsen if the stock market continues its precipitous decline, which has already wiped out several years of gains. In addition, state and local governments may have to make a substantial increase in their contributions to make up for the investment losses, at a time when their tax revenues have been tumbling.
New York's fund, unlike those in other places, is run solely by the state comptroller rather than by a committee. "The buck stops here," Mr. McCall said recently. "I'm responsible."
Mr. McCall is no investment guru, a la Warren Buffett. He is advised by a group of investment-world luminaries, as well as by a professional staff that makes recommendations (which he usually accepts). The fund also hires consultants and outside managers for some of its holdings.
Mr. McCall, a former state senator who was appointed comptroller in 1993 and has been elected twice, says he is proud of his successful efforts, including two lawsuits, to keep the cash-starved state government from raiding the pension fund.
But he cites as his most important contribution "the overall performance of the fund."
Over a 10-year period ending June 30, the fund's investments gained an average of 9.9 percent, well above the returns of most other large pension funds, according to data from Wilshire Associates, a California firm that tracks institutional investments. The median return for big funds was 9.3 percent, and the difference translates into millions of dollars a year.
Despite two years of steep stock market losses, New York's fund has continued to do better than most of its competitors. In the 12 months through June, New York's fund lost 5.6 percent, but its biggest rival, the California Public Employees' Retirement System, lost almost 5.9. New York City's funds, by contrast, lost 8.3 percent, while the Wilshire median loss was 5.8 percent.
Almost three quarters of the New York fund's stocks simply mimic the composition of stock market indexes like the S & P 500 in a program run by the fund's staff.
For a big fund like New York's, indexed investments are necessary, even though they don't fare that well when markets are down. "You put the money there to buy broad diversification, cheaply," said Catherine A. Higgins, a senior consultant at Frank Russell Company. "You didn't expect them ever to be the top performers."
Indexing has caused some problems for the fund, because as long as a stock stays in an index, it stays in the fund no matter how far the price falls.
So while one of the fund's outside investment managers, Alliance Capital, sold Enron last summer for $41 a share, Mr. McCall said, the stock remained in the indexed portion, causing a $58 million loss. (To put that in perspective, if you had a similar loss in your $10,000 401(k), you would be down by about $5.)
The outside money managers have generated their own share of controversy, in part because they tend to make generous contributions to Mr. McCall's campaigns. Mr. McCall insists the contributions have no influence on his choice of managers, most of whom are well known in the pension-management business.
Under Mr. McCall, the fund has diversified into real estate, increased its holdings of foreign stocks, and started to invest in private companies. And as its gains in the stock market ballooned in the 1990's, it took money out of the stock market so that American stocks never accounted for more than half of the investments.
While that dampened the fund's results during the market boom, it protected New York from the losses experienced by some more aggressive pension funds. "It was a strategic decision that paid off," Mr. McCall said.
Not all of the fund's choices have worked out well in the last fiscal year. A bet on foreign stocks was largely a loser, with some investments in big countries down almost 10 percent. Foreign investments make up almost 15 percent of the fund's portfolio.
It was a bad year for investing in private companies, which make up about 6 percent of the fund's investments. Nationally and in New York, venture capital investing has dried up as the stock market plunged and the outlook for high-tech companies dimmed. The fund's private equity investments lost almost 12 percent of their value in the 12 months ending in March. 
Those are the very kinds of investments for which Governor Pataki has criticized Mr. McCall, saying he has put a smaller percentage of the pension fund's direct (non-stock market) investments in state businesses than his predecessor, Edward Regan, did. Mr. McCall's camp says the overall dollar value of New York investments, including stocks, has grown to $24 billion from $14 billion since the comptroller took office. 
Mr. McCall said he, too, is disappointed by the slow pace of the state's $250 million Venture Capital Investment Program, which the Legislature authorized in 1999. He has hired four investment managers and promised them $115 million, but only $14 million has actually been invested in companies, and half has gone to firms outside of New York.
Jeffrey Gordon, a spokesman for the comptroller's office, said it had put out a request for proposals from investment managers five days after Governor Pataki signed the bill creating the program. "We heard from numerous interests who were very willing to invest our money, but who were not qualified to do so or who had insufficient track record to meet our risk tolerance or who were unable to raise capital to match our money," he said.
By late 2000, when the fund picked some outside investment firms, the venture capital boom was ending.
Experts note that investing in private companies is always a slower process than investing in public companies, because it is virtually impossible to extract yourself from a bad deal. Michael P. McQueeney of Summer Street Capital in Buffalo, one of the firms hired by Mr. McCall, said "We look at 100 deals for each one that we do."
Mr. McCall allows that the money managers he hired "have been slow, and I have been disappointed."
"But the bottom line is, you don't throw money away," he said.
Despite the problems with private investments and the poor performance of the stock market, the fund's overall performance in recent years has been strong enough that Mr. McCall could push to increase the benefits. Public employees with 10 years on the job no longer have to contribute 3 percent of their salaries to the fund, and retirees now get an annual cost-of-living raise in their pensions because of legislation that Mr. McCall backed.
Not everyone thinks the automatic annual raise, called a COLA, is a good idea, because it means that even in bad investment years, the fund will have to dispense more money to retirees. "It seems to me that the COLA could do far more long-term damage to the fund than the stock market has done," said Mr. Clowes of Pensions & Investments. 
Retirees disagree, said Kevin F. Murray, executive director of the Retired Public Employees Association in Albany. He argues that the annual adjustment, which is set at half the inflation rate, is easier for the pension fund to plan for than the occasional erratic raises granted by the Legislature.
The huge investment increases, which pushed the fund's assets to as high as $127 billion in fiscal 2000 up from $56 billion in fiscal 1993, also made it unnecessary for the state and local governments to contribute much to have their employees covered by the plan.
The contribution rate, which in the early 1980's was more than 15 percent of most employees' salaries (and close to 30 percent for police and firefighters), was zero for several years and has recently gone up to about 0.5 percent. And it may well increase; the pension fund assumes that its investment will gain 8 percent annually, a rate it has not achieved in two years.
"The poor performance of the fund is going to cost taxpayers real money across the state," said Michael McKeon, a spokesman for the Pataki campaign. Mr. McCall, he said, "needs to be held accountable for that failure." 
Mr. McCall said he knew that some local government officials were worried that they would have to boost contributions.
"I say, let's keep it in perspective," he said. "You used to have to pay between 7 and 8 percent, and for four years you've been paying almost nothing. That's not bad."

HEADLINE: MOST WANTED: DRILLING DOWN/SEMICONDUCTORS; 
Asia Gains in Chip Market

BYLINE:  By LAURIE J. FLYNN 

 BODY:
The America's share of the $131 billion worldwide semiconductor market has continued to plummet this year, dropping to only 22 percent of worldwide revenue in the second quarter of 2002, as communications and other high-technolgy companies cut costs by sending more of their chip making offshore. (The data, compiled by the market research firm InStat/MDR, groups North, Central and South America; the United States' chip output represents the vast majority of the region's total.) 
 In 1998 and 1999, at the height of the Internet boom, the Americas' share reached an all-time high of 33 percent, primarily as expanding technology businesses in the United States made their chips locally to react more quickly to the changing market, said Steve Cullen, an Instat/MDR market analyst. 
 During that period, the Asia Pacific region had less than a quarter of the market. But in April 2001, the Asia Pacific region passed the Americas and has remained ahead since. That trend has been fueled by the low labor costs in China, along with China's recent membership in the World Trade Organization. LAURIE J. FLYNN

HEADLINE: New Jersey Redraws Party Lines 

BYLINE:  By John B. Judis and Ruy Teixeira; John B. Judis, a senior editor at The New Republic, and Ruy Teixeira, a senior fellow at the Century Foundation, are the authors of "The Emerging Democratic Majority."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Senator Robert G. Torricelli's withdrawal from the New Jersey race last week could mean defeat for the state's Democrats. Not only did they lose the advantage of incumbency, but the legal and political battles over his replacement could linger through the remainder of the campaign.
 Yet unless the United States Supreme Court reverses the New Jersey Supreme Court's decision allowing the Democratic Party to replace Mr. Torricelli on the ballot with former Senator Frank Lautenberg, the Democrats stand a good chance of winning the election. That's because New Jersey, which voted for Republican presidential candidates from 1968 through 1988, is part of a nationwide swing -- particularly strong in the Northeast, Far West and parts of the Midwest -- toward the Democratic Party. 
 The first and most obvious reason for this trend is that the parties have changed. The New Jersey Republican Party used to be dominated by New Deal liberals, but since the late 70's conservatives have played a growing role. Republicans would nominate some moderates like former governors Thomas H. Kean and Christie Whitman, but they would also regularly back conservative candidates like gubernatorial nominees Jim Courter and Bret D. Schundler, whom Democrats easily defeated. Meanwhile, after voters denied re-election to Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat, in 1993, largely because of his tax increases, New Jersey Democrats have moved to the political center. Gov. James E. McGreevey was the chairman of the centrist Democratic Leadership Council in New Jersey and is fiscally cautious.
But the state's electorate has also changed dramatically. New Jersey used to be known for its heavy industry and its midsized immigrant cities, but it has become the nation's pre-eminent suburban, postindustrial state. It's a leader in financial and commercial services; it still makes goods, but many of them, like pharmaceuticals, are the products of extensive research and design. Professionals make up almost a quarter of New Jersey's work force, compared to 15 percent nationally.
In the 1950's, professionals voted Republican. But since the 1960's they have come to care more about clean air and water, women's rights, gun control and campaign finance reform. Many professionals, like doctors, worry that the quality of their work is being undermined by market forces. They don't like budget deficits and are leery of big spending programs, but they are concerned about inequality and injustice. And they increasingly vote Democratic.
Take upscale Bergen County, next to New York City, which is a bastion of professionals and which used to vote solidly Republican. In the 1988 presidential election, George Bush defeated Michael Dukakis by a margin of 58 percent to 41 percent there. Four years later, Mr. Bush's margin of victory over Bill Clinton was a mere 2 percent. In 1996, Mr. Clinton defeated former Senator Bob Dole 53 percent to 39 percent, and in 2000 former Vice President Al Gore defeated George W. Bush 55 percent to 42 percent. Within the county and across the state, Mr. Gore actually did best among more affluent and educated voters.
Democrats in New Jersey, as elsewhere, could also count on votes from women and from minorities. As the Republican Party became socially conservative in the 1980's, women, who once voted disproportionately for Republicans, began voting disproportionately for Democrats. In 2000, Mr. Bush won only 35 percent of the women's vote, compared to 62 percent for Mr. Gore. Democrats also gained the support of New Jersey's minorities, who went to 33 percent of the population in 2000 from 26 percent in 1990. In the 2000 presidential election Mr. Gore won 88 percent of the black votes and 58 percent of the Hispanic vote.
Democrats also benefited from the return of many white working-class voters -- the "Reagan Democrats" -- who had abandoned the party in the 1980's over civil rights, crime and welfare. After the 1991 recession, which took the bloom off Republican economic policies, and after the Democrats' turn to the center on crime and welfare, many of these voters began supporting Democrats. In Gloucester County, just outside of Philadelphia, where chemical plants still provide many blue-collar jobs, Ronald Reagan won 62 percent of the vote in 1984; George Bush won 59 percent of the vote four years later. By 2000, however, Mr. Gore won 57 percent of the vote while George W. Bush won just 39 percent.
These groups, particularly the professionals, women and minorities who live in the new postindustrial metropolitan areas, are changing American politics. California and Illinois, like New Jersey, also voted for Republican presidential candidates from 1968 through 1988. Like New Jersey, both states are now strongly Democratic.
Republicans can still win elections in these states. But to do so, they must either run as centrists, as did Mr. Kean and Ms. Whitman, or hope for a tarnished Democratic opponent like Mr. Torricelli. In the absence of these conditions, the Democrats are more likely to win -- in New Jersey next month and, increasingly, across the nation in the years ahead.

HEADLINE: Debate to Intensify on Copyright Extension Law 

BYLINE:  By AMY HARMON 

 BODY:
The Supreme Court is scheduled to hear arguments this week over the constitutionality of a 1998 law that extended copyright protection by 20 years. Experts on both sides of the closely watched case say that its outcome could reshape the way cultural products are consumed and how their profits are divided.
 The court's decision will determine whether a host of material -- including early Mickey Mouse movies, Cole Porter songs and Robert Frost poems -- will become available for free to the public or remain in the control of their copyright holders. 
 Since the court agreed to hear the case in February, it has become a touchstone in an increasingly acrimonious debate over how to balance the rights of consumers with those of big media companies at a time when digital technology is threatening both.
Under the 1998 law, material whose copyright formerly would have lapsed 50 years after its creator's death became protected for an additional 20 years. Copyrights held by corporations, meanwhile, were extended to 95 years, from 75 previously. 
Over the long term, supporters of the law say, it will promote creative work by offering a bigger economic payoff to those who invest in it.
The 1998 law also aligns the United States' copyright terms with those of European countries.
But detractors say the statute inhibits creativity by making it harder and more expensive for other people to obtain and build upon existing works. The 1998 law, these critics argue, mainly benefits powerful corporate copyright holders like the Walt Disney Company, whose intensive lobbying helped pass the legislation. 
The law's challengers say that it disregards the public's side of the balance that the Constitution sought to strike when it authorized Congress to issue copyrights "for limited times" to "promoted the progress of science and useful arts." The initial Copyright Act, in 1790, set a maximum term of only 28 years. 
Opponents of the 1998 law say that by issuing a series of 11 extensions over the last 40 years -- the latest being by far the longest -- Congress has exceeded its powers by, in effect, giving copyright holders a permanent monopoly over the use of their material. 
Lawrence Lessig, the Stanford law professor who has spearheaded the case since its inception almost four years ago, says that the rise of the Internet makes the copyright issue all the more urgent, because works that fall into the public domain would for the first time be easily accessible via the Internet for millions of people to enjoy and to incorporate into new digital works of their own.
"Imagine you want to do something with the New Deal, and you get images and songs and stories and put it together on the Internet for everyone to see," Mr. Lessig said last week in a telephone interview from a Washington hotel room, where he was preparing for this Wednesday's oral argument. "Just at a point where technology is making all of this available, the law ought not to get in the way for no good reason."
Mr. Lessig said that he planned to argue that throughout the last century, copyrights primarily governed only commercial entities -- companies with the printing presses, movie studios or broadcast stations capable of widely distributing information and entertainment. But now, Mr. Lessig said, copyright law touches everyone who has an Internet connection, which makes it more important than ever to adhere to the limits the Constitution intended to place on the duration of copyrights. 
The government, to be represented on Wednesday by Theodore B. Olson, the solicitor general, is expected to argue that no one, including the Supreme Court, can impose an arbitrary definition of "limited times." In its filings on the case, the government has argued that the Constitution leaves such definitions up to Congress.
But the law's opponents argue that any law limiting speech must satisfy a compelling state interest in the least restrictive way possible. The copyright term extension, they say, should be tested under the First Amendment to see whether it is overly restrictive of the free-speech rights of would-be users of copyrighted material that previously would have been in the public domain. 
Courts have traditionally rejected that position. It is also rebutted in the government's filings and in a brief by Floyd Abrams, a prominent First Amendment lawyer. Mr. Abrams argues that free speech is protected under the extension because of the fair-use provisions built into copyright law, which enable scholars, critics and other individuals to make some use of copyrighted material in their own work. What is more, he argues, the copyright law protects only the expression of ideas, not the ideas themselves. 
Jack Valenti, the chairman of the Motion Picture Association of America, said that, in practice, a longer copyright term would serve the Constitution's goal of harnessing copyright for the public good. Private ownership is the necessary incentive to make material widely available, he said. 
"Who is going to digitize these public domain movies?" Mr. Valenti said. "To digitize a movie costs a huge amount of money. Who would spend the money if they didn't own it? If you didn't own your house would you spend a lot of money to bring it up to snuff?"
The entertainment industry is particularly sensitive to copyright issues these days. File-swapping services like KaZaA are enabling Internet users to easily exchange free digital copies of copyrighted music. And the impending transition to digital television raises copyright concerns about viewers' ability to trade high-quality digital copies of movies and television shows over the Internet. 
The case has attracted 38 friend-of-the-court briefs from prominent intellectuals, artists, elected officials and advocates in numerous fields -- who in some instances seem to defy traditional political lines. Fifteen economists from across the political spectrum, including the Nobel laureates Milton Friedman and Kenneth Arrow, for instance, wrote a brief in support of the challenge, arguing that it is "highly unlikely that the economic benefits from copyright extension" outweigh the additional costs.
The conservative advocate Phyllis Schlafly, who is the founder of the Eagle Forum Education and Legal Defense Fund, also submitted a brief in support of overturning the law, as did the Intel Corporation, besides more predictable partisans like the Free Software Foundation and several library associations. 
Mr. Lessig filed the suit on behalf of Eric Eldred, a New Hampshire computer administrator who had published dozens of public-domain books online as a hobby until the copyright extension act prevented him from posting a selection of Robert Frost poems in 1998.
In an elaborate demonstration of what it means to have a public domain, Brewster Kahle, the founder of the nonprofit Internet Archive in San Francisco, is driving across the country in a van that has an Internet-linked satellite antenna on top and a laser printer inside. 
Last week Mr. Kahle made several stops at schools and libraries, as well as a bookmobile conference, to distribute "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland," "Heart of Darkness" and other books in the public domain that have been scanned and are available free online. He plans to park outside the Supreme Court and do the same on Wednesday.
Lined up on the government's side are Mr. Abrams; Dr. Seuss Enterprises; Senator Orrin Hatch, a Utah Republican; several members of the House Judiciary Committee, and virtually all of the major copyright holder trade associations. 
It will fall to Mr. Lessig, who is a former clerk for Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia and who has become a kind of rock star for the digital liberties set, to convince the justices to accept the unconventional analysis.
If they do, the decision could be a turning point in redefining a balance between copyright consumers and producers -- and the technology companies that are often in the middle. 
Among the points Mr. Lessig likes to make is that extending copyright terms for works of great artists who are deceased, like George Gershwin, cannot promote the creation of new works because the original artists themselves can no longer create.
Only about 2 percent of works protected by copyright produce continuing revenue for their owners, Mr. Lessig says. But no one can use the rest without hunting down the owners and negotiating licenses. 
Disney faced no such restrictions, he says, when the company drew on Victor Hugo's work to produce the animated film "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" or the fairy tales of the Brothers Grimm to make "Cinderella" and "Snow White."

HEADLINE: Brazil's Markets Wait To Exhale After Vote 

BYLINE:  By TONY SMITH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Oct. 6 

 BODY:
With the outcome of Brazil's election leaning toward a second round between the left-wing front runner, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, and the governing coalition's candidate, Jose Serra, markets were expected to call a truce on Monday and give the country's embattled currency and bonds a chance to recover.
 Depending on the final result, investors will be waiting to see whether Mr. da Silva, a former metalworker known as Lula, will move swiftly to assuage market nerves by naming a credible economic team, or trying to determine what chances he will have against Mr. Serra, an accomplished technocrat and the markets' favorite, in a runoff election in three weeks. 
 "It's a cliffhanger result, but assuming there's a second round, I think we might see some good news in the market," said Doug Smith, chief economist for the Americas at Standard Chartered Bank in New York. "On the other hand, if Lula ends up winning in the first round, people will resign themselves to thinking he won't be as bad as they thought." 
"There is some good will in the market for him," he added. "For the sake of Brazil, everybody wants things to work out." 
Nervousness about just how radical Mr. da Silva's economic policies would be has severely punished currency, stock and bond markets in recent months. The real has slumped to nearly four to the dollar, worth less than the peso of Brazil's bankrupt neighbor, Argentina, while the benchmark C-bond has plumbed depths of less than half its face value, levels normally reserved for a country about to default. 
Mr. Smith said that a second round would rally markets because it would allow Mr. Serra, a former health minister, an accomplished technocrat and President Fernando Henrique Cardoso's handpicked successor, to focus more on economic issues, widely seen as Mr. da Silva's principal weakness. But lacking charisma, Mr. Serra has failed to capture the hearts of many of Brazil's 115 million voters. 
Analysts said that, after months of writhing over the uncertainty of Sunday's outcome, most of the markets' worst fears had already been discounted in prices. "I think the panic will calm down as the uncertainty recedes," said Walter Molano, chief Latin American economist at BCP Securities. "You might even get a rally Monday." 
In recent weeks, Mr. Molano has been one of the most vocal advocates of dumping Brazilian paper, predicting that the country was on the slippery slope toward defaulting on its debt. 
Allan Conway, head of global emerging markets at WestAm, an asset management company in London, said, "Brazil has been ridiculously oversold and should never have gotten down to these levels." 
Should Mr. da Silva triumph, though, he will have to move swiftly to name an economic team capable of winning over the markets and of persuading banks to keep open vital credit lines to Brazil and its exporters. 
Those credit lines have been drying up just as Brazil needs all the hard currency it can get to bolster its accounts. 
The names of top-level managers like Henri Philippe Reichstul, former chief of the state oil giant Petroleo Brasileiro, and Henrique Meirelles, former chief of global banking at FleetBoston, are making the rounds on Wall Street as possible candidates for Mr. da Silva's team. 
But party stalwarts like Aloisio Mercadante and Guido Mantega, economic aides who have dragged Mr. da Silva's Workers' Party toward the center in recent years, are also in the running. 
Mr. da Silva worried analysts with his recent rejection of extending the term of Arminio Fraga as central bank president and his veiled threats of intervention in state companies. 
"The old-style Workers' Party is coming out of the woodwork," said John Welch, chief Latin American economist at WestLB in New York. 
He predicted that Mr. da Silva would be "horribly emboldened" by a first-round win and could raise the national minimum wage or loosen the grip on inflation, which could further destabilize Brazil's already precarious finances. 
But even supporters of Mr. Serra predicted that Mr. da Silva would not adopt radical policies, partly because his party is unlikely to win a majority in Congress and will have to make deals with pro-market parties. 
"There's absolutely no feeling of panic -- everything's normal," said Marcelo Lima, partner in the Sao Paulo advertising agency EugenioWG and a former investment banker, who was voting today. "Just four years ago, with Lula so far ahead, things would have been different."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC SAYS BUSH NEEDS TO PAY HEED TO WEAK ECONOMY 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY and JANET ELDER 

 BODY:
A majority of Americans say that the nation's economy is in its worst shape in nearly a decade and that President Bush and Congressional leaders are spending too much time talking about Iraq while neglecting problems at home, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
 The poll found signs of economic distress that cut across party and geographic lines. Nearly half of all Americans are worried that they or someone in their household will be out of a job within a year. 
 The number of Americans who said they believe the economy is worse than it was just two years ago has increased markedly since the summer. The number of Americans who approved of the way Mr. Bush has handled the economy -- 41 percent -- was the lowest it has been in his presidency. Many people said they worried that a war in Iraq -- which most Americans view as inevitable -- would disrupt an already unsettled economy. 
The poll found that despite the emphasis by Mr. Bush since Labor Day on the need to move against Saddam Hussein, support for such a policy has not changed appreciably since the summer. While most Americans said they backed Mr. Bush's campaign against Iraq, the sentiment was expressed with reservations and signs of apprehension about its potential repercussions.
Americans said they feared a long and costly war that could spread across the Middle East and encourage more terrorist attacks in the United States. They said they did not want the United States to act without support from allies and did not want the United States to act before United Nations weapons inspectors had an opportunity to enter Iraq. 
As Congress prepares to resume debate on a resolution supporting the use of force in Iraq, Americans said they thought members of both parties were trying to manipulate the issue for their political advantage.
"Bush is spending way too much time focusing on Iraq instead of the economy, and he's doing it as a political move," said Gladys Steele, 42, a homemaker from Seattle who is a political independent, in a follow-up interview yesterday. "He thinks keeping us fearful about going to war will distract us from how bad the economy is."
The poll was conducted a month before what Democrats and Republicans view as an extraordinarily competitive round of midterm Congressional elections. 
In recent days many Democrats have grown glum about the upcoming election, arguing that Mr. Bush and the White House have successfully drowned out domestic issues that the Democrats had hoped to capitalize on with his talk of war. Many Democrats had even feared that the debate over war had undermined their chances of winning the House and holding on to their one-seat margin in the Senate.
Mr. Bush is to deliver a national address on the subject tonight.
But the Times/CBS News poll suggests that no matter what is happening in Washington, voters are more concerned with the economy and domestic issues than with what is happening with Saddam Hussein, presenting the Democrats a glimmer of hope as Congress prepares to vote on the Iraq resolution and adjourn to campaign. 
Whether any of this makes a difference in an election that will most likely be decided in a handful of Senate and House races is an entirely different matter. A nationwide poll, while revealing of broad sentiments in the American electorate, cannot be used to predict results accurately in the relatively small number of Congressional races that are considered competitive. 
This poll, conducted by telephone Thursday through Saturday, was taken of 668 adults nationwide. It has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
By every indication, the subject of Iraq should dominate the news out of Washington for at least the next week. There is Mr. Bush's speech tonight, and then the debate in Congress is expected to last at least through Friday. 
In addition, in a handful of competitive races, Republican candidates are seeking to use the issue of acting against Iraq as a way to undercut Democratic opponents.
Two-thirds of Americans say they approve of the United States using military power to oust Mr. Hussein. A majority of Americans say that Mr. Bush has a clear plan to deal with Iraq; by contrast, a majority say the White House does not have a clear plan to deal with terrorism at home.
But there are signs of ambivalence.
With Mr. Bush pushing for quick action against Baghdad, nearly two-thirds of respondents said they wanted to give the United Nations more time to try to send weapons inspectors into Iraq. 
Similarly, most Americans said Mr. Bush should not act until he wins approval from Congress -- and they applauded Congress's pushing the administration for details on its Iraqi plans.
There were also clear suggestions that some Americans suspected that Mr. Bush's intentions went beyond simply disarming Iraq. More than half said that Mr. Bush was more interested in removing Mr. Hussein than in removing potentially lethal weapons.
Fully 7 in 10 respondents said they expected that war with Iraq was inevitable. More than half said they believed that Iraq poses a greater threat to the United States today than it did two years ago.
On a number of measures, the poll suggested that politicians in Washington were out of step with the concern of Americans. Again and again, in questions and in follow-up interviews, respondents talked more about the economy than Baghdad and expressed concern that leaders in Washington were not paying enough attention to the issues that mattered to them.
"There is no balance right now between finding solutions to our domestic problems and our foreign affairs," said Michael Chen, 30, an independent who works as a sales manager in Beaverton, Ore. "No one is talking about how to solve the economic downfall." 
Geoff Crooks, 44, an independent who lives in Lincoln, Neb., said: "We are paying way too much attention to Iraq."
"Meanwhile, the stock market has fallen 25 percent and tons of people are unemployed -- including myself," said Mr. Crooks, who had worked as a travel consultant.
Democrats have hoped that concern about the economy would allow them to turn this election into a referendum on Republican fiscal policies, in a way that would sweep out of office a large number of Republicans -- what politicians refer to as a nationalization of the election. So far, there is no evidence that that has begun. 
But the concern about the economy would seem to be a matter of concern for Mr. Bush, who is two years away from his own re-election campaign. More than two-thirds said the president should be paying more attention to the economy than he is.
"I hate to say this because I'm a Republican, but the economy was better when Clinton was in office,' said Donna Doolittle, 42, a benefits coordinator who works at a hospital in Holiday, Fla. "Maybe interest rates are low now, but health insurance is going up; there are layoffs."
Mrs. Doolittle said she thought that Mr. Bush was trying to make the country "feel safe after what happened" but added, "We need to feel safe about the economy, too."
There were other findings that could prove important over the final weeks of the campaign. Over the summer, Democrats had hoped that the turmoil on Wall Street and reports of corporate malfeasance would give them an issue to use against Republicans. The poll found that nearly half the respondents thought that Mr. Bush was more interested in protecting corporations than in protecting ordinary Americans.
There was unhappiness as well among Americans about Congress. Nearly half of the respondents said they disapproved of the way Congress was doing its job, and 70 percent said they thought it was time to throw out some incumbents and bring in some new members. In 1994, when Republicans, lead by Newt Gingrich, swept Democrats out of control of the House, that figure was 84 percent.
But at the same time, in a not-unusual bit of discordance often found by poll takers measuring the view of Congress, more than half of registered voters said they would vote to re-elect their own local representative.
Not unusually, among all respondents, Republicans were seen as stronger on the military and in dealing with terror -- the issues that have largely dominated the news out of Washington over the past month. Democrats are seen as the stronger party in dealing with domestic issues; in particular, Social Security and prescription drugs. Those are the issues that party leaders said they were planning to try once more to emphasize once Congress leaves Washington and the campaigns move into their final days.

How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Thursday through Saturday with 668 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 42,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variation in the sample relating to geographic region, sex, race, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than four percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups, the margin of sampling error is larger.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variation in the wording and order of questions, for example, may lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: A Spirited Race for Congress Brings Politics to the Arizona Desert 

BYLINE:  By Andres Martinez 

DATELINE: SEDONA, Ariz. 

 BODY:
The other night George Cordova came to the public library here pursuing votes in one of the more improbable battlegrounds in the fight for control of Congress. Sedona's serene and otherworldly red-rock buttes in the high Sonoran Desert have long lured visitors, retirees and New Age spiritualists seeking to get away from it all. This year they are luring the politicians.
 The First Congressional District is one of two new House seats in Arizona. Covering 60,000 square miles, it is the largest Congressional district in the nation that is not a whole state. It also has one of only 35 or so competitive House races nationwide. That's why President Bush and Terry McAuliffe, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, have stopped by recently. 
 Arizona is fertile ground in the Democrats' long-shot quest for a net gain of seven seats, which they need to wrest control of the House. The other new district, to the southwest, is heavily Hispanic and Democratic, a sure thing. If Mr. Cordova wins, Democrats will have cut the Republicans' edge in the Arizona House delegation from 5-to-1 to 5-to-3. The fact that the three Democrats with the best chances of winning are Hispanic speaks volumes about the threat demographics could someday pose to Arizona's Republican hegemony. 
The First Congressional District is the West writ large -- encompassing the Grand Canyon, numerous mining communities, the Navajo and other Indian nations and towns like Flagstaff, Prescott and Casa Grande. There are sizable Mormon, Native American and Hispanic populations. Washington may seem like a long way off, but in truth the federal government here looms far larger than it does almost anywhere else. For starters, it owns much of the land. When Mr. Cordova, a 36-year-old businessman, addresses federal policy regarding water disputes, mining rights and forest fires, he is talking about pressing local issues. 
Unlike many contests these days, this one offers strong contrasts, with Mr. Cordova wanting government to do more and his Republican opponent, Rick Renzi, 44, wanting it to do less. Mr. Cordova supports abortion rights and is sympathetic to environmentalists' concerns. Mr. Renzi opposes abortion rights and scoffs at his opponent's "anti-ranch" environmental views. Mr. Cordova thinks widespread economic anxiety should help the Democratic Party, here and nationally. Mr. Renzi disagrees, arguing that district residents are more concerned about environmental obstacles to economic development and bureaucratic mandates imposed on small businesses than about falling stock prices. Mr. Renzi thinks he is a better fit for a district where he claims 72 percent of the residents go to church and have conservative views on issues of "life, morality and family values."
Mr. Renzi also emphasizes that he has 12 children -- all of whose names begin with "R" -- while his opponent has none and is single. As for the growing Hispanic vote, this need not be a threat to Republicans, in his view, as long as Hispanics "stay true to their Catholic heritage." 
In his talk at the Sedona library, Mr. Cordova focuses on health care. Adding a prescription drug benefit to Medicare, he says, should be Congress's top priority. "Something is wrong when we must run shuttles to Nogales so that the greatest generation can afford their medications," he says, referring to the Mexican border town. 
Parochial issues might ordinarily determine this election's outcome, but this is no ordinary year. The country is still suffering the aftershocks of 9/ll, and of the stock market's meltdown. There is also the talk of war. "The economy and Iraq are such overpowering issues right now that they crowd out the usual local concerns," says Zach Smith, a political scientist at Northern Arizona University. "In coffee shops in places like Prescott and Winslow, people are talking about the same two topics people are talking about in New York and Washington."
On the war issue, Mr. Renzi's more obvious hawkishness could help in a state that, one Sedona Democrat, Jackie Young, concedes with a sigh, is "pro-gun" and "pro-war." Mr. Renzi calls his opponent "undecided and soft." However, these charges have been blunted to some extent by the support Richard Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, has given to President Bush.
Mr. Cordova doesn't mention Iraq during his presentation. But when the issue is raised during a question-and-answer period, he insists there is no "sunlight between me and our commander in chief," though when he elaborates, some rays do come through.
With neither candidate well known in a district so vast it takes eight hours to drive across it, the Democrats' slight numerical advantage is offset by the Republicans' vast material superiority. Mr. Renzi is expected to spend at least twice as much as Mr. Cordova, and Mr. Cordova's strongest potential supporters are the least likely to turn out at the polls. 
In the end, however, the way the two great issues of the day unfold in coming weeks could determine the outcome of not just this race but others across the country. Consider two different Nov. 5 scenarios. In one, Washington presents a unified front on Iraq while new revelations of corporate malfeasance and economic weakness trigger new rounds of selling on Wall Street. In the other, renewed partisan bickering on Iraq breaks out while signs emerge of a stronger economic rebound. 
It is hard to imagine that the outcome of the race in Arizona's First Congressional District would be the same under both scenarios.
