HEADLINE: Better Laws to Settle the Port Labor Dispute 

BYLINE:  By William B. Gould IV; William B. Gould IV was chairman of the National Labor Relations Board from 1994 to 1998 and is author of "Labored Relations: Law, Politics and the N.L.R.B."

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore. 

 BODY:
The last time a president tried to invoke the Taft-Hartley Act, which provides for federal intervention if a strike or lockout threatens "national health or safety," he failed. In 1978, a federal judge rejected President Jimmy Carter's effort to use the act to halt a coal miners' strike.
 President Bush's invocation of the act this week to end the management lockout of the longshore workers' union on the West Coast is likely to be more successful, particularly if the evidence shows that national security is imperiled. The growth of globalization should make the court even more receptive to the president's argument, and courts have been willing to grant injunctions in past port disputes. 
 But while invoking Taft-Hartley may be a smart legal strategy, it is fundamentally flawed as a labor policy. The Taft-Hartley procedures tend to inflame labor-management passions rather than promote the dialogue and compromise that are the necessary elements of collective bargaining. Management's willingness to compromise is dissipated by the knowledge that the federal government can intervene.
The Taft-Hartley Act, passed in 1947, allows the president to seek an injunction against a work stoppage. If the courts grant it, there is an 80-day cooling-off period, during which the two sides may negotiate under the supervision of a federal mediator. If they are still unable to reach an agreement after 80 days, the workers can go on strike or management can lock them out; in effect, the dispute is no further toward resolution.
The International Longshore and Warehouse Union, which represents 10,500 workers on the West Coast, has been working without a contract since Sept. 1. On Sept. 29, shippers and port operators shut down 29 West Coast ports, saying the union was engaging in a work slowdown. But the lockout was also meant to produce White House intervention. An injunction would allow companies to begin shipping again and, in the process, diminish their willingness to bargain through January.
Supporters and opponents of Taft-Hartley in Congress make predictable arguments. Union-hostile Republicans and moderate or conservative Democrats are alarmed by the danger to the economy and favor federal intervention. Liberal Democrats are against intervention because it is inconsistent with free and autonomous collective bargaining. There is a third way, however, which is fair to both sides and produces a final and binding settlement: final-offer arbitration.
Such arbitration would encourage the voluntary resolution of differences. It would require the third-party neutral arbitrator to select the final offer of one side or the other -- taking into account practices in other industries, economic considerations and questions of basic fairness. Thus it would create an incentive for each party to be more reasonable in its demands in order to have its position selected. This formula has been successful in public-employee disputes and in baseball salary arbitrations.
There are both practical and political problems with this approach, however. While management generally favors arbitration, the dock workers would be fearful that they would get less from arbitration than from economic pressure. Moreover, organized labor would not have confidence in an arbitration process overseen by the Bush administration, given its intervention in airline negotiations and its bashing of public-sector unions in the debate over the Homeland Security legislation. Yet final-offer arbitration, if it contains new authority for state government leadership, might attract labor support.
It might be difficult to put this procedure in place promptly enough to cope with the current dispute. Therefore labor and management should begin now to get federal legislation that would allow for states to oversee final-offer arbitration in all such future disputes.
It may sound unrealistic. But there are ways to make it work: If the law required the arbitration panel to be appointed by governors of the states most affected by the work stoppage, for instance, labor's objections to federal oversight of the system might be answered. The involvement of state officials would also induce the strong political advocacy at both the federal and state level which is necessary for the bill's success.
Legislation replacing Taft-Hartley's archaic and one-sided injunction process should be introduced without delay. It would be an invaluable tool in resolving future strikes and lockouts -- and the mere prospect of it could help spur meaningful negotiations in the current labor dispute. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE AFTERMATH; 
Rift Over Plan to Impose Rule on Iraq

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO and ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 

 BODY:
The Bush administration is considering plans to create a provisional government for Iraq that could provide a base for opposition to President Saddam Hussein and form the core of a new government if Mr. Hussein is ousted, senior administration officials said. 
 But the proposal, which is being pushed by several Iraqi exile groups has received mixed reaction inside the administration. It has strong support among Pentagon officials, who want to incorporate it into invasion plans. But the State Department and the Central Intelligence Agency have been cool to the idea. 
 One proposal calls for American troops to seize and defend territory inside Iraq where exile groups could set up an interim capital before or during an invasion to topple Mr. Hussein. Proponents contend that creating an alternative government on Iraqi soil would encourage military commanders and government officials to break with Mr. Hussein during the initial phases of an attack. That, they argue, could hasten the collapse of the Baghdad government. 
"It's like the role of the French resistance during World War II," said one Iraqi opposition leader. "The United States stood up DeGaulle, gave him a P.R. role, gave him credibility, and helped establish a government the French people could rally around." 
But senior officials in the State Department and C.I.A. argue that the administration should encourage a homegrown leadership, not impose one. A provisional government would give the exile groups a head start in controlling the country's vast oil wealth, causing resentment and perhaps even civil war, they say. 
"The idea of a provisional central government is just a power grab, as far as I can see," said a person involved in State Department planning for a post-Hussein government. 
In his nationally televised speech on Monday, President Bush spoke only in broad terms about how the administration and its coalition partners would deal with a post-Hussein Iraq, a series of plans that White House officials say is still evolving. 
"If military action is necessary, the United States and our allies will help the Iraqi people rebuild their economy and create the institutions of liberty in a unified Iraq at peace with its neighbors," Mr. Bush said. 
The differences over a provisional government exemplify a rift on Iraq policy that has bedeviled the Bush administration for months and disrupted planning for reconstructing Iraq if Mr. Hussein is deposed, Iraq experts and exile leaders say. 
Hawks close to the Pentagon blame the disruptions on the State Department, arguing that the agency has been slow to plan for a post-Hussein government because it dislikes the exile groups, particularly the Iraqi National Congress.
"State has been reluctant to think about Iraq after Saddam, in part because that would force them to think about who we are dealing with among the opposition," said Richard Perle, chairman of the Defense Policy Board, an advisory panel to Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld. "We should have developed a government in exile long ago." 
But State Department officials contend that it has been difficult to plan for a new regime because it has not been clear -- and is still not clear, they say -- how Mr. Hussein may be deposed. Planning for all those contingencies is complex and has only recently begun, the officials said. 
"In the end, it's not going to be a made-in-Washington blueprint," the senior official said. "Will we parachute in our government-in-exile and say, 'Here are your new rulers.'? Let's be realistic. People who are inside Iraq are going to decide Iraq's future." 
An alternative to the provisional government plan circulating in the State Department calls for creating an interim council representing Iraqis from both inside and outside the country that could help guide reconstruction. But under that plan, the central government -- and particularly the oil industry -- would be administered by the United Nations and the United States military until a democratic government could be created, a process that could take years, officials said. 
"Oil is key to holding the country together," said one person involved in planning for a post-Hussein Iraq.
To encourage planning by the Iraqi opposition, the State Department has begun bringing together Iraqi political leaders and intellectuals to develop position papers on a range of topics, including democratic institutions, the judiciary, the media, water and agriculture, oil, health care, education and public finance. 
But many Iraqi opposition leaders deride the effort as an academic exercise. The United States should be helping to organize and preparing to recognize a provisional government that can take power the moment Baghdad falls, they contend. 
They want the administration to endorse a provisional government before a major conference of opposition groups that may take place in Brussels later this month. That conference is intended to demonstrate that the politically and ethnically diverse groups, who have squabbled frequently in the past, can unite behind a new government. 
Meanwhile, the Pentagon has been developing its own plans for Iraq following an invasion. They include maintaining a large multinational army in Iraq for at least a year to track down and eliminate Iraq's clandestine weapons programs, ensure stability around the country and deal with potential problems in providing assistance to civilians. 
In northern Iraq, military forces would probably protect the oil fields around Kirkuk and Mosul to prevent rival groups from trying to seize them. The largest foreign presence would likely be in the central part of the country around Baghdad, Mr. Hussein's power base. 
In addition to military security forces, thousands of military civil affairs specialists, familiar with the linguistic and cultural differences within Iraq, would probably be deployed throughout the country, officials said. 
Some influential advisers say the post-Hussein planning process is too disjointed, with State Department and Pentagon planning operating on completely separate tracks. Stephen J. Hadley, the deputy national security adviser, oversees the administration's planning. 
The advisers, who include former House Speaker Newt Gingrich and Mr. Perle, argue that the White House should create a high-level interagency group to coordinate the military and reconstruction planning before an invasion takes place. That sort of powerful council could overcome the bureaucratic and philosophical divisions that have hindered reconstruction planning, the advisers contend. 
"It was a mistake we made in Afghanistan," said Mr. Gingrich, who sits on the Defense Policy Board. "You shouldn't go into a country militarily without having thought through what it should look like afterward."

HEADLINE: Dispute Lingers as Longshoremen Return to Work 

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 9 

 BODY:
Erik Ragland was among the thousands of longshoremen who returned to work today along the West Coast under a federal court order. His sweaty handshake and the sheet of perspiration seeping from beneath his hard hat were proof enough of that.
 But like many of his fellow union members, Mr. Ragland was steaming about a lot more than a hard day's work in the sun. He was grateful to be on the job for the first time in nearly two weeks, he said while catching his breath during a break from unloading a container ship on the waterfront here. Money has been so tight that earlier this year he moved in with his parents, he said. 
 But do not expect Mr. Ragland, 33, to be happy. In his view, the order to reopen the ports to the longshoremen, issued Tuesday at President Bush's request, was a tactic of the port operators to break the union. Mr. Bush had no business interfering in their contract negotiations, he said, and by doing so, he tipped the balance against the union workers.
"The Pacific Maritime Association has been using devious tactics," Mr. Ragland said of the group that represents the shipping lines and terminal operators. "This is slickery and trickery at work. The plan all along was to get Bush to come in."
The association denies the contention, insisting it had no choice but to close the 29 West Coast ports because longshoremen, working without a contract since June, had engaged in a work slowdown. The union said workers were only observing safety regulations because five longshoremen have died on the job this year. 
"We regret that it came to this, and did everything we could at the bargaining table to avoid it," Joseph Miniace, president of the association, wrote in response to the order. "The union wasn't willing to go along."
Mr. Bush stepped in after the two sides deadlocked in sessions with a federal mediator and his advisers suggested that the mounting toll on the economy was too great. The injunction issued Tuesday night will remain in effect until next week, when a hearing will be held on whether to grant a full 80-day injunction.
Yet if part of the idea behind the required reopening of the ports was to cool tempers, indications among the workers were not encouraging.
As trucks lined up at the Port of Oakland, the longshoremen spoke bitterly of their employers and indicated they had no intention of working faster. About 225 vessels were idled by the lockout, including 30 anchored here and in the San Francisco Bay, and it was unclear how long it might take to cope with the backlog.
"For a lot of people it is tough being out of work; a lot of us don't make the kind of money they say we make," said Ernest Evans, a longshoreman for 35 years. "We want to work, but not under these circumstances."
Mr. Evans said he remembered when President Richard M. Nixon intervened in the last big contract dispute, in 1971. That time, the union was on strike, and after being forced back to work for 80 days under the Taft-Hartley Act, returned to the picket lines for another month or so.
"The employers didn't want to negotiate before we were ordered back to work, and they still didn't want to negotiate after the 80 days," Mr. Evans said. "I see the same thing happening again."
Eusebio Perez, who is scheduled to retire next month, was also pessimistic. Mr. Perez was listening to the radio in his pickup truck after being told there was no equipment to operate. With so many workers returning, the terminal operators were scrambling to decide which ships to load and unload first. The confusion left some people being paid to wait.
During the strike in 1971, Mr. Perez worked odd jobs at night to keep his house. This time, Mr. Perez, 66, is not worried about the money, but he fears for his union friends -- and the union itself.
"From the bottom of my heart I disagree with President Bush," Mr. Perez said. "These companies are not playing fair with us. 
One of the central issues in the dispute involves how to deal with new technology management wants to introduce to speed the movement of cargo. That technology would most directly threaten the marine clerks, union members who deal mostly with paperwork rather than loading and unloading ships. The union fears the loss of those jobs, which are generally higher paying, would be a devastating blow, particularly since many longshoremen aspire to be clerks.
One clerk, Roger K. Alexander, said he had been working despite the lockout since late last week because of an agreement to exempt military supplies from the stoppage. Even with the exemption, though, some commercial vessels carrying military cargo were snarled in the shutdown, leading President Bush and others to worry about its handling.
Mr. Alexander said he sympathized with Mr. Bush's predicament, but he hoped people would try to understand the union's position. After years of fighting to keep jobs, it would be suicide to accept a contract that allowed the new technology jobs to go to nonunion workers, he said.
"We are not union thugs," he said. "We are just trying to keep our share of the pie."

(Photographs by Peter DaSilva for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: White House Joins Fight Against Electric Cars 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 

 BODY:
The Bush administration went to court today to support the automobile industry's effort to eliminate requirements in California that auto manufacturers sell electric cars.
 President Bush's chief of staff, Andrew H. Card Jr., was the chief lobbyist for General Motors, one of the plaintiffs in the case. Mr. Card was also head of an auto industry trade association when California proposed to require electric vehicles, and has publicly opposed such a requirement. 
 Under California clean air rules, 10 percent of the vehicles sold in the 2003 to 2008 model years must be electric or "zero-emission vehicles." But the state, recognizing that the car companies were not ready to meet that goal, offered to let them sell hybrid vehicles, which run on gasoline and electricity, to satisfy part of the requirement. 
Still, the industry wants to avoid having quotas at all and was not satisfied with that relaxation of the rules. It sued the state, arguing that the hybrid provision violated federal law.
Katherine Kennedy, a lawyer at the Natural Resources Defense Council, which supports the California rule, said that California "attempted to make things more flexible for the car manufacturers, and cheaper, and this lawsuit is what they got as thanks."
In a brief filed today with the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, the Bush administration endorsed the industry's argument that this substitution was improper because it would, in effect, regulate fuel economy standards, over which the federal government holds exclusive jurisdiction. The car companies would get credit toward the electric-vehicle quota depending on the fuel economy of the hybrids.
The brief does not appear to raise any new substantive arguments, but it carries some political significance in that it appears to favor Detroit over Los Angeles. Mr. Bush lost Michigan in 2000 to Vice President Al Gore, and while Mr. Bush was defeated in California as well, the vote was far closer in Michigan. Mr. Bush has been reaching out to union voters and is hoping to capture the state in 2004 while the likelihood of California voting for him appears more remote.
"The major issue isn't the substance of the brief but the fact of the brief," said Daniel Becker, director of the global warming and energy program for the Sierra Club. "The fact that the Bush administration, with the former chief lobbyist of G.M. as a chief of staff, is weighing in on the side of G.M. to overturn California's efforts to clean the air that Californians breathe is outrageous."
Scott McLellan, a spokesman for the White House, dismissed the accusation that the administration was siding with General Motors because of Mr. Card's past connection.
"Congress long ago made clear there should be a uniform fuel economy standard," Mr. McLellan said. "The American people would be best served if the leadership of special interest groups worked with us in our efforts to increase fuel efficiency, promote safety and improve air quality."
Congress has long allowed California to set its own emission standards because smog there is so bad. As a result, the state has set emission requirements that have forced car companies to invent new technologies for pollution control.
Since 1990, California has been trying to incubate an electric car industry, putting it on the leading edge of battle between clean-air advocates and the automakers. What California does, states in the Northeast tend to adopt as well, another reason the car companies are trying to block the electric car, which they say is impractical in California and even worse in cold climates.
Environmentalists said that the auto industry initiated contact with the Bush administration to file the brief on the industry's behalf. Jon S. Coifman, a spokesman for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said, "It's our understanding that this whole thing is expressly at the behest of auto industry plaintiffs."
The administration brief acknowledges that the hybrid option is one of several ways that the car companies could meet the requirements. But it noted that a lower court found that "these other alternatives are in fact impractical, and that manufacturers seeking to minimize their costs will be forced to produce hybrid vehicles that meet the state's fuel efficiency standard."
It also said that the state cannot list compliance options in matters -- like fuel economy -- where only the federal government is allowed to regulate.
In a statement tonight, Gov. Gray Davis said: "Fuel cell and hybrid technology is a decade ahead of where it would have been in the absence of zero-emission vehicle regulations. I am disappointed that the federal government would intervene with our efforts to protect our air quality."

HEADLINE: Fighting Mayor's Proposed Smoking Ban Not on the Basis of Health, but of Economics 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and smoking opponents will face off with restaurant, nightclub and bar owners today at the first hearing on the mayor's proposal to ban smoking in all public places in New York City, which would be one of the strictest antismoking laws in the country.
 When Mr. Bloomberg first announced his proposal in August as a way to protect the health of restaurant workers, there were few voices of dissent. 
 But in recent weeks, opponents have become more vocal, sending letters to newspapers, peppering City Council members with phone calls and visits and hiring lobbyists. 
"We are not arguing the health issue," said E. Charles Hunt, the executive vice president for the city chapter of the New York State Restaurant Association, whose survey of hundreds of members last month said that 65 percent oppose the proposed law. "Because it is pretty hard to argue that. But we have heard from a lot of employees who understand the risks and are fearful that business will decline drastically and they will lose their job. Maybe that is not good judgment on their part, but they certainly have a right to make that decision."
Some restaurant owners and their workers support the bill, which would go beyond the current law banning smoking in restaurants over 35 seats, making all restaurants totally smoke-free, as well as bars, bingo parlors and private clubs. One supporter, Richard Toes, who has tended bar for 22 years, said he is tired of refereeing fights between smokers and nonsmokers at his bar. "I can't tell you how bad it is," he said. "I have seen everything short of fisticuffs over smoking."
But many other restaurants and bars, particularly those in poor neighborhoods and within hotels, staunchly oppose the measure, and argue that a weak economic period presents the worst time to test what the mayor says is irrefutable evidence that establishments will not lose money once they go smoke-free. Hotel owners, for instance, are particularly concerned about international tourists.
"Our members are telling us that cocktail lounges and bars in their hotels host a great number of visitors from Europe, South America and Asia who insist on smoking," said Joseph E. Spinnato, president of the Hotel Association of New York City, in an e-mail message. "They may go elsewhere, causing those cocktail lounges and bars to be less frequented. In that case, the people the legislation is trying to protect may be without jobs."
The New York Nightlife Association says that 21 percent of 1,043 customers surveyed in bars and clubs said they would spend less time and money in those places if smoking were banned. 
Brendan McCormick, a spokesman for Philip Morris Companies, which has laid low in this most recent battle, said "a handful" of trade groups and bars had requested money from the tobacco company to help fight the bill. He said the company was "looking at a broad number of requests." In 1994, when the City Council was pondering the current law, the Empire State Restaurant and Tavern Association accepted roughly a half million dollars in aid from the company.
On the other side, the American Cancer Society and other advocates for the law have also approached the council. 
People on both sides of the issue have said it has been difficult to take the measure of council members or their speaker, Gifford Miller, who has yet to take a position on the bill and whose decision will ultimately guide the body.
But antismoking opponents have a more attentive audience in the speaker than they might have a year ago, largely because Mr. Miller has been disenchanted with Mr. Bloomberg, who announced his intentions without consulting the speaker, and who spent much of the summer suggesting that anyone who opposed his bill in any form was insensitive.
Further, Mr. Miller is seizing on the smoking bill as leverage for other things he wants from the mayor, such as budget relief in areas that are of key interest to council members, aides say. Several members said they are interested in exploring a less stringent law, one that perhaps leaves bars open to smokers. Mr. Bloomberg and his aides bristle at the notion of a horse trade on this legislation.
The mayor, who plans to testify today, has suggested that he will not sign any legislation that comes short of his vision for a smoke-free city. "The essence of the bill is either you have clean air for people that are working there or you don't,"' Mr. Bloomberg said at a news conference yesterday with Dr. Jeffrey S. Wigand, the antitobacco whistle-blower and founder of the Smoke-Free Kids organization.
But the mayor has said that before about his proposals, then later accepted compromises. And he has toned down his rhetoric in recent weeks, commending Mr. Miller for calling a speedy hearing. He added that it will be his job to persuade the Council when he testifies today.
The mayor's aides are confident that their measure, which has the support of 22 members and needs 26 votes, will pass. "There is a raft of people willing to testify that this is not bad for business and it is good for health," said William Cunningham, Mr. Bloomberg's communications director.

HEADLINE: In Campaigns Nationwide, Plans for Social Security Become a Focus of Ads 

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 

 BODY:
For years, Republicans have privately fumed over the predictable barrage of election commercials by Democrats on Social Security, while doing little to fend off the blows.
 This year, however, the Republicans are flicking the sand off their faces and fighting back. In a coordinated and calculated strategy, Republicans in the House and Senate are delivering quick and sharp counterpunches to dispute Democrats' contentions that the Republicans plan to pilfer the Social Security checks of the elderly by steering their retirement money into the stock market. 
 A result is a barrage of advertisements about Social Security so large that it is framing the debate on the issue. In race after race, Democrats are seizing on the tumbling stock market to underscore the danger of privatization, the term they use to describe President Bush's plan to funnel part of Social Security proceeds into private investment accounts. Most Republicans, in a turnaround, are distancing themselves from the plan and pledging to protect benefits. 
If there is a common theme among the Republican advertisements, it is in their portrayal of Democrats as a horde of "fright mongers" who are rustling bushes in the dark.
"It's a case of a planned aggressive reaction by Republicans," said Glen Bolger, a Republican pollster who works on many Congressional races. "We know the Democrats are going to come after us on Social Security. So let's not get caught napping."
When Alex Sanders, the Democrat who is running for the Senate in South Carolina, ran an advertisement that said Representative Lindsey Graham, the Republican nominee, supported a "risky stock market scheme," Mr. Graham answered with his own commercial.
"Sanders and his Washington handlers run television ads full of distortions to scare seniors, ads that have been called bogus appeals to emotion that are trying to scare us all to death," the narrator in the commercial says as images of Mr. Graham and President Bush flash on the screen. To drive home the point, the commercial ends with the word "Bogus" plastered on the screen.
Elizabeth Dole, who is running to fill the Senate seat in North Carolina, tried to defuse the attacks from her Democratic opponent by looking straight in the camera and saying of her opponent: "Erskine Bowles has distorted my record again. So let's help him get it straight. I will never vote to take one single penny away from seniors on Social Security."
In some cases, Republicans are trying to turn the tables on Democrats with advertisements that say they have violated the Social Security trust by voting to raise taxes on benefits under President Bill Clinton.
"Democrat Tim Holden calls himself a conservative," says an advertisement by the House Republican campaign committee in Pennsylvania. "But what kind of conservative votes against our seniors on Social Security?" 
Representative Holden, a Democrat, is facing Representative George W. Gekas, a Republican, in a redrawn district.
Democrats, who delight in their dominance on Social Security issues, say they have nothing to fear from the counterattacks. The economy is in trouble, the stock market is in the gutter, and many Republicans are on record as supporting Mr. Bush's Social Security proposal. The shift to private accounts, the Democrats argue, would reduce the guaranteed monthly amounts in Social Security checks.
All of that adds up to a delectable year for Democrats to debate the issue, they say.
"Even if the ads fight each other to a draw," a spokeswoman for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, Jenny Backus, said, "people trust Democrats on the issue inherently more."
A spokesman for the Senate Republican campaign committee, Dan Allen, said Democrats had pounced on the word privatize in commercial after commercial to frighten voters into thinking that Republicans want to dismantle Social Security. Republicans avoid the word at all costs.
"Democrats are trying to find their hook for this cycle," Mr. Allen said. "They want to demonize it with one word, privatization."
In Missouri, the issue has led to four television commercials in a month. Former Representative Jim Talent, who is challenging Senator Jean Carnahan, a Democrat, co-sponsored a bill in 1993 that would have allowed individual retirement accounts. The accounts would have been financed by payroll deductions and employer contributions. The legislation could also have imposed penalties for failing to create the accounts.
That point was brought to voters' attentions in an advertisement that the state's Democratic Party paid for and that begins with a picture of men on the stock exchange floor. A voice says: "An unstable economy. Falling financial markets. All that, and Jim Talent would invest Social Security money in the stock market? It's true."
Confronting the charge, the state's Republican Party put out a commercial in which Mr. Talent, looking squarely into the camera, said: "There they go again. Another lie. The liberal groups of Washington can say whatever they want. I am not going to vote to privatize Social Security. Tell Jean Carnahan to stop scaring seniors."
Not all Republicans are taking a defensive approach. Last week, a new group of powerful allies, the Coalition for the Modernization and Protection of America's Social Security, or Compass, started its advertisements in 20 markets, pushing the idea of personal savings accounts to rescue Social Security.
The coalition is financed by the Business Roundtable and the United States Chamber of Commerce, among other groups, and expects to spend $8 million on its campaign, which includes mailings and print advertising. 
A spokesman for the group, Derrick Max, said it was trying to fill a void left by Republicans who had mostly turned their backs on individual accounts. Mrs. Dole is promoting a plan to let workers invest part of their payroll taxes in accounts similar to those in 401(k) plans, but that the government would administer.
"My plan doesn't affect seniors," Mrs. Dole said in an advertisement. "It helps their grandchildren increase their benefits without raising taxes."
For the Compass organization, Mrs. Dole's race is critical. 
"We will be able to point to it," Mr. Max said, "and say you can be in a tough race with a lot of money spent and you can discuss the issue and win. But if she loses . . ."

HEADLINE: Asian Companies Relieved over Reopening of U.S. Ports 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Oct. 9 

 BODY:
Businesses across East Asia expressed relief today after President Bush won a temporary court order to reopen 29 West Coast ports in the United States, although worries persisted that the underlying labor dispute had not been resolved.
 So far, at least, the 11-day shutdown of the ports does not appear to have lasted long enough to inflict serious damage on big exporters like China, Japan and Taiwan. The possibility that West Coast ports might be closed temporarily has been a top subject of conversation among East Asian business executives for several months, and many companies took precautions that appear to have blunted the initial effects of the port closings. 
 Many businesses, like the Giant Manufacturing Company, which is based in Taiwan and is one of the world's largest bicycle manufacturers, sent huge extra shipments to American warehouses over the summer to ensure that stores would not suffer a disruption of supply. 
Some high-technology companies booked extra shipments in advance on special air freight services like the four chartered jumbo jet freighters a week from East Asia to the United States that Danzas AEI Ltd., a German logistics company, began offering in early September for customers worried about a possible labor dispute.
"We anticipated something like this would happen," said Peter M. Landsiedel, Danzas's vice president for North Pacific operations.
Government officials in the region like Henry Tang, Hong Kong's secretary of commerce, industry and technology, said today that the West Coast port closings did not appear to have inflicted any enduring harm.
Piles of shipping containers have started to accumulate on some docks at Hong Kong's container port, the world's largest, and the Hong Kong government set up a task force today to help manage the distribution of increasingly scarce empty containers to exporters here and in southern China. But orders have not been permanently lost to suppliers elsewhere, Mr. Tang said. "The shipments are only stored up in Hong Kong, and they are not being canceled," he explained.
The shipping problem has come closest to being acute for China, which is the biggest shipper to West Coast ports, having overtaken Japan. Factories in China, often owned by businesses from Taiwan and Hong Kong, also tend to produce a lot of bulky, low-cost goods, from toys to refrigerators, and air shipment is often not financially feasible for them. 
Exports from East Asia surged in late summer as companies prepared for the American labor dispute. Hong Kong's exports, for example, grew at an annual rate of 6 percent in the second quarter, but this surged to 11 percent in July and August as companies stuffed warehouses in the United States with extra shipments.
Giant Manufacturing has nearly a two months' supply of bicycles in storage in the United States, twice the normal inventory, said Jeffrey Sheu, a spokesman. Giant also lined up backup supplies of suspension forks, which it imports from the United States for its best models of bicycles, sold under several brand names including Giant and Trek.
"At present, there is no impact to Giant" from the temporary closing of the ports, Mr. Sheu said.
Clothing companies were less able to stockpile goods in American warehouses because fashion changes faster for garments than for bicycles. Rebecca Wei, the assistant general manager of the Shirley International Company Ltd., a large sportswear company based in Taipei, said that her business's operations in Asia had accumulated huge inventories of unshipped merchandise.
It is typically the garment customer's responsibility to choose the transportation and pay for it, and few buyers have become desperate enough yet to pay for air freight. "So far, we don't see any serious effect," she said, adding that she remained concerned that port operators and longshoremen had not yet resolved their differences.
A federal judge is expected to rule next week whether to impose an 80-day cooling-off period on both sides. But the port operators could lock out the workers again, as happened in the current dispute, at the end of the cooling-off period, or the workers could go on strike.
The businesses most affected by the port closings appear to have been those supplying parts to manufacturers in the United States that operate factories with very lean inventories. Toyota prides itself on keeping scant supplies of parts next to its assembly lines or in nearby warehouses, but that has proved a handicap during the port shutdown.
Toyota said today that it would step up its air shipments of auto parts from its suppliers to the United States while waiting for ports to reopen and backlogs to clear.
China Airlines, the world's eighth-largest hauler of air cargo, announced today that it had scheduled eight extra flights of Boeing 747-400 freighters to Los Angeles and Chicago by the end of next week, increasing its cargo capacity on these routes by 15 percent. To free pilots for the extra trips, the Taipei-based airline canceled several passenger flights.
The airline said that it would schedule additional cargo flights if it found enough customers.
Fred Hu, the chief economist in the Hong Kong office of Goldman, Sachs, said the temporary reopening of the ports would help East Asia but did not address the biggest danger the region faces: the risk that American consumers might someday slow down the buying binge that has kept so many Asian exporters profitable and growing.
"This by itself is not a great cause for celebration," Mr. Hu said of the reopening of the ports. "The central threat to Asia and its trade flows is sluggish demand in the United States."

HEADLINE: Democrats Want Change At the S.E.C. 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 

 BODY:
The search led by Harvey L. Pitt for a new top accounting regulator turned into a political brawl today as administration officials defended him against prominent Democrats who called for Mr. Pitt to be removed as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
 The Democratic leaders of the Senate and House urged President Bush in a letter to oust Mr. Pitt, who has become a lightning rod for renewed criticism of the administration's handling of the economy and what some see as its inability to overcome declining confidence among stock market investors. 
 They said that Mr. Pitt's decision to back away from an earlier commitment to support John H. Biggs, a widely endorsed critic of the accounting profession, to lead a new accounting oversight board "represents the culmination of a pattern of behavior by Mr. Pitt that is steadily eroding the credibility of the S.E.C."
At a news conference on Capitol Hill, the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, said that Mr. Pitt had "given the accounting industry a veto over who will head the new board."
But the letter from the Democrats seemed only to solidify -- at least for now -- White House support for Mr. Pitt.
"That's an old, tired cry," the White House spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said, citing what he said was the agency's record number of enforcement actions and its confiscation of corrupt executives' illicitly earned money. "I think it's a political charge that has no merit and substance."
The criticism of Mr. Pitt comes as Democrats try to open a debate on the competence of the administration's economic team. The Democrats have been frustrated as the White House has drowned out their theme of economic mismanagement by focusing on growing concerns over Iraq.
The new corporate fraud law requires the five S.E.C. commissioners to appoint the five new members of the accounting board by Oct. 28, in the week before Election Day, and Democrats have seized on Mr. Pitt's handling of the selection as an illustration of the broader economic policies of the administration.
"At best, Chairman Pitt's repeated insensitivity suggests an arrogant indifference to the appearance of conflicts of interest that can only weaken the confidence the S.E.C. should be working to build," Senator Daschle and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader from Missouri, wrote in their letter to the president. "At worst, Chairman Pitt has allowed associations with past clients and the industries he is regulating to influence his judgment and actions in ways that are improper or unethical. In either case, Mr. Pitt is not the right person to head the agency that oversees our financial markets."
Mr. Pitt's handling of corporate scandals and market turmoil has been fodder for criticism for much of the year. His critics include Senators John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, who along with Mr. Daschle earlier this year urged Mr. Bush to replace him because they said he could not credibly conduct inquiries and write tough rules for his former clients on Wall Street and in the accounting profession.
Mr. Pitt has denied accusations that he has been too slow to respond to the wave of corporate corruption, saying that the agency has brought a record number of cases. But he has testified that significant provisions of the legislation that was signed by President Bush were unnecessary. And he was attacked for holding private meetings with executives of companies that were former clients and are now under investigation.
He also irritated some White House officials when he went to Congress without their knowledge three months ago and proposed unsuccessfully to have his position elevated to the status of cabinet level, outranking such officials as the director of central intelligence, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, and all the civilian heads of the various branches of the armed services.
Mr. Pitt, who left belatedly yesterday for a brief trip to Brussels to meet with European regulators and talk before a group of accountants, could not be reached for comment. Christi Harlan, a spokeswoman at the S.E.C., said that the president "has said nothing but good things about Harvey Pitt's tenure."
Commission officials today described the search as being in turmoil, as some officials were reaching out to political notables with little experience in accounting and corporate governance issues.
Some Republicans on the commission were said to have recently approached William H. Webster, the former director of the F.B.I. and the C.I.A., to consider being a candidate to lead the accounting oversight agency. Mr. Webster, who is 78 years old, told the S.E.C. officials that he would think about whether he was interested in taking the job, people involved in the selection process said. Mr. Webster's secretary said he was out of town and could not be reached for comment.
Mr. Biggs continues to be the top choice of the two Democrats at the commission, Roel C. Campos and Harvey J. Goldschmid. Friends said today that Mr. Biggs retired early from his post as chairman and chief executive of TIAA-CREF, the large pension system, after Mr. Pitt and other officials suggested last month that he take the step to be available to accept the post as head of the new accounting board.
Mr. Biggs also received a strong public endorsement today from Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee. He is the main author of the legislation creating the new oversight board and one of the few top Democrats to refrain from attacking Mr. Pitt.
"I have emphasized to S.E.C. Chairman Harvey Pitt the necessity of having a strong independent board, which is at the very heart of the reform effort," Mr. Sarbanes said. "Regrettably, the process of selecting the board seems to be in disarray."
Mr. Sarbanes joins a growing list of lawmakers and other prominent figures endorsing Mr. Biggs. Others include Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman who turned down appointment to the board; Charles A. Bowsher, a former comptroller general and head of an earlier accounting oversight board, and Arthur Levitt, Mr. Pitt's predecessor at the commission.

HEADLINE: House Acts to Speed Medical Devices' Approval 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 

 BODY:
The House passed a bill today to speed the approval and marketing of a new generation of medical technology that promises better diagnosis and treatment of many illnesses.
In return, the industry -- manufacturers of medical devices -- would, for the first time, pay user fees so the government could hire more people to review the inventions.
Consumer groups worry about conflicts of interest, but the bill has broad support in both houses of Congress. It was approved in the House by a vote of 406 to 3, and supporters said they were confident that the Senate would soon approve it, perhaps with modest changes. 
Representative Richard M. Burr, Republican of North Carolina, said it was essential to speed the approval of medical devices, like cardiac pacemakers and implantable drug-infusion pumps, because many products had life cycles measured in months, not years.
"In this industry," Mr. Burr said, "the rule is: innovate or die."
Lobbyists for the industry said that the Food and Drug Administration now took an average of 411 days to review and approve a new medical device, and that the legislation would reduce that time by 100 days.
Manufacturers would pay user fees initially set at $139,000 for federal review of each new medical device. Small businesses, with sales of less than $10 million a year, would pay $53,000 for each application.
Under the bill, many companies could hire outside experts to inspect their plants for federal compliance. Private inspectors would be accredited by the government and would report to the F.D.A., which could continue to visit some companies.
Senators Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire, said they hoped the Senate would pass a similar bill this year. James P. Manley, a Kennedy spokesman, said the senator "has concerns about some provisions of the House bill," including the one authorizing use of private inspectors.
Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, also expressed concern about that provision, but voted for the bill, insisting that the private inspectors "must supplement and not supplant" the work of federal employees.
Under the bill, the F.D.A. would retain its current authority to conduct inspections, and it is expected to continue spending on inspections at current levels, adjusted for inflation.
Representative Sherrod Brown, Democrat of Ohio, said the user fees and the private inspection system created potential conflicts of interest. But he supported the bill. Stephen J. Ubl, executive vice president of the Advanced Medical Technology Association, which represents 1,000 companies, hailed passage of the bill. Congress has sharply increased federal spending on biomedical research at the National Institutes of Health, Mr. Ubl said, but a bottleneck has developed at the F.D.A. because the agency is not equipped to handle the fruits of that research.
Mr. Burr said people at the agency had been "overwhelmed by the volume of new products that they must review." At the same time, the products are becoming more complex.
The new generation of medical devices includes blood sugar monitors worn like a wrist watch, electronic brain stimulators to reduce the symptoms of Parkinson's disease, and wound dressings made of living human skin cells. Researchers have also developed a bionic retina, artificial finger joints and a device that works like an artificial pancreas. Drug-coated wire-mesh stents can be implanted in the chest to keep blood vessels open. Patients can swallow capsules containing tiny video cameras that take pictures as they pass through the digestive tract.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
An Increase in Advertising Drives a Rebound at Yahoo
Yahoo posted better-than-expected third-quarter sales and earnings as it gained market share in advertising and job listings from its rivals. Over all, Yahoo posted sales of $248.8 million, $10 million more than analysts expected. The company had earnings of $28.9 million, or 5 cents a share, a penny above forecasts.
 Yahoo's rebound was driven in part by a diversification into fee-based services and a resurgence in advertising sales. The overall Internet advertising market is not growing, and America Online is still suffering declines in its online sales. Yahoo, by contrast said its ad sales increased 22 percent. Page C3. 

Port Union Members Criticize Bush
In the view of many union members, President Bush's decision to intervene in the dockworkers labor dispute was a tactic of the port operators to break the union. A22.

The shutdown of the West Coast ports does not appear to have lasted long enough to inflict serious damage on big exporters like China, Japan and Taiwan. C15.

Bristol-Myers Faces Another Inquiry
Bristol-Myers Squibb, already the subject of an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, faces an additional inquiry on the issue by the United States attorney for New Jersey. C4.

Executives, directors and employees of ImClone Systems sold nearly $74 million in stock in the weeks before the company suffered a regulatory setback that sent shares into a tailspin, according to a House committee. C4.

Changes at Salomon's Research Unit
Citigroup said it was removing two top executives in the stock research division of Salomon Smith Barney, its investment banking division. The changes come as the conduct of Salomon's analysts is under investigation. C4.

A Bicycle for Pedaling to Work
Seeking to ignite growth with products appealing to more than the athletic and outdoorsy, bicycle makers are exploring the commuter bicycle, an inexpensive and comfortable vehicle for getting to work and back. C4.

United Begins Talks With Unions
United Airlines will start negotiating separately for concessions with each of its five unions, even though the unions had formed a coalition to present a single concession proposal. The unions offered $1 billion in concessions; the airline had sought $1.5 billion. C2.

Fears of Hard Landing Rattle Tokyo
As Japan's markets veered down, investors bailed out, tightened their belts or begged the government to avoid a hard landing. But Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi rebuffed pleas by refusing to try to make a soft landing. And Heizo Takenaka, left, the new economics minister, would merely confirm what investors already knew: the markets are in severe shape. World Business, Section W.

Looking to the 50's for a Sales Idea
To try to revive its image among younger car buyers, Buick is taking the unusual step of resurrecting an old hero. Buick is rolling out an ad campaign built around Harley Earl, the style wizard who oversaw the creation of G.M.'s grandest designs in the 1950's. The problem is, Mr. Earl died in 1969. Advertising. C10.

Film Studio in a Deal With Maxim
New Line Cinema has reached a deal with Maxim magazine that gives the studio the option of turning content from Maxim into a film project. The deal marries a racy young men's magazine and the studio that produced the Austin Powers movies. C8.

Looking Behind Economy's Curtain
One expanding field of research looks behind the assumptions on which the modern economy is based, studying how people arrange their affairs, how they create institutions to govern their relationships and how those institutions contribute to or hinder growth. Economic Scene: Virginia Postrel. C2.

HEADLINE: City Budget Gap Grows, and Visions of the 70's Grow Vivid 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
New York City's fiscal watchdogs and budget mavens have been known to cry wolf. Year after year, they sound alarms about yawning deficits, heavy debt, draconian cuts just down the road, giant tax increases just around the corner. They invoke the early 1990's, the 1970's. But somehow the city always seems to muddle through.
 But now there is a growing consensus among government officials and fiscal monitors that, this year, the budget wolf may really be at the door. 
 As New York City prepares to try to close its second $5 billion budget gap in two years, the city's fiscal crisis, which many New Yorkers have heard about but not yet felt, is all but certain to take on a more concrete, tangible reality in the coming months. 
The city is struggling to cut up to a billion dollars in spending by next month, including large cutbacks to a Police Department that is laboring to keep crime down while fighting terrorism, a Fire Department that is rebuilding from the losses of Sept. 11 and a new Department of Education that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has staked his mayoralty on improving.
The mayor, who has long been averse to tax increases, is now openly mulling them. And many fiscal experts expect the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which is controlled by the state, to raise bus and subway fares.
The balancing act, officials say, is to find ways to slash expenses and raise money without endangering the city's recovery from the attack on the World Trade Center, or resorting to the level of layoffs, service cuts and deferred maintenance triggered by the 1970's fiscal crisis -- service cuts that still haunt the urban imagination. 
But with the streets already getting slightly dirtier by the city's own reckoning, the police force shrinking a bit, some businesses reeling from the recession and others looking to decentralize after Sept. 11, the balancing act is proving difficult, officials said. And the sputtering economy that is driving down city revenues is also driving up some expenses, from a rise in homeless families to rising Medicaid costs.
"How you allocate pain is a difficult exercise, and there are no painless alternatives," Felix G. Rohatyn, the financier who helped lead the city through the 1970's, said of the current crisis. "I have a reputation for being a pessimist. You don't have to be a pessimist to be heavily concerned with what one sees."
Elected officials, paving the way for some of the bitter medicine to come, are sounding the alarm. Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, said yesterday that "the city is going into perhaps the most severe fiscal crisis in its history," adding that it was worse than the crisis of the 1970's. Asked later about that remark, Mayor Bloomberg said that it was "probably as good a description as anything." 
Mr. Rohatyn and other fiscal experts said that, in some ways, the 1970's were worse. The city's finances were far more tangled then, and its crushing debt ultimately cost the city its ability to borrow more money.
The magnitude of the gap was worse as well, in a way: Diana Fortuna, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, said that the city's shortfall in 1975 was about 19 percent of its spending, while next year's shortfall is running at 15 percent.
In other ways, though, the current crisis is more troubling than that of the 1970's, experts said. Most important, the city was given several years to spread the pain and straighten out its finances back then, while it is now obligated by law to balance its budget each year or risk a takeover of its finances by a state control board. And the experts noted that the state was in much better fiscal health then, and therefore better able to help the city, and that Washington came through with significant aid. 
The current problem is simple to state but difficult to solve: officials expect that tax revenues and state and federal aid will fall roughly $5 billion short of meeting the city's expenses next year. The causes of that shortfall range from the recession, which has eaten away the Wall Street profits that the city depends on, to the Sept. 11 attack, to spending that rose faster than the rate of inflation in the Giuliani administration.
And when it comes to the economy, the city is catching few breaks. 
Wall Street profits, which lead to big bonuses, and therefore taxes for the city, are not doing as well as the city had been expecting, said Ronnie Lowenstein, the director of the city's Independent Budget Office. She said that while the city was counting on Wall Street profits of $12.8 billion in 2002, the actual number would likely be lower since it was only $5 billion in the first half and preliminary data showed that it was depressed in the last few months.
Mayor Bloomberg said yesterday that some tax revenues were coming in below the city's already conservative estimates. "If tax revenues don't pick up a little bit, we'll have to do something near the end of fiscal '03," the mayor said. The city's fiscal year ends June 30.
And if this year's $5 billion gap was closed relatively painlessly, city officials worry that they may have run out of most painless options.
Some agencies are balking at Mayor Bloomberg's request to offer suggestions for cutting their budgets by 7.5 percent -- the amount each agency will need to cut next month for the city is to reach its goal of trimming spending a billion dollars.
The Police Department came back with suggestions to cut less than 40 percent of the roughly $235 million in cuts that it had been asked for, and the Fire Department came back with less than half of its roughly $75 million in requested cuts. Now department officials and administration officials are wrangling over further cuts.
When it comes to the Police Department, there are really only three main areas where significant savings can be made: the number of officers, the number of civilian employees and the amount of overtime budgeted. Cutting any has its drawbacks. 
Cutting police officers is difficult during an economic downturn when it could be harder to keep crime down and when the number assigned to antiterrorism duties has risen to more than 1,000 from fewer than 20. Cutting civilian positions is a little easier politically, but the net effect is often to take police officers from their enforcement duties to give them civilian work.
And the Police Department has come to rely on overtime to get large numbers of officers to patrol big events, or to assign officers to some of the recent big antidrug programs.
Mayor Bloomberg has said that he will not sacrifice public safety, and he has expressed a willingness to spare some agencies from a full 7.5 percent cut. But he has noted again and again that only about $15 billion of the city's $42 billion budget is really discretionary and that the biggest pieces are education and police. 
The city, he said, cannot afford not to cut from the agencies that spend the most. "I think you have to take a look at where the moneys are," he said this week. "There are very small departments where there's not an appreciable amount of money to save even if you close them down, and we have no intention of doing that. But every single department will share."

HEADLINE: Venezuela Braces for a New Round of Antigovernment Protests 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela Thursday, Oct. 10 

 BODY:
With its armed forces deployed in the capital, the government of President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela braced for an antigovernment march today that might be the largest since the April 11 demonstration that briefly toppled him. 
 Throughout the week, tanks and troops have been positioned to protect the presidential palace as government loyalists accused protest organizers of plotting to remove the president from power. 
 "They must not think that behind the march they are going to be able to stage a coup," Mr. Chavez said Wednesday in a speech in the capital, Caracas. "The people and the armed forces are on the alert." 
Government forces in recent days have raided the homes of a former foreign minister and military officers who were accused of taking part in a conspiracy against Mr. Chavez, though they have not been charged. The government also said it had proof that leaders of the Democratic Coordinator, an umbrella organization for anti-Chavez organizations, were orchestrating a coup.
The coordinator "has fallen into the hands of rightist extremists who, utilizing the media, propose the return to the old politics and play to the fascist sectors of the country," said Guillermo Garcia Ponce, a member of Mr. Chavez's left-leaning Bolivarian Revolutionary Movement.
Opponents of Mr. Chavez said the government had failed to provide evidence. They also said the raids and the militarization of the city were unnecessary and authoritarian.
"In a dictatorial regime, these procedures form part of the terror machine," said Tal Cual, an influential Caracas newspaper, in the lead editorial on Wednesday. "In a democratic regime, they are absolutely illegitimate."
The government has been on edge since April, when Mr. Chavez was removed from office after an antigovernment march by hundreds of thousands of people ended in violence. A popular uprising returned Mr. Chavez to power two days later, but tensions have grown as efforts to start a dialogue between Mr. Chavez and his opponents have failed.
Opponents describe Mr. Chavez's government as radical and incompetent, and they claim that the president's supporters killed at least 19 unarmed protesters on April 11. Many diplomats and rights groups say that the deaths were caused by both sides in a series of gun battles, and that the opposition has been recalcitrant and impractical.
The turmoil has hobbled the economy, which contracted by 7.1 percent in the first half of the year.
The situation has worried the United States, which is dependent on Venezuelan oil. The Bush administration, which seemed to welcome Mr. Chavez's removal in April, went so far last month as to announce it would oppose any effort to meddle by "illegal and/or violent actions" with the "constitutional and democratically elected government of Venezuela."
"The United States has distanced itself from an opposition that's weak and inept," said Michael Shifter, who tracks Venezuela for the Inter-American Dialogue, a policy analysis group in Washington. "It's not an embrace of Chavez, but they want to have a hands-off, neutral position."
Opposition leaders, though, say that the only solution is for Mr. Chavez to resign or call early elections. The president, whose term ends in 2006, has refused to do so, though he has said he would welcome a referendum on his rule.
