HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES; 
Excerpts From Senate Debate on Iraq Policy

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the Senate debate yesterday on using military force against Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times. The speakers included Senators John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts; Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine; Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont; and Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska. 

Senator Kerry
 The reason for going to war, if we must fight, Madame President, is not because Saddam Hussein has failed to deliver gulf war prisoners or Kuwaiti property. As much as we decry the way he's treated his people, regime change alone is not a sufficient reason for going to war, as desirable as it is to change the regime. Regime change has been an American policy under the Clinton administration, and it is the current policy. I support the policy. 
 But regime change, in and of itself, is not sufficient justification for going to war, particularly unilaterally, unless regime change is the only way to disarm Iraq of the weapons of mass destruction pursuant to the United Nations resolution. As bad as he is, Saddam Hussein the dictator is not the cause of war. Saddam Hussein sitting in Baghdad with an arsenal of weapons of mass destruction is a different matter. 
In the wake of Sept. 11, who among us can say with any certainty to anybody that the weapons might not be used against our troops or against allies in the region? Who can say that this master of miscalculation will not develop a weapon of mass destruction even greater, a nuclear weapon, than reinvade Kuwait, push the Kurds out, attack Israel, any number of scenarios to try to further the ambitions to be the pan-Arab leader or simply to confront in the region and once again miscalculate the response, to believe he is stronger because he has those weapons? 
And while the administration has failed to provide any direct link between Iraq and the events of Sept. 11, can we afford to ignore the possibility that Saddam Hussein might accidentally, as well as purposely, allow those weapons to slide off to one group or other in a region where weapons are the currency of trade? 
How do we leave that to chance, Madame President? That is why the enforcement mechanism through the United Nations and the reality of the potential of the use of force is so critical to achieve the protection of the long-term interests, not just of the United States, but of the world, to understand that the dynamic has changed, that we're living in a different status today, that we cannot sit by and be as complacent or even negligent about weapons of mass destruction and proliferation as we have been in the past.
The Iraqi regime's record over the decade leaves little doubt that Saddam Hussein wants to retain his arsenal of weapons of mass destruction, and obviously, as we've said, grow it. These weapons represent an unacceptable threat. 
I want to underscore this administration began this debate with a resolution that granted exceedingly broad authority to the president to use force, and I regret that some in the Congress rush so quickly to support it. I would have opposed it. It gave the authority to use force not only to enforce all of the U.N. resolutions as a cause of war, but also to produce regime change in Iraq and to restore international peace and security in the Persian Gulf region. 
It made no mention of the president's efforts at the United Nations or the need to build multilateral support for whatever course of action we ultimately would take. 
I am pleased that our pressure and the questions we have asked and the criticisms that have been raised publicly, that the debate in our democracy has pushed this administration to adopt important changes, both in language, as well as in the promises that they make. The revised White House text which we will vote on limits the grant of authority to the president to the use of force only with respect to Iraq. It does not empower him to use force throughout the Persian Gulf region. 
It authorizes the president to use armed forces to defend the national security of the United States, a power most of us believe he already has under the Constitution as commander in chief. And it empowers him to enforce all relevant Security Council relations related to Iraq. Now none of those resolutions, or for that matter any of the other Security Council resolutions, demand Iraqi compliance with its international obligations and call for a regime change. 
In recent days, the administration has gone further. They are defining what relevant U.N. Council resolutions mean. When Secretary Powell testified before our committee, the Foreign Relations Committee, on Sept. 26, he was asked what specific U.N. Security Council resolutions the United States would go to war to enforce. His response was clear. The resolutions dealing with weapons of mass destruction and the disarmament of Iraq. 
In fact, when asked about compliance with other U.N. resolutions which do not deal with weapons of mass destruction, the secretary said, "The president has not linked authority to go to war to any of those elements."
When asked why the resolution sent by the president to the Congress requesting authority to enforce all the resolutions with which they had not complied, the secretary told the committee: "That's the way the resolution is currently worded. But we all know that the major problem, the offense, what the president is focused on and the danger to us and the world, are the weapons of mass destruction." 
In his speech on Monday night, President Bush confirmed what Secretary Powell told the committee. In the clearest presentation to date, the president laid out a strong, comprehensive and compelling argument why Iraq's weapons-of-mass-destruction program is a threat to the United States and the international community.

Senator Snowe
What urgency has interjected itself that would necessitate the actions we contemplate today? Mr. President, my answer begins not by citing a single fact or occurrence, but rather by illustrating a new encroaching threat over the past decade that was foreshadowed by the first attack on American soil since Pearl Harbor, the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center. 
I believe that that was a seminal moment, when our enemies of today were introduced to the realm of the possible as those who would wish our destruction developed and implemented comprehensive strategies to systematically assault Americans and our interests whenever, wherever and however they could. It also should have been an awakening for America. And that's why I spearheaded investigations into the comings and goings of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the mastermind of that bombing in 1993 who entered and exited this country five times totally unimpeded. 
What I found led me to introduce legislation in 1994 requiring information-sharing among critical government agencies to ensure those on the front lines of securing America would have the resources to keep dangerous aliens from entering the United States. But there were those who didn't take the threat seriously. And those reforms were quietly altered and allowed to fade out of law in 1998 and out of the national consciousness. 
Now, as we peel back the layers through further investigation, we discover the sheik was closely tied to Osama bin Laden and the network we now know as Al Qaeda. The point is over the decade of the 90's and into the fledgling days of 21st century, our consciousness was not attuned to the emerging pattern of attacks. And so the pattern continued. From the Khobar Towers in 1996 to the 1998 embassy bombings in Kenya and Tanzania to the attack on the U.S.S. Cole in the fall of 2000 and culminating in the horrific attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. 
That terrible day would finally and forever change the way we assess our security and vulnerability, single-handedly adding the term "homeland security" to our national lexicon. It has changed our conception of what constitutes weapons and warfare and how both may be used against us. To paraphrase Governor Ridge, we are now compelled to come to grips with an enemy who makes no distinction between combatants and noncombatants. The battlefield itself has changed. Today asymmetrical threats accost us in the theater of engagement that includes our own backyard. There is no line of demarcation. 
Before Sept. 11, we underestimated the threat and overestimated our security. That is why the Senate and House have been holding joint intelligence hearings to determine how we can learn from the failures of the past. The lapses were so egregious that it prompted our recent vote to authorize an independent commission to conduct a more far-reaching inquiry into how we could have done better and how we must do better in the future, because there is no longer any question as to the scope of the threat and the ability and the intent of terrorist groups to bring devastation to our soil.
As Secretary Rumsfeld said, and I quote: "We have entered a world in which terrorists' movements and terrorist states are developing the capacity to cause unprecedented destruction. Today, our margin of error is notably different. In the 20th century, we were dealing for the most part with conventional weapons, weapons that could kill hundreds or thousands of people, generally combatants. In the 21st century, we are dealing with weapons of mass destruction that can kill potentially tens of thousands of people, innocent men, women and children." 
It is through this prism of the post-Sept. 11 world, Mr. President, that we must view an ever-emerging convergence of threats over the last 10 years represented on the one hand by transnational terrorism exemplified by Al Qaeda, with cells in more than 30 countries, and on the other by a regime in Iraq that has already developed and deployed horrific weapons of mass destruction. 
Even as far back as 1991, the United Nations was concerned enough about a potential linkage between terrorists and Saddam Hussein to include in Resolution 687 a requirement that Iraq inform the Security Council, and I quote, "that it will not commit or support any act of international terrorism or allow any organization directed toward commission of such acts to operate within its territory." 
Today we know from Secretary Rumsfeld that Al Qaeda is operating in Iraq, that we have accurate and not debatable evidence of reportedly presence of senior members of Al Qaeda in Baghdad and other associations. Iraq has also provided safe haven to Abdul Rahman Yasin, one of the F.B.I.'s most-wanted terrorists, who was a key participant in the first World Trade Center bombing. 
We also know that Saddam Hussein continues to provide $25,000 rewards to the families of suicide bombers in the Middle East, continues to harbor the Abu Nidal organization and continues to harbor the Palestinian Liberation Front. 
And so the question we really need to ask ourselves is this, why is Hussein so single-mindedly and at all costs amassing such huge stores of horrific weapons? We know he has them. We know he has used them before. The question is will he use them again? 
The answer is that we don't know for certain. But from all I have been able to ascertain from high-level briefings, the logical conclusion based on all of the evidence, all of the broken promises, all the obfuscation and now this nexus between Hussein and other terrorist groups and individuals is that we simply can't afford the risk to humanity.

Senator Leahy
There's no dispute that Saddam Hussein is a menace to his people and to Iraq's neighbors. He's a tyrant. The world would be far better off without him. He's made no secret of his hatred of the United States. And should he acquire nuclear weapons and the means to deliver it, he'd pose a grave threat to the lives of all Americans, as well as many of our closest allies. 
The question isn't whether he should be disarmed. It's how imminent is his threat and how do we deal with it. Do we go it alone, as some in the administration are eager to do, because they see Iraq as the first opportunity to apply the president's strategy of pre-emptive military force? Do we do that, potentially jeopardizing the support of those nations we need to combat terrorism? Do we further antagonize Muslim populations who already deeply resent our policies in the Middle East? Or do we work with other nations to disarm Saddam, using force if other options fail? 
The resolution now before the Senate leaves the door open to act alone, even absent an imminent threat. It surrenders to the president authority which the Constitution explicitly, explicitly, reserves for the Congress. As I said two weeks ago, it's premature. I've never believed, nor do I think that any senator believes, that U.S. foreign policy should be hostage to any nation or even to the United Nations. We have to do what is right and necessary to protect our security whenever it's called for. But going to war alone is rarely the answer.
And Monday night, the president spoke about working with the United Nations. And I agreed with so much of what the president said. The status quo is unacceptable. Past U.N. resolutions have not worked. Saddam Hussein and other Iraqi officials have lied to the world over and over. And the president points out an effort is under way at the U.N. to adopt a strong resolution requiring unconditional unimpeded access. This effort is making steady progress. Successful, it could achieve the goal of disarming Saddam without putting thousands of American and innocent Iraqi lives at risk or spending tens of billions, or actually hundreds of billions, of dollars at a time when the U.S. economy is weakening and the federal deficit is growing. Retirement savings of American senior citizens have been decimated. 
Now, diplomacy is often tedious. It doesn't usually make the headlines or the evening news. We certainly know about past diplomatic failures. But history has shown over and over that diplomatic pressure cannot only protect our national interests, it can also enhance the effectiveness of military force when force becomes necessary. 
Now the negotiations are at a sensitive stage. We authorize use of force today, Congress is saying, irrespective of what the Security Council does, we've already decided to go on our own way. Some say the president's hand will be strengthened by his passiveness.
In 1990, when the United States successfully assembled a broad coalition to fight the gulf war, we passed a resolution only after the U.N. had acted. Now the world knows that President Bush is serious about using force against Iraq. And the votes are here in Congress to declare war if diplomatic efforts fail and war becomes unavailable. But the resolution now before us goes well beyond what the president said on Monday about working through the United Nations. It would permit the administration to take precipitous unilateral action without following through with the U.N. 
Many respected and knowledgeable people, former senior military officers and diplomats have expressed strong reservation about this resolution. They agree that if there were credible evidence that Saddam Hussein was planning to use weapons of mass destruction against the United States or one of our allies, the American people and the Congress would overwhelmingly support the use of American military power to stop it. But they haven't seen that evidence. Madame President, neither have I. We've heard a lot of bellicose rhetoric, but where are the facts?
I'm not asking for 100 percent proof. But the administration is asking Congress to make a decision to go to war based on conflicting statements, angry assertions and assumptions based on speculation. This is not the way a great nation goes to war.

Senator Hagel
We should not mistake our foreign policy priorities for ideology in a rush to proclaim a new doctrine in world affairs. America must understand that it cannot alone win a war against terrorism. It will require allies, friends and partners. 
American leadership in the world will be further defined by our actions in Iraq and the Middle East. What begins in Iraq will not end in Iraq. There will be other Iraqs. There will be continued acts of terrorism, proliferating powers and regional conflicts. If we do it right and lead through the United Nations in concert with our allies, we can set a new standard for American leadership and international cooperation. 
The perception of American power is power. And how our power is perceived can either magnify or diminish our influence in the world. The Senate has a constitutional responsibility and an institutional obligation in this effort. 
Federalist Paper No. 63 specifically notes the responsibilities of the United States Senate in foreign affairs as follows, and I quote: "An attention to the judgment of other nations is important to every government for two reasons. The one is that independently of the merits of any particular plan or measure, it is desirable on many and various accounts, that it should appear to other nations as the offspring of a wise and honorable policy. The second is that in doubtful cases, particularly where the national councils may be warped by some strong passion or momentary interest, the presumed or known opinion of the impartial world may be the best guide that can always be followed. What has not America lost by her want of character with foreign nations? And how many errors and follies would she not have avoided if the justice and propriety of her measures had in every instance been previously tried by the light in which they would probably appear to the unbiased part of mankind?" 
Remarkable words.
The resolution before us today should be tried in that same light as The Federalist Papers points out. The original resolution proposed by the Bush administration, S. J. Resolution 45, would have been a setback for this institution. It did not reflect the best democratic traditions of either Congressional executive relations or the conduct of American foreign policy. S. J. Resolution 46, sponsored by Senators Lieberman, Warner, McCain and Bayh, is a far more responsible and accountable document than the one we started with three weeks ago. . . .
S. J. Resolution 46 narrows the authorization for the use of force to all relevant U.N. resolutions regarding Iraq and to defending our national interests against the threats posed by Iraq. It includes support for U.S. diplomatic efforts at the United Nations; a requirement that before taking action, the president formally determines that diplomatic or other peaceful means will not be adequate in meeting our objectives; reference to the war powers resolution requirements in periodic reports to Congress that includes those actions described in the section of the Iraq Liberation Act of 1998, regarding assistance and support for Iraq upon replacement of Saddam Hussein. 
This resolution recognizes Congress as a co-equal partner in dealing with the threat from Saddam Hussein's Iraq. If disarmament in Iraq requires the use of force, we need to consider carefully the implications and consequences of our actions. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Software: Microsoft Executive Faults Licensing Plan 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Microsoft's chief executive, Steve Ballmer, said yesterday that his company made mistakes when it moved to a new licensing plan this year that angered customers, some of whom had to pay more. "With 20-20 hindsight, I probably wouldn't have made any of these changes when the economy was going to go south," Mr. 
Ballmer said in an interview at a conference sponsored by the market researcher Gartner Inc. in Orlando, Fla. Microsoft switched to the new plan Aug. 1 to try to make its software licensing programs easier to understand and cheaper for some customers. The plan requires clients to buy maintenance contracts, which cost at least 25 percent more than the software alone, or to pay more for upgrades to new programs. Analysts have estimated that most customers will end up paying more, and some clients have said they are looking at competing programs.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 39

LENGTH: 4668 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "RICHARD AVEDON: PORTRAITS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 5). Just eight years after the last Richard Avedon show, here's a survey of portraits. The fashion analogy is obvious: the repackaged product, a clever campaign to market the same old goods. But the show is gorgeous: a pitch-perfect mix of modest-size, big and unbelievably big prints, each an exquisitely made object. Whatever else the works might be, they are unforgettable. Celebrity only partly accounts for their status. Mr. Avedon brings other factors to bear: a sense of spectacle, clinical precision, energy, movement even in static head shots (the figures often seem so tense they look ready to jump out of the pictures) and an irrepressible attraction to power. His career dovetails with the era of the paparazzi, the tell-all media, the obligatory scandals and secret sufferings of the rich and fashionable. You might say he raised this cultural fixation to a neurotic art. The trade-off with him is always between style and substance. It's the conflict of our culture. No wonder his pictures are so embedded in our imagination. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $7 for students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* JUDY CHICAGO: "THE DINNER PARTY," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Feb. 9). This exhibition welcomes back Ms. Chicago's extravagant installation banquet of ceramic plates and handmade table runners dedicated to 39 women. A feminist landmark, it is joining the permanent collection 22 years after its first appearance at the museum. It is amazing to see. Made with the help of hundreds of volunteers from 1975 to 1979, "The Dinner Party" sums up the first stage of feminist art, reflects the late 70's rematerialization of the art object and is startlingly prescient of the art of the late 80's and 90's in its ambition to be both aggressively visual and politically charged. Despite being almost as much a part of American culture as Norman Rockwell, Walt Disney, W.P.A. murals and the AIDS quilt, it retains much of its original revolutionary fervor. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; $3 for students and 62+ (Roberta Smith).

* "CULTIVATED LANDSCAPES: REFLECTIONS OF NATURE IN CHINESE PAINTING WITH SELECTIONS FROM THE COLLECTION OF MARIE-HELENE AND GUY WEILL," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Feb. 9). This show is basically a rotation of the permanent collection, of the kind required to protect light-sensitive silk scrolls and ink-painted album pages. But the Met has a flair for turning necessity into a virtue by reintroducing work along thematic lines and introducing fresh material to lend a sense of event. Such is the case here. At the center of the reinstallation is a group of splendid Ming and Qing dynasty paintings recently given or promised to the museum by the New York collectors Marie-Helene and Guy Weill. They are a genuine attraction in themselves and a logical link in the continuum that this museum's remarkable Chinese holdings span from beginning to end. Hours and admission: See above (Holland Cotter).

* "FACING THE MASK" and "RECENT ACQUISITIONS: SELECTIONS FROM THE PERMANENT COLLECTION," Museum for African Art, third floor, 36-01 43rd Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-7700 (through March 2). The Museum for African Art, formerly of SoHo, makes the leap to a new home in Long Island City, with a very beautiful if surveyish show, "Facing the Mask," which happens to be all about moving. Some of the moving is physical, some psychological and spiritual, and it is embodied in more than 70 stunning masks, no two alike, from across sub-Saharan Africa. Some were used for popular entertainment; others were moral forces incarnate. Their purpose was transport, and they are supplemented by films of masquerades in action. Also on view is a selection of work from the museum's still small but growing permanent collection. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "GAUGUIN IN NEW YORK COLLECTIONS: THE LURE OF THE EXOTIC," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Oct. 20). The first major New York exhibition in four decades devoted to Gauguin isn't major-major by Met blockbuster standards: more than half of the 120 pieces are drawings and prints. But these are pretty spectacular, and they are joined by some two dozen paintings, including coral-and-mango-colored visions of a mythical South Pacific that are among the most beautiful images created by any modern artist. Only the Met has the resources to put this kind of material together, though if you want to get a real sense of the not-so-nice artist himself, check out the new critical biography by Nancy Mowll Mathews, "Paul Gauguin: An Erotic Life" (Yale University Press). Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

* "NOMADIC ART OF THE EASTERN EURASIAN STEPPES: THE EUGENE V. THAW AND OTHER NEW YORK COLLECTIONS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 5). The 200 or so miniature bronze, gold and silver sculptures in this show, most of them in the form of real or fantastic animals, are associated with nomadic peoples who traveled the vast plains from northern China to the Black Sea in the first millennium B.C. Although they transformed every culture they touched, including Classical Greece, Achaemenid Iran and China, little is known about them. Rather than trying to break fresh scholarly ground, the show put the emphasis on aesthetic appeal, and that appeal is powerful. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

* "POUSSIN, CLAUDE AND THEIR WORLD: 17TH-CENTURY FRENCH DRAWINGS FROM THE ECOLE DES BEAUX-ARTS, PARIS," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Dec. 1). The Ecole des Beaux-Arts, the world's oldest surviving art school (founded in 1648), assembled an enormous collection of works to instruct its students in the discipline of drawing. Those from the 17th century, the great age of Nicolas Poussin and Claude Lorrain, are especially outstanding. The 71 here survey French drawing from 1620 to 1680, when Classicism came to French art, aiming to restore High Renaissance ideals of clarity, order and balance with the Italian painter Raphael as a revered model. The emphasis is on the works of Poussin (1594-1665) and Claude (1604-1682), a history painter and a landscapist. But lesser-known masters like Simon Vouet, Eustache Le Sueur and Charles Le Brun are also included. Wicked doings in the Bible, sex in mythology, the ordered schematics of French architecture and the pomp and circumstance of the French court are some of the subjects covered in the drawings, which should send any aficionado to the Frick on the run. Hours and admissions: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; students and 62+, $5 (Grace Glueck).

* "THE THAW COLLECTION: MASTER DRAWINGS AND OIL SKETCHES, ACQUISITIONS SINCE 1994," Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0008 (through Jan. 19). This selection of more than 100 European drawings and oil sketches is the latest update on a personal collection that Eugene V. Thaw and his wife, Clare, have been depositing at the Morgan in increments since 1975. The last such show in 1994 left everyone a bit light-headed it was so good. This one has a lot going for it, too, including work by Rembrandt, von Ruisdael, Degas and the incomparable Samuel Palmer. A cluster of 19th-century German and Scandinavian works give the proceedings a piney, Romantic air. Nearly half the show is plein-air oil sketches, which the Thaws have recently been acquiring in depth. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, to 8 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6 for students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "BILL VIOLA: GOING FORTH BY DAY," Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 12). An ambitious meditation on the epic themes of human existence, this frescolike video installation consists of five panels, shot using the latest technology and projected simultaneously on the walls of one huge gallery. Each deals with a specific theme: rebirth, journey through life, disaster, death and resurrection. Inspired by the works of Renaissance painters like Giotto and Luca Signorelli, it relates as much to still painting as it does to the moving images of cinema and television. Except for a few scenes, the action is almost in slow motion, suggesting the stasis of looking at paintings and allowing the viewer to shift attention from panel to panel without losing focus. The liveliest scene is "The Deluge," in which a series of ordinary street events occurs before the facade of a Classical-looking house. They are interrupted by a tumultuous flood pouring out of the building's apertures that sends people running for their lives. The work was mostly shot before the Sept. 11 disaster, but is amazingly prophetic of it. If some of the imagery is corny, it is still a deeply felt and provocative piece of work. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $9, students and 65+ (Glueck).

* "WINOGRAND 1964," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 860-1777 (through Dec. 1). In 1964 the photographer Garry Winogrand crisscrossed America, taking nearly 20,000 photographs along the way. Here are around 150 of them, most of them never shown before. Winogrand was a hit-and-miss artist, and the show could have been edited. But the images add up to a fresh, divinely eccentric portrait of America after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. The resonance with 9/11, though obvious, goes unstated. A poor skeptic, Winogrand clearly saw the fragility and the preciousness of what binds people together. Many of the pictures seem fragile, too: they're fleeting stories sometimes so provisional as to be barely coherent, irreducible, like life, to a simple message. Winogrand captured how America once again transformed catastrophe into commerce, an inevitable but also strangely redemptive process. Hours and admission: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $9; $6, students and 62+ (Kimmelman).

Galleries: Uptown

GEORGE BASELITZ, "Paintings and Drawings From the 1960's," Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, (212) 517-8677 (through Nov. 2). Before this German Neo-Expressionist started turning his canvases upside down, he made earthy, saturnine paintings and drawings right side up. His gnarly, muddy pictures from the 60's of people and animals have an evocative, primordial quality and sometimes, as in a small ink portrait of a bare-chested Antonin Artaud, a strange delicacy (Ken Johnson).

MARKUS LUPERTZ, "Semiramis," Knoedler, 19 East 70th Street, (212) 794-0550 (through Nov. 16). Titled after the Babylonian Queen Semiramis, creator of the legendary Hanging Gardens, Mr. Lupertz's paintings, in which rectangles of florid, clotted Abstract Expressionist painting are set off within internal borders, might be a meditation on beauty and decadence. Superficially, these medium-size canvases by the head of the Dusseldorf Academy of Art resemble the paintings of Howard Hodgkin, but they are animated more by oblique irony than by lyrical hedonism (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

TOLAND GRINNELL, "A Mobile Home and Other Necessities," Mary Boone Gallery, 745 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 752-2929 (through Oct. 19). This artist goes to even greater lengths than usual to state the obvious, handmaking a 31-piece suite of luggage that has all the comforts of the most luxurious Upper East Side co-op apartment to remind us that we live in an era of material excess. The works have an empty-headed muscle-bound perfection in which message is overwhelmed by medium. But the impeccable pale yellow caning with forest green leather trim should be optioned by Vuitton or Hermes pronto (Smith).

* "THE HEAVENLY TREE GROWS DOWNWARD: SELECTED WORKS BY HARRY SMITH, PHILIP TAAFFE AND FRED TOMASELLI," James Cohan Gallery, 41 West 57th Street, (212) 755-7171 (through Oct. 19). Smith (1923-1991) is best known for his archival recording project "Anthology of American Folk Music." But he was also a filmmaker and an inventive painter. Some of his paintings and early films are shown here, and they reflect his many interests, from alchemy and psychoactive drugs to jazz and modernist art. He is joined in this show by two fine contemporary painters, Mr. Taaffe and Mr. Tomaselli, who admire his work and, in different ways, share his sensibility. Mr. Taaffe's contribution adds up to a laboratory of new ideas; Mr. Tomaselli shows some of his best collage-paintings to date (Cotter).

Galleries: Chelsea

WILL COTTON, Mary Boone Gallery, 541 West 24th Street, (212) 752-2929 (through Oct. 19). With a dry, thin touch, Mr. Cotton continues to paint giant images of supersweet desserts, like flans in a lake of syrup, that are more repulsive than mouth-watering. His project might be a comment on a culture of instantaneous gratification. Now he has added to the mix nubile young women, naked or in underwear. Dusted with sugar, drenched in chocolate or smeared with frosting, these misty dream girls loll about in hypoglycemic dazes (Johnson).

WINKA DUBBELDAM, "From HardWare to SoftForm," Frederieke Taylor, 535 West 22nd Street, (646) 230-0992 (through Oct. 19). The owner of the firm Archi-tectonics looks into the future and sees -- surprise! -- interactive technology. Here the New York architect offers a transparent screen on which the ghostly bones of a futuristic building morph wildly in response to the viewer's tread on floor switches. In a few years, no doubt, this sort of thing will look quaintly primitive (Johnson).

* FERUS, Gagosian Gallery, 555 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 741-1111 (through Oct. 19). A tribute to the life, times and art of Ferus, the farsighted gallery that was arguably the point of origin of the Los Angeles art scene but that also reflected its artistic moment -- the fertile decade from 1957 to 1967 -- as fully as any New York gallery. Major works by Ed Ruscha, Frank Stella, Ellsworth Kelly, Billy Al Bengston, Robert Irwin, Larry Bell and Jay DeFeo and others make the show a museum-caliber treat (Smith).

* CAROL JACKSON / KAZ, Ten in One Gallery, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 604-9660 (through Oct. 19) Ms. Jackson gets better and better at producing funny, sometimes profound simulations of vernacular signs in embossed and painted leather, with texts like "Flight Is a Weapon Which Bears No Disgrace; Remember to Run." Comic strips by the underground cartoonist Kaz are hilariously filthy and beautifully drawn. His rotund rodent protagonist, Creep Rat, is a drunk, a murderer, a sex pervert and a loser, yet his indomitable optimism is endearing (Johnson).

MICHEL MAJERUS, "Leuchtland," Friedrich Petzel, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 680-9467 (through Oct. 19). Giant copies of kitschy magazine covers, Frank Stella-style stripe paintings, distorting mirrors, a huge painting of an orange, green and white United States flag, partially smeared; an imitation de Kooning painting, emblazoned with slick lettering reading "No Style No Points"; and a connecting system of brightly colored panels -- altogether, these create a stridently dissonant environment designed, perhaps, to satirize the society of the spectacle (Johnson).

"THE MICROWAVE," Cristinerose/Josee Bienvenu, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 206-0297 (through Oct. 19). "Words have become the disease of the information era," announces the oracular publicity release for this intriguing 11-artist group exhibition. Be that as it may, most of the participants play at transforming the textual into the visual. The ghosts of film subtitles haunt Stefana McClure's minimalist color fields; Stephen Sollins whites out words from television schedules; Marco Maggi constructs miniature architectural models by cutting into reams of typing paper; and Jacob El Hanani draws allover fields of eye-strainingly fine abstract calligraphy (Johnson).

CLIFFORD ROSS, "Hurricanes," Sonnabend, 536 West 22nd Street, (212) 627-1018 (through Nov. 2). When a hurricane hits the coast of Long Island and most reasonable people are indoors safe and dry, Mr. Ross is up to his waist in the ocean shooting the waves. In his large, eerily lucid black-and-white photographs, the thrashing surf appears magically frozen into otherworldly landscapes (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

* KAFFE FASSETT, "Pattern as Obsession," Luise Ross, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 343-2161 (through Oct. 26) Notwithstanding the exhibition's title, this London artist is less obsessed than delightfully inventive in using the domestic arts of knitting, needlepoint, rug hooking and sewing to produce colorful, optically absorbing essays in patternmaking. A funky, folk-art-like quality is belied by the sophisticated play with harmony and dissonance (Johnson).

* 25TH-ANNIVERSARY BENEFIT SELECTIONS EXHIBITION, the Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166 (through Oct. 26). Nearly 400 drawings by artists who have previously exhibited at this valuable institution over the last 25 years create an initial impression of wondrous creative fertility. With extended looking, one starts to feel a certain leveling decorousness, but there are intriguing oddities, like Stavit Allweis's picture of a wild-eyed girl in a pool of water, a kind of surrealistic fairy painting (Johnson).

RICHARD WOODS, Deitch Projects, 76 Grand Street, (212) 343-7300 (through Oct. 19). "Super Tudor," the New York solo debut of this British artist, has a great opening: the gallery exterior tricked out in Olde English half-timber that is optically super, startlingly Tudor and thoroughly surreal. Inside is good, too, but only if you keep your eyes glued to the faux parquet floor, scaled up in shades of blue and black. Otherwise, the promising package holds little more than a pleasant clash of familiarly ironic decor quotations (Smith).

Other Galleries

* "BETWEEN WORD AND IMAGE: MODERN IRANIAN VISUAL CULTURE," Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780 (through Dec. 7). This no-frills exhibition is about the dynamics of cultural borrowing, the inseparability of art and politics, and the interplay of modernism and Islamicism. It begins with painting and sculptures from the 1960's in which Western styles and Iranian themes merge. It continues with riveting photographs documenting the arrival of the Iranian Revolution in 1979. And it concludes with art that the revolution produced: political posters inspired by both the Western counterculture and militant Islamic ideology. Depending on the amount of synthetic thinking you're willing to do, the results can seem richly layered, or disjointed and undercooked. But the materials and the ideas on display are fascinating (Cotter).

ALEX GREY, Tibet House, 22 West 15th Street, Flatiron district, (212) 807-0563 (through Jan. 3). Mr. Grey's painting, with its tantric symbolism, medical-illustration finesse and New Age optimism, might be described as psychedelic realism. In it, the human figure is rendered with X-ray, or CAT scan, transparency, the way Aldous Huxley saw a leaf when he was on mescalin. Mr. Grey's images have been appropriated by a countercultural audience: they have shown up on promotional posters for rave events and on paper used for blotter-style LSD. But they look right at home at Tibet House, where contemporary versions of religious tankas, meant for esoteric instructon and meditation, often hang (Cotter).

"MADE BY NATURE," Dorsky, 11-03 45th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 937-6317 (through Oct. 27). Artists selected by the curator Robert S. Mattison collaborate with natural life forms. Jim Toia's ghostly abstractions are produced by spore-spreading mushrooms. In Michele Brody's luminous installation, blades of rye grass grow from small bottles. In a video by Hope Ginsburg, live bees form a swarming beard on the artist's face. Howard Schwartzberg paints with bloodworms, while Emil Lukas uses live, ink-drenched maggots. Monika Kulicka's chlorophyll restoration projects look like abandoned science experiments (Johnson).

Last Chance

* "ARTIST IN THE MARKET PLACE 22," Bronx Museum of the Arts, 1040 Grand Concourse, Bronx, (718) 681-6000 (through Sunday). The 36 artists in this 22nd annual exhibition hail from Europe, Asia and across the United States. Together they give a fair sense of today's room-for-everyone art world. There's plenty of well-made painting, drawing and sculpture. Work is often politically or psychologically fraught. An incremental aesthetic -- one of piecing together and building up -- prevails. The museum has done its best to help all concerned put a best foot forward by giving the show the full run of the main galleries; the results overall look terrific: airy, serious, museum-quality. Hours: Wednesdays, noon to 9 p.m.; Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 for students and 65+; free on Wednesdays (Cotter).

* RIDLEY HOWARD, Fredericks Freiser, 504 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 633-6555 (through tomorrow). Sweet, day-dreamy and a bit eerie, Mr. Howard's paintings are like a cross between Alex Katz and Edward Gorey. On medium-size canvases, in a finely tuned palette of pale colors, he paints broad, simplified spaces in which he stages suggestive dramas involving small, exactingly drawn people of a certain comfortable class. The image of three elegant people riding in an old-fashioned speedboat across a wide-open sea is oddly exhilarating and enigmatic (Johnson).

* MICHAEL HURSON, Paula Cooper Gallery, 521 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-1105 (through tomorrow). At the heart of this show are seven drawings done from a reproduction of Seurat's painting "Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte." They reiterate the painting's gliding figures and majestic recession of space, while replacing its seamless surface with the quirky, slightly anxious, multitextured intimacy that Mr. Hurson has developed over the years and puts to excellent use here (Smith).

* ROBERT MELEE, "You Me and Her," Andrew Kreps Gallery, 516 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 741-8849 (through tomorrow). Picasso had his wives and lovers. William Wegman has his Weimaraners. Mr. Melee has his mother. She is the muse of his current show and, as always, an arresting presence: past middle age, partial to Phyllis Diller wigs, Alice Cooper eyeliner and alcohol, she is the subject of photographs and videos notable for their mingling of affection and aggression. They exist in some transcendently abject universe where inhibitions and animosities fall where they may, where perversity is pleasure and decay a kind of innocence. You may not want to live there, but you won't forget your visit in a hurry (Cotter).

JOAN MITCHELL, HORACE BRISTOL, Robert Miller Gallery, 524 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 366-4774 (through tomorrow). Mitchell works from four decades include some fine, sensuously gnarly examples from the late 1950's and early 60's. Bristol, an early Life magazine staff photographer, made photographs for the Navy in the 1940's; they have an odd resonance now in a time of war anxiety and patriotic agitation (Johnson).

* "HELIO OITICICA: QUASI-CINEMAS," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, between Prince and Houston Streets, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Sunday). A Brazilian proto-installationist of the 1960's, Oiticica wanted nothing more than to have people kick off their shoes and immerse themselves in the karmic pleasures he devised. This show focuses on his somewhat tangential work of the 70's, when he lived in New York: it consists of rooms slung with hammocks or padded with mattresses or covered with sand and balloons; slides of Jimi Hendrix, Marilyn Monroe and Luis Bunuel flash on the walls to music by Yma Sumac, the Latin diva. This description makes the work sound juvenile or pointless, which it is not. A buoyancy derives partly from the sly humor, self-mocking and pervasive. Art was for Oiticica a state of mind and a condition of the heart -- a university for the soul with an open-admission policy. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, noon to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3 for students, artists and 65+ (Kimmelman).

"OUT OF SITE: FICTIONAL ARCHITECTURAL SPACE," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Sunday). For many young artists, the mingling of art and architecture holds manifold attractions. It's a way to blur categories, explore new technologies, deal with interesting images and social themes. The participants in this savvy group show, organized by Anne Ellegood, do all this in work that treats architecture as virtual structure, a fluid marker of space. Matthew Northridge's cityscape of 3,000 small, various-size handmade blocks of masonite is a standout, along with Sven Pahlsson's hallucinatory video animation "Sprawlville or Life at Highway Exit Ramp," Nina Bovasso's paintings of piled-up cities and Ricci Albenda's optically dynamic wall of words. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

PAUL HENRY RAMIREZ, "Space Addiction," Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street, (917) 663-2453 (through today). In flat, hard-edged graphics, Mr. Ramirez's zany montage of spurting breasts, delicately hair-fringed orifices, dangling genitalia, targets, polka dots and stripes harmoniously proliferates all over the gallery's walls. It suggests that what underlies holistic fantasies of Modernist design is infantile yearning for the ideal mother. Out in the courtyard, "Outer City, Inner Space" (through Jan. 3) includes an undulating, tubular ceiling by Teresita Fernandez; an internally illuminated, futuristic igloo by Stephen Hendee; and a giant Chinese food takeout bag by Ester Parteg -- all resonating to good effect with Mr. Ramirez's Neo-Pop lunacy (Johnson).

* "SNAPSHOT POETICS: PHOTOGRAPHS BY ALLEN GINSBERG," Howard Greenberg, 120 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 334-0010 (through tomorrow). Ginsberg, the ur-Beat poet, had only the finest in photography teachers. Berenice Abbott advised him: "Don't be a shutterbug, young man" and "Don't get so close or you'll get a bulging eye or cheek too big." Robert Frank told him to include the hands of people more often in his pictures. But before Abbott and Frank took him under their wings, when Ginsberg was taking pictures "as keepsakes of my own total sacramental, personal interest in intimate friends," he did just fine. His "drugstore prints" of his fellow Beats, Jack Kerouac, Neal Cassady, Peter Orlovsky, William S. Burroughs, Lawrence Ferlinghetti and Gregory Corso, have a dashing callowness about them, especially those with Ginsberg's precise handwritten captions. This gallery acquired the Ginsberg photographic archive in the spring, and is showing off a bit of its bounty, 68 prints out of more than 1,000 vintage and modern prints. (Sarah Boxer).

HEADLINE: INSIDE ART 

BYLINE:  By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:
A Corporate Sale With Personality
 I.B.M. did it; so did Reader's Digest. When the going got tough, these companies auctioned prized selections from their art collections. Now on Nov. 13 Christie's is to auction nine works of postwar and contemporary art owned by the Israel Phoenix Assurance Company. 
 The company is selling because of a change in ownership, as did CBS when it sold 100 works at Sotheby's in 1997 for $3.9 million. Generally, outstanding corporate collections are formed by chief executives so passionate about art that they buy paintings, drawings, prints and sculptures not just for their own living rooms but for the office, too. This collection, one of the few corporate collections in Israel, was formed by Joseph Hackmey, the company's former managing director, who began buying art for the company in the early 1980's. 
Mr. Hackmey put together a rare collection of Israeli art, which the company is keeping. But after he sold his controlling shares in the company to car importers this year, the new owners decided to part with some of the postwar and contemporary art. "Although it is a corporate collection, it's very personal," said Brett Gorvy, head of postwar art for Christie's worldwide.
The nine works being sold are expected to bring $14.2 million to $20 million. They include a group of minimalist pieces by Robert Ryman, Agnes Martin and Eva Hesse and paintings by American postwar masters like Jasper Johns, Barnett Newman, Robert Rauschenberg and Mark Rothko.
Of the group, two are already generating much talk among collectors. One is Johns's "0 Through 9" (1961), a superimposition of the numerals 0 to 9 in a range of grays, estimated at $6 million to $8 million. Over the years it has been in several respected collections, among them those of the publishing magnate S. I. Newhouse Jr. and the architect Graham Gund, based in Cambridge, Mass.
Two others from the same series, in color, have recently landed in museums: the Whitney Museum of American Art bought one this year for a reported $15 million, and in 1999 the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art bought a "0 Through 9" and nine other works for an unreported price from the Fukuoka City Bank in Japan. Still, major early paintings by Johns don't often come on the market.
Rarer still are paintings by Newman. The company is selling "White Fire I" (1954), the first major Newman on the market since Christie's sold "The Word II" (1954) for a record $3 million in 1995. "White Fire I," which was part of the recent Newman retrospective at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, is at the Tate Modern in London, where the exhibition is currently on view. The painting is to leave the Tate for Christie's Rockefeller Center headquarters a week before the sale, and the new buyer will be asked to send it back until the exhibition closes on Jan. 5.
It was once owned by E. J. Powers, a pioneer in the communications industry, who died in 1993 and was a prominent collector of modern art in the postwar years. One of Newman's mature abstractions, it consists of an aqua background punctuated by two zips, as he called them: a wide pale beige band on the left and a bleeding blue stripe on the right. Christie's estimates the painting will bring $4 million to $6 million.
"It's domestic in scale," Mr. Gorvy said of the 47--by-59 3/4-inch painting. "The sheer rarity of seeing a painting like this on the market is already creating extraordinary interest, and timing is perfect, given the recent acclaim accorded to the exhibition."
Like most other top works on the market this fall, the collection attracted considerable competition from other auction houses and galleries, specifically PaceWildenstein, experts close to the negotiations said. And the sellers insisted on financing; in this case, Christie's actually bought the paintings. While executives there won't say how much they paid, experts believe it was around $13 million.

A Gift for San Francisco
A rocky economy may have slowed some big spenders, but the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art is still receiving gifts. This week it announced that an anonymous donor had made a partial and promised gift to the museum of an eight-painting suite created by Gerhard Richter in 1999. The news was timed to tomorrow's opening of "Gerhard Richter: 40 Years of Painting," a traveling exhibition that opened at the Museum of Modern Art in New York in February, then went to the Art Institute of Chicago. (It will be on view in San Francisco through Jan. 14, then it goes to the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington from Feb. 20 to May 18.)
The eight paintings, each named "Abstract Picture" and numbered 858-1 through 858-8, are brilliantly colored. Seven are on aluminum panels, and the eighth is on linen. The series was not included in the retrospective in New York or Chicago.
"This is a huge gift for us," said Madeleine Grynsztejn, senior curator of painting and sculpture at the San Francisco museum. "With this group we now own 21 works by Richter, ranging from early works in 1966 through all his stylistic periods."

New Public Archive
Art history students and scholars will now have two major archives available to them.
Calvin Tomkins, the New Yorker writer and author of many books on modern art, has donated his research materials to the Museum of Modern Art. The gift includes complete interviews with artists like Robert Rauschenberg and curators like Kirk Varnedoe.
Meanwhile the Getty Research Institute in Los Angeles, which was given the Duveen Archive by the Metropolitan Museum of Art four years ago, has finished cataloging it and putting it on microfilm. The archive, records of the celebrated dealers who operated from 1869 to 1964 in London, Paris and New York, will be available at the Getty Research Center, and microfilm copies will be given to the Watson Library at the Met, the Witt Library of the Courtauld Institute in London and the Institute of Art History in Paris.

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
The DNA Of a Fading Motor Skill: R-1-2-3-4

BYLINE:  By GEORGE BLUMBERG 

 BODY:
MY mother was at the wheel of our blue Chevrolet and my father was next to her, yelling, "More gas, more gas!" It was 1953, and Mom was getting a driving lesson at a time when for most people, driving still required shifting the gears of a manual transmission.
 The sound of grinding gears, the shuddering and bucking that snaps the heads of children in the back seat (like mine, on that memorable day) back and forth, the cries of "clutch in!" and "now shift to second!" -- these once-familiar parts of every new driver's rite of passage have been all but written off as fading bits of Americana. An alarming number of adults no longer share memories like mine. 
 Many perfectly competent drivers now view the ability to drive a manual-shift car as arcane and somewhat exotic, almost a black art. 
But there are still people who want to learn. And there are still parents (and probably spouses) who want to teach. Like tracking tigers in the jungle, weaving rope or starting fires with flint and steel, shifting has historically been taught within families, passed down through the generations. And in some families, it still is.
Driving schools have pretty much dropped out. "We don't have an instruction car to teach manual-transmission driving -- there just isn't enough demand," said Brad Huspek, who has been a driving instructor for 25 years and is a now school administrator for Sears Driving Schools in Lansing, Mich. "It's maybe just a little section in our textbook."
According to Neal Oddes, the manager of product research for J. D. Power & Associates, an auto industry research firm, only about 9 percent of new cars and light trucks have manual transmissions. Another 9 percent have the new manual-automatic hybrids: the driver pushes a button to select a gear, a computer actually makes the shift, and there's no clutch pedal. The great majority, 82 percent, have traditional automatics. Indeed, another term for the manual transmission, standard, has become a misnomer. 
Manual-transmission cars may be cheaper, but not by much. An automatic transmission, financed over the years, adds just a few dollars a month to a car payment, according to Bob VanAlmkerk, a sales manager of Brandfon Honda in Branford, Conn. Manual transmissions, he said, are "more for the performance seeker."
Statistics say he is right. In the premium sports car category, which includes cars like Porsches, the Audi TT and BMW's Z models, manual transmissions are in 61 percent of the new cars sold. Twenty percent are hybrids, and just 19 percent are automatics. For people who want to make use of all the power and versatility of the machine as they drive, controlling the gears is a natural part of the experience.
Whatever cars they drive, proponents of manual shifting talk about practicality -- greater control of the car in slippery conditions, fuel economy. But when pressed, they readily admit that they find shifting fun.
Who wouldn't want to share that with the next generation?
As I grew up, I watched my father's intricate driver's ballet, feet moving from clutch to accelerator to brake and back, hands plying the shift lever in synchronicity. When the day came, I made the transition from passenger to driver. I can imagine my father before me, watching his aunt shift her DeSoto taxi -- she was one of the few women driving cabs in New York City in the 1930's -- or seeing his carpenter father's huge, rough hand stir the big gear lever that sprouted from the floor of his 1936 Pontiac.
Sometimes, children teach parents. "I learned to shift from my son when he was in the fifth grade," said Cindy Willoughby, the communications officer for the Driving School Association of the Americas in Milwaukee and a licensed instructor. "In 1978 my husband blocked my car in the driveway with his new Ford pickup, and he wasn't around to move it." Her son, now 34, told her that he would sit next to her in the pickup and tell her when to shift. "Off we went to the mall," Ms. Willoughby said, laughing at the memory. "It was a little jerky at first, but smooth on the way back." Later Ms. Willoughby taught her two daughters to shift, and now they both drive a car with a five-speed manual transmission.
I taught my own daughter in a Honda Civic Si. Years later, when she picked me up at the Anchorage airport one day in her Toyota four-by-four pickup, I swung myself into the cab and smiled. There in front of me were the five-speed gear lever and the separate transfer case lever to shift into high or low four-wheel drive.
As we drove into the snowstorm, I felt secure. The shifting gene was intact.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW; 
Seeking a Smoking Gun in U.S. Violence

BYLINE:  By A. O. SCOTT 

 BODY:
Michael Moore's new documentary, "Bowling for Columbine," rapturously greeted at the Cannes Film Festival in May, opens today in New York City and Los Angeles in an atmosphere of intense political polarization. Not that Mr. Moore, a cheerful rabble-rouser and author of the best seller "Stupid White Men," would have it any other way. But in times of political anxiety and global insecurity -- most times, in other words -- arguments have a tendency to turn into shouting matches.
 The most disappointing -- and the most likely -- response to Mr. Moore's disturbing, infuriating and often very funny film would be uncritical support from his ideological friends and summary dismissal from his foes. The slippery logic, tendentious grandstanding and outright demagoguery on display in "Bowling for Columbine" should be enough to give pause to its most ardent partisans, while its disquieting insights into the culture of violence in America should occasion sober reflection from those who would prefer to stop their ears. 
 I hope the movie is widely seen and debated with appropriate ferocity and thoughtfulness. Does that sound evasive? I'm sorry if it does, but at the moment, political certainty seems to me to be a cheap and abundant commodity, of much less value than honest ambivalence. 
Mr. Moore, in the good-natured, confrontational style familiar from "Roger and Me" and "TV Nation," his sadly short-lived series on Fox, tracks his subject far and wide: a little too far and a little too wide perhaps. His starting point is the horrific massacre at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo. Like everyone else, he wonders how such a thing could have happened, and what it says about contemporary American society. 
These questions quickly lead to larger ones: Why do Americans shoot one another so much more often than the citizens of other developed countries? Why do our lives seem to be governed by fear? The recent string of killings around Washington provides a grim reminder that these issues are always timely.
These are hardly simple questions, and Mr. Moore vacillates between acknowledging their complexity and giving in to his own urge to simplify. He dismisses a number of possible answers out of hand. Is violent popular culture to blame? No, because in a country like Japan, with a tiny fraction of our gun deaths, people consume super-brutal movies, video games and comic books with even more voracity than we do. Poverty? No, since Canada and many European nations have much higher unemployment rates and much lower homicide rates. Is it our history of warfare and brutality? Compared with imperial Britain and Nazi Germany, he suggests, we're downright pacific. 
But each of these assertions rides roughshod over some obvious doubts and qualifications. Unemployment, in countries with more extensive welfare states than ours, is not necessarily the same as poverty, and the wholesale brutality of states and empires engaged in wars of conquest is not the same as the retail mayhem of armed individuals.
But though he seems to be hunting for a specific historical cause for events like Columbine, Mr. Moore, when it serves his purposes, is happy to generalize in the absence of empirical evidence and to make much of connections that seem spurious on close examination. Several times he notes that the Columbine shootings occurred on the same day as the heaviest United States bombing of the Kosovo war. The more you think about this coincidence, the less it seems to mean.
He visits a Lockheed Martin plant near Columbine that manufactures missiles and pesters a company flack about the links between the factory's products and the shootings. "I guess I don't see that connection," the man says, standing in front of the company's wares. Mr. Moore and the camera clearly take him for a fool: another stupid white man doing his job. But you don't have to be a big fan of nuclear weapons to think that he might have a point.
This exchange is followed by a montage, accompanied by Louis Armstrong singing "What a Wonderful World," of American foreign policy misdeeds from the 1950's to the present. Their relevance is, again, arguable, but by now it should be clear that Mr. Moore is less interested in argument than in provocation. The last image is of the airplanes smashing into the World Trade Center, accompanied by this text: "Sept. 11, 2001: Osama bin Laden uses his expert C.I.A. training to murder 3,000 people." 
The idiocy of this statement is hardly worth engaging; it is exactly the kind of glib distortion of history that can be taken as a warrant to dismiss everything Mr. Moore has to say. And this is a shame, since much of the movie is worth engaging, and manifests genuine curiosity and a wicked satirical sense along with finger-pointing self-righteousness. While Mr. Moore, as an interviewer, has a tendency to shame his subjects or make them look ridiculous, he can also be a sympathetic, attentive listener. And to his credit, he includes several moments in which he himself is clearly distressed or taken by surprise by what his interlocutors have to say. 
The camera collects quite a few odd, touching and unsettling moments. A home-security consultant, full of matter-of-fact sales talk about deadbolts and fortified safe rooms, breaks down at the mention of Columbine. A visit to James Nichols, whose brother, Terry, helped Timothy McVeigh plan the Oklahoma City bombing, reveals a scared, angry man who lives surrounded by guns on a farm where he grows, of all things, organic soybeans to be made into tofu. And a prosecutor in Michigan, Mr. Moore's home state, explains that guns are a much bigger problem in the white suburbs there than in mostly black urban areas.
"I didn't think that's what you were going to say," Mr. Moore says. "I thought you were going to say it was black kids in the inner city." When he goes against the grain of his own prejudices -- and keeps in check his desire to be the center of attention -- "Bowling for Columbine" is riveting and scary, and its vision of a society racked by fear, riven by inequality and armed to the teeth is neither comforting nor easily wished away.
Mr. Moore's less admirable traits cannot be ignored, even -- and especially -- if you find merit in some of his views. The film seems to reach a natural conclusion when Mr. Moore, accompanied by two boys wounded at Columbine, visits Kmart's corporate headquarters to demand that the company stop selling ammunition. (The high school killers bought their bullets in one of its stores.) But Mr. Moore, unable to forgo another chance to prove his moral superiority, ends the film with a visit to Charlton Heston's house.
You can be repelled by Mr. Heston's actions as president of the National Rifle Association -- he is shown addressing pro-gun rallies that took place in the wake of the school shootings in both Littleton and Flint, Mich. -- and still find Mr. Moore's tactics distasteful. His tendency to scapegoat may satisfy his need for drama, but it makes for lousy politics.
"Bowling for Columbine" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has many scenes of violence, most taken from surveillance videos and the evening news.

BOWLING FOR COLUMBINE

Written and directed by Michael Moore; directors of photography, Brian Danitz and Michael McDonough; edited by Kurt Engfehr; music by Jeff Gibbs; produced by Charles Bishop, Michael Donovan, Kathleen Glynn, Jim Czarnecki and Mr. Moore; released by United Artists/Alliance Atlantis. Running time: 119 minutes. This film is rated R.

WITH: Michael Moore, Dick Clark, Charlton Heston, James Nichols, Marilyn Manson, John Nichols and Matt Stone.

HEADLINE: S.E.C. Chief Promises To Cooperate With Europe 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Oct. 10 

 BODY:
Harvey L. Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, may be under increasing fire in Washington, where Democratic leaders accuse him of having been too soft on corporate wrongdoing. But he won praise from European policy makers here today when he promised to seek their cooperation on a broad range of new accounting standards and regulatory measures.
 Responding to criticism that the United States practices a kind of economic imperialism by requiring some foreign companies to comply with a new corporate oversight law, Mr. Pitt told a gathering of European accounting professionals today, "We seek to usher in a new regulatory regime in concert with you, not impose our solutions on you." 
 Mr. Pitt said he was open to considering waivers in special cases where the new law, known as the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, conflicts with the laws of foreign countries or where foreign regulations can achieve comparable ends by different means. To keep a trans-Atlantic dialogue open on these issues, Mr. Pitt said he was considering having the S.E.C. open an office in Brussels.
But he stopped short of offering the broad exemptions to the law that some Europeans have hoped for. Mr. Pitt said he was obliged "to implement the Sarbanes-Oxley Act fully for all companies, foreign and domestic," and that "foreign companies can, therefore, expect that many of our new rules will apply to them."
Still, Mr. Pitt's willingness to discuss these issues and consider alternatives was well received at a time when many of the messages Washington sends on economic and regulatory issues are viewed here as one-sided. Frederik Bolkestein, the European Union commissioner for internal markets and taxation, who met privately with Mr. Pitt during his trip to Brussels, said he was encouraged by the new air of collaboration. 
Beyond the corporate governance issues addressed by the Oxley-Sarbanes law, the newly cooperative atmosphere extends to accounting rules, especially for companies wishing to sell stock in countries other than their own. 
Right now, many European companies must prepare their accounts twice under different and sometimes conflicting rules, once for their home country's stock market and regulators and once for Wall Street and the S.E.C. But American and European officials agreed last month to work toward a set of common standards, which in some instances will mean modifying American rules to conform to the international accounting standards generally used in Europe -- an idea that was virtually unthinkable as recently as a year ago.
"Traditionally, the argument from the United States has been that if we want to have an international set of rules, they ought to be U.S. rules, because we have the best system," said Robert H. Herz, the chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, in a recent interview. Referring to the Enron, WorldCom and other corporate scandals, Mr. Herz said, "The recent events have led people to question whether our system is that much superior, and it has increased receptivity toward international accounting standards."
At the same time, the international standards, whose authors sought to combine the best rules from a range of competing national standards, have been gaining momentum abroad. All 15 member nations of the European Union, plus Australia and Russia, have pledged to adopt them by Jan. 1, 2005, increasing pressure on the United States to take them seriously.
"This is the first big move, and it could lead to others," Sir David Tweedie, the chairman of the International Accounting Standards Board, said of the agreement his board struck last month with its American counterpart, the board led by Mr. Herz.
The two panels will go rule by rule through the two sets of standards over the next few months and vote on which provision is best in each case. That will not always be easy, some experts warned, because they start with different fundamental premises. The international standards tend more toward setting general principles and then requiring accountants to use their own best judgment in following them. By contrast, the American standards set out thousands of specific rules that must be followed.
Critics of the American system say it encourages mindless compliance without considering the broader picture and tramples the spirit of the rules while abiding by their letter. Critics of the international standards say they allow too much room for competing interpretations of the same transactions.
Some of the choices between the rules are expected to be straightforward. For instance, Sir David said he expected the panels to favor the international rules for pension fund accounting, which call for recording fair value of assets at the end of each year. American rules now allow pension funds to use an average value of the assets over five years, which can mask losses, he said.
Other provisions are expected to lead to more debate, like the accounting for research and development costs. The international standards treat development costs like a tangible asset, capitalizing them on the balance sheet and then depreciating them over the life of the product. American rules treat some development costs that way but call for others to be treated as expenses when they are incurred.
The difference can be major for some companies. Nokia, the cellular phone maker, calculated its 2001 net income under both systems, and came up with 2.2 billion euros the European way, but only 1.9 billion euros the American way, in part because it had to treat more of its development costs as expenses.
"The arguments for each rule are pretty evenly matched," said Mary Tokar, a partner at KPMG. "You can't say one is clearly right and the other is clearly wrong."
As a parting word of advice, Mr. Pitt urged international accounting rule makers to keep clear of politics. He apparently was following that rule himself when he refused today to comment on recent calls for his resignation by Congressional Democrats.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Marketers gather to talk of coping with tough times.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
GROWING doubt about the course of the economy has dimmed the mood of consumer marketers as they gather for the first meeting of their trade association in two years.
 The marketers are gathering for the 92nd meeting of the Association of National Advertisers, which began yesterday in Naples, Fla., and continues through Sunday. The uncertainty among members of the association, which canceled its conference last year after the terrorist attacks, is indicated in estimates that attendance will fall to about 400 from almost 500 in 2000. 
 "It's down from previous years, as you might expect, but it's gratifying that we have this many people," John J. Sarsen Jr., president and chief executive of the association, said in an interview before the conference began. 
"Everyone is cautious," Mr. Sarsen added. "Even people who are optimistic are cautious."
Anyone needing additional evidence for that risky outlook found it this week in several places. In a consumer survey by the NPD Group, 89 percent of respondents said they planned to spend the same amount or less during the holiday shopping season than they did in the period a year ago. Also, 98 percent of respondents agreed that buying on sale was just as or more important than it was last year, when the profits of retailers fell after they reduced prices to stimulate demand.
The anxiety in retailing was reflected by an unexpected reshuffling of the senior marketing ranks at Sears, Roebuck & Company only 70 shopping days before Christmas. David Selby, the senior vice president for marketing at Sears -- and a member of the board of the association -- is leaving as of Tuesday. He will be succeeded by Janine Bousquette as executive vice president and chief customer and marketing officer. Word of Mr. Selby's departure came the same day he was named No. 11 on a list of the top 25 "power players" among corporate marketers by the trade publication Advertising Age.
Also, in a report this week on the advertising and marketing services industries, Kevin Sullivan, an analyst at Lehman Brothers, said he was concerned about "the impact of the fragile economy" on marketing spending in the fourth quarter and early next year, "as marketers look to protect their bottom lines." As a result, Lehman lowered earnings estimates for Harte-Hanks, the Interpublic Group of Companies and the Omnicom Group.
"These are troubling times for sure, no question about it," said James D. Speros, chief marketing officer for the United States at Ernst & Young in New York, who is the 2001-02 vice chairman of the association.
"The fundamentals for many businesses are still not strong, causing some marketers to pull back and hurting the media and agencies," Mr. Speros said, which is why the conference is being focused on "what advertisers must do to build brands and foster growth in a troubled economy."
Prescriptions to achieve those goals are to be offered this morning by two speakers in the first general session. One is Charles B. Strauss, chairman of Unilever North America in New York and the other is Thomas G. Stemberg, chairman and chief executive at Staples, the office supply retailer.
"The way you survive and prosper in uncertain times in the categories we're in is to innovate on your best brands," Mr. Strauss said. "And that's what we're doing" because "that's where we see real opportunities for growth."
For instance, Mr. Strauss said that in August Unilever began introducing American men to Axe -- a deodorant body spray the company sells in other countries -- with a big, splashy campaign by the New York office of Bartle Bogle Hegarty. The budget is large, an estimated $90 million, and "we're very happy with the early results," he added.
"The pressure, the challenge, is to grow the top line," Mr. Strauss said, referring to revenue, "and our marketing spending in the second half and fourth quarter will be significantly higher than what we had a year ago or in the first half."
Mr. Stemberg said Staples also saw advantage in adversity.
"Our basic business is trending positively," Mr. Stemberg said, "and we see a huge opportunity to differentiate ourselves from the many other purveyors of office products."
Staples is introducing this week the first work from its new agency, Martin/Williams in Minneapolis, part of Omnicom. The $70 million campaign is intended to help deliver "high-single-digit revenue growth for the remainder of the year," Mr. Stemberg said, despite the sluggish economy.
At the general session tomorrow, a leading agency executive, Donny Deutsch, will offer suggestions on overcoming tough times. Some of what he plans to say may surprise the audience.
"I think agencies can do better, and clients need to make agencies do better," said Mr. Deutsch, chairman and chief executive at Deutsch in New York, part of the Partnership division of Interpublic. "The harder clients are on agencies, the better agencies become."
"Maybe clients shouldn't stay with agencies 30 years," he added. "What does that mean? Let's make it about accountability. If you don't perform in a year, you should be gone."
The conference is also devoting time to rituals like the election of officers and the presentation of awards.
Mr. Speros of Ernst & Young was elected chairman of the association for 2002-03. He succeeds Dawn Hudson, the chairwoman for 2001-'02; she is the president of Pepsi-Cola North America in Purchase, N.Y., part of PepsiCo.
James R. Stengel, global marketing officer at the Procter & Gamble Company in Cincinnati, was elected vice chairman for 2002-03.
On the awards front, John Hamlin, vice president for the consumer group at the Dell Computer Corporation in Round Rock, Tex., received the Grand Marketer of the Year Award from the trade publication Brandweek, published by VNU, at the dinner last night. Mr. Hamlin was selected from winners of awards in 10 consumer-product categories for his work in helping Dell become the nation's leading brand of personal computers.
Also, Edward A. Faruolo, vice president for corporate marketing at the Cigna Corporation in Philadelphia, will receive today the Robert V. Goldstein Award, named after a former board member of the association and the Advertising Council. Mr. Faruolo is being honored for his work as volunteer director of a pro bono campaign for American for the Arts.
