HEADLINE: On Main Street, Business Is a Bit Lean 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN WARNER

DATELINE: BERNARDSVILLE 

 BODY:
ON Mine Book Road, the hilly shopping street that rises up from the commuter train station, a few longtime retailers selling orthopedic shoes and dry goods mingle with newcomers selling high-end kitchen gizmos, a sleek Japanese restaurant and a chic ladies' boutique where Palumbo's family pharmacy used to be.
 Yet even here in Somerset County -- surrounded by the stone-walled estates of corporate titans and New Jersey's horsey set -- retailers fear that after a long buying binge, consumers are beginning to pull back. 
 "People are holding on to their bucks," said Sid Sussman, owner of Sussman's Department Store, an independent dry goods and clothing retailer in Bernardsville since 1948. "They've lost money in the stock market. They're worried about their jobs. They're even sending their wives back to work." 
And if this wealthy enclave is feeling the strain, then the question becomes even more urgent: how are the rest of the more than 200 downtown shopping districts throughout the state holding up during this time of uncertainty?
Last year, going into the all-important holiday season, shoppers in New Jersey were still reeling from the terrorism attacks of Sept. 11 and the anthrax scare. Moreover, those traumas were set against a backdrop of rising unemployment and declining stock market prices.
Still, consumers surprised economists with their resilience through much of the past year. Interest rates remained low and housing values continued to climb. Homeowners refinanced mortgages to put more money in their pockets or snap up new cars on zero-interest payment plans.
But now retailers fear the long-awaited slowdown is beginning to take shape, with the possibility of war in Iraq the latest blow to consumer confidence.
"People could deal with Sept. 11," said Pam Schroeder, the owner of Epitome, a women's clothing boutique. "They were starting to heal. They were trying to be positive about the economy when this issue with Iraq came up. I think that is what really started the concern."
She said her sales remained strong this year, at least until the middle of the summer, when plans for the invasion of Iraq began to dominate the headlines.
And as if talk of war and a struggling economy were not enough, the exceptionally warm weather through the summer and early fall has also worked against retailers. "When the weather is hot they're not concentrating on what they should be buying for the winter," said Philip Santangelo, a salesman at J. Mastro shoes in Bernardsville.
Even the calendar is conspiring against storeowners -- who typically make two-thirds of their annual sales and half their profits in the holiday season. This year, Hannukah starts early, on Nov. 29, and the period between Thanksgiving and Christmas is shorter than last year.
"With six less shopping days this year, we're a little concerned," said Melanie Willoughby, president of the New Jersey Retail Merchants Association, which represents 3,500 merchants in the state.
Ms. Willoughby said that while low interest rates have encouraged home buying and car shopping for a time, consumers now face the reality that they must live with the payments on those loans. In addition, she said, health care is also taking an increasing share of disposable income.
"Our outlook for the holiday sales season nationally as well as in New Jersey is at best dim," said Kurt Barnard, a national retail consultant based in Upper Montclair. "We'll be lucky if we meet the levels that were achieved a year ago, which were really paltry."
The problem is that shopping is big business in New Jersey. For instance, Ms. Willoughby said that 50,449 stores were scattered throughout this state, the most densely populated in the nation. The retail industry employs 585,000 workers -- the second-largest employment category in the state after services, she said.
Last year alone, total retail sales were put at $105 billion, up from $101.9 billion in 2000. This year, sales are expected to reach $107.1 billion, and grow to $110.9 billion in 2003, according to the New Jersey Council of Economic Advisors.
But the council said the increase was not being driven by retail sales along the myriad Main Streets throughout the state, but by new car sales, a healthy real estate market and tourism.

'People Out of Work'
On the down side, payroll employment declined at the annual rate of 0.3 percent in the first half of the year, according to the council -- though even there New Jersey fared better than the nation as a whole, which recorded a 1.2 percent decline in employment. 
"I have a lot of friends who have lost their jobs on Wall Street and in computers and the Internet," said John Zulauf, who owns three stores in Ridgewood. "There are definitely people out of work."
Indeed, some of them had worked for Mr. Zulauf himself. He said he had eliminated seven part-time positions, and was working two or three shifts a week at the register as well as managing his stores.
Last year, Mr. Zulauf's business was up 18 percent before Sept. 11, but ended the year down 15 percent. "That was a huge swing of cash for a small business," he said.
Despite the disturbing signs, he said that in the last few months, some of the volatility had disappeared and that he was planning on a 10 percent increase at his stores, which sell crafts, home furnishings and cards, stationery and albums.
In addition to concerns over the loss of jobs and the increasing uncertainty over Iraq, the summer's corporate scandals eroded confidence in business and drove share prices down even further. As the Council of Economic Advisors said in its mid-year report made public last month: "Falling equity prices combined with widespread stock ownership pose substantial risks to consumer confidence, and spending and are the single-largest threat to the recovery."
A sluggish holiday spending season is expected to weigh on malls as well as Main Street. Already there have been casualties among retail chain stores, including Ames Department Stores, Kmart and The Wiz, which have closed New Jersey stores in the past year.
Malls remain heavily dependent on their department store anchors and apparel retailers, which tend to have high-end prices and have been struggling compared with home furnishings stores.
"We are very heavily malled here in New Jersey," said Mr. Barnard, the retail consultant. "But we are in a period right now of very great caution on the part of the consumer, and people today will go to a store and look at the price tag before they look at the product. In the late 90's you often didn't look at the price tag at all."
Ms. Willoughby said so-called power centers -- anchored by such discounters as Target, Kohl's or Wal-Mart -- were expected to fare better than malls in a downturn, although Wal-Mart surprised retail analysts recently with a more cautious outlook.
To be sure, some businesses -- like home repair centers -- are booming. And last spring, clothing sales were up 6 percent over the same period last year, while home furnishing sales were up almost double that, 11 percent, Mr. Barnard said.
Lyn Sattler, the owner of Absolutely Fabulous Things Amen, a home furnishings shop in Bernardsville, said that she was expecting a good season. She believes that though customers may prune their gift lists this year, they will still spend to create a homey holiday
"People aren't going to be picking up a lot of little nothings," Ms. Sattler said. "But when it comes to family and friends, they are going to want to create a sense of warmth for the people they love."
From Mr. Barnard's vantage point, however, Main Street merchants are the most vulnerable in a sharp spending downturn, particularly because small retailers cannot offer the selection and the bargains of a national discounter, and because they often lack the capital to ride out a prolonged slowdown.
To Elaine Moffett, who has owned three different stores over the past 31 years in Westfield, a prosperous middle-class town in Union County, spending downturns are like hurricanes.
"You just have to hang in there and weather it," said Ms. Moffett. "You have your good years and you have your bad years. This is a tough year, but we've had many good years. That's how the pendulum swings."
Ms. Moffett, who has run Periwinkle Gifts since 1989, said her inventory levels were lean, and she was working harder to find bargains from her own suppliers to pass along to price-sensitive shoppers.

Better Positioned This Time
Brian Ford, a retail analyst at Ernst & Young, said New Jersey's downtowns were better positioned to survive a downturn this year than they were in the early 90's, when store vacancy rates were up and they were confronting new competition from discount centers. 
Since then, Mr. Ford said, shoppers had grown to savor the personalized attention they could get in small-town shopping districts and have become increasingly reluctant to fight the traffic to clogged malls and shopping plazas.
"It is a whole different experience when you go to Main Street," he said. "It's an outing. You get the family together and walk. You have something to eat. You do some shopping. You feel like you had a quality time."
Since 1990, 22 towns have participated in the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs' Main Street New Jersey program, which offers technical assistance to volunteer organizations that want to take a coordinated approach to managing their local business districts.
In those towns, 891 new businesses have been started and 115 have expanded, creating 4,907 jobs. Private investors have spent more than $140.6 million on building rehabilitations. Another $5 million in public money, mostly from county and local governments, has also gone into refurbishing downtown buildings.
Joe Spector, a third-generation owner of The Leader Store, an independent clothing and sporting goods retailer in Westfield, said public improvements and better business coordination have allowed it to blossom since the recession of the early 1990's.
"That was a transitional time not only for Westfield but the whole region," Mr. Spector said. "It was a time when a lot of traditional mom-and- pop retailers were retiring. But the facelift we've had in the last 10 to 12 years has helped to make Westfield a regional shopping destination again."
When many revitalization efforts were completed, towns found they had new restaurants to feed those shoppers whose wallets were swollen with Wall Street profits -- from sushi bars to pastarias to pizza places.
Chris Nadolny and his wife, Ellen, opened Celebrate Food & Cafe seven years ago in Maplewood Village, a picture postcard town in Essex County. Last fall, when diners became anxious about going into Manhattan, business surged. More than a year later, customers are still coming and spending $5 to $6 a ticket over last year, said Mr. Nadolny.
Even if the economy sours, he said, people will still come out to eat.
"I think the difference between the last recession and what is going on now is that people used to see the stock market as a safe place to leave their money," he said. "Now they are pulling it out and putting it into their home and into enjoying life. The consumer is 10 years more intelligent now. They have more of a sense of the ups and downs."
When Peter Matushin was planning to open his luxury high-concept store JetLife in Westfield, he did research into spending during the Depression era.
"Even in the worst economy, women went out and bought a tube of lipstick and men bought shaving cream because they were soothing, minor self-indulgences as opposed to buying a new car or house," Mr. Matushin said. "Buying a high-quality bar of soap is attainable in the worst economy."
Mr. Matushin, and his partner, Donna Pudwill, who were downsized out of their jobs in last August after years in corporate America -- said starting a business in a trying economy was less risky than it might seem.
"Corporate America is no safer than opening up a mom-and-pop shop if after 15 years you can be dropped with a week's notice like a rusty stapler," he said. "We decided to invest in something tangible -- ourselves."
JetLife, housed in a former fur shop, mixes standard retailing with services and event-driven marketing. For instance, the store sells cotton towels, soap and other pampering products. And for their troubles, customers are offered electronic chair massages, an oxygen bar and hydro-aromatherapy. Shoppers can even use all three services at one for a package discount.
Mr. Matushin also wants to develop an art gallery and stage such events as yoga classes or a "nail night" to benefit charity and fill the shop with potential customers.
"A lot of these people in these towns in their younger days lived in Manhattan and went to the same clubs in the 80's," Mr. Matushin said. "Now, they want to return to some of that. I wanted to bring some of that urban-ness into the suburbs."

A New Frontier for Chains
Towns like Westfield have also become the new frontier for national chain retailers usually found in malls. Westfield has a Gap, FootLocker, Victoria's Secret, and a Banana Republic. The Secaucus retailer Children's Place is scheduled to open there as well.
Mr. Spector who fought bitterly against a mall proposed near downtown Westfield 20 years ago, welcomes the chains, which he said lure shoppers to town from well beyond Westfield.
"We have local people who feel the national chains are a negative influence," he said. "My response is that is a misconception. When I was growing up, Westfield was always a regional center for larger stores. The only difference is the names and the nature of the businesses have changed."
When the current caution -- and the tightening of the purse strings -- will ease is difficult to predict. "Some resolution of the situation in Iraq and a sense that the stock market has hit bottom will help people start to regain their confidence," said Barbara Bickart, associate professor of marketing at Rutgers' School of Business in Camden and a specialist in consumer behavior.
The November elections, she said, may begin to provide some resolution.
For his part, Mr. Barnard, who has tracked retailing since the 1950's, said the current cycle was as complex as any he had ever confronted.
"This is an extraordinary cycle because it includes the possibility of war," he said. "That's a loose cannon. Plus, we are still carrying with us the scars of 9/11, and 9/11 has impinged very deep on the fabric of our economy and our psyche, more than anything I can ever recall."
As Professor Bickart said, the wounds from the attacks of Sept. 11 -- especially among New Jerseyans -- were still raw, and emotion may be driving spending patterns along with more rational concerns over unemployment and stock market losses.
"Especially among younger people," she said, "the days of extravagant spending are out. Conspicuous consumption is not so cool anymore."

HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE LIFE; 
His Job: Chasing Wall Street Deadbeats

BYLINE:  By THOM WEIDLICH

 BODY:
MICHAEL S. COLOMBO is a debt collector, but not one who goes after small fry -- people who refuse to pay for their magazine subscriptions or for credit-card charges that have gotten out of hand. Instead, he pursues stockbrokers and investors who owe money on loans or margin calls. And he does this through the art of firm persuasion.
Mr. Colombo, 40, is in the business of getting people to pay the money they owe brokerage firms and investment banks. For more than 15 years, he did this work for three companies in-house, starting in 1983 at PaineWebber. 
 A year and a half ago, he opened his own collection shop, the StreetWide Asset Recovery Group in Manhattan, with backing from the Firebrand Financial Group. 
 Mr. Colombo goes after stockbrokers who leave their companies still owing them money and investors who overextend themselves on margin and can't pay up. Given the state of the economy, he is a very busy man these days. He has contracts with 17 financial institutions, including Berry-Shino Securities, InvestPrivate and J. P. Turner & Company, and he oversees some 300 cases at a time. He receives a percentage of what he recovers.
In the past, many firms either wrote off this debt as a lost cause or assigned its collection to a lawyer, who rarely made it a priority. Mr. Colombo, on the other hand, focuses on these obligations like a pit bull.
"This is what I do," he said. "I know the players. I know the system. I know the collection laws." He estimates that in 19 years, he has recovered more than $45 million, once recouping $1 million in one shot. His biggest single collection so far at StreetWide has been $400,000.
Wall Street is taking notice: this year, he was profiled in Registered Rep, a stockbrokers trade magazine.
Brokers may owe money to their former employers because of loans they took out as new hires. Brokerage houses typically forgive these loans in stages over several years, but if the broker leaves before the contract is up, he owes the balance. Not all are eager to pay up.
Mr. Colombo says brokers sometimes argue that they are off the hook because, after all, the company didn't give them everything it promised.
"The bottom line is -- and I tell brokers this all the time -- if you had a problem with the firm you went to, God bless you if you want to go to another one," he said. "But you don't get to keep the money. You signed a promissory note and you promised to pay."
If that doesn't work, the two parties go to arbitration before the National Association of Securities Dealers. Mr. Colombo handles that work until the actual hearing, when a lawyer has to take over. He says that only about one-quarter of the cases go that far.
"Mike's excellent at this," said Edward Rose, director for litigation at Investec Ernst & Company in Manhattan, one of StreetWide's clients. "He has the approach of a collection firm, but he has the business background. If you went to a standard collection firm, I don't think they'd understand the nuances of how these debts are created."
Mr. Colombo tells of a recent case in which, a month before a broker was going to leave his midsize firm owing $80,000, he put his house into his wife's name to shield it from any judgment. Instead of first pursuing the broker, Mr. Colombo subpoenaed the wife. That was enough to make her husband deal with his financial obligation, he says.
SOME targets are far from Wall Street. About a year ago, Mr. Colombo said, one client gave him a case in Alabama involving a customer who had run up margin debt of $17,000. When the customer refused to pay even after losing in arbitration, Mr. Colombo hired an Alabama lawyer to get a court judgment. The man eventually wrote a check for the amount owed plus interest.
Sometimes, the situation is messier. Mr. Colombo recalls a case while he was collecting in-house. A customer told his broker he wanted to sell short 11,000 shares of eBay.
"But the market went against him and we had to buy the position at a loss of $397,000," he said.
The client never paid up, and the fact that the trade was made in the name of a shell company made it difficult to go after him, Mr. Colombo said. But he was eventually able to win back the debt plus interest and legal fees.
"I had a lawyer write me a three-page memo on why it was uncollectable, but I don't really take that very well," Mr. Colombo said.
Karen M. Cullen hired StreetWide when she was general counsel of Prime Charter Ltd., a New York broker-dealer that was absorbed by Fahnestock Viner Holdings of Toronto. The fee was money well spent, Ms. Cullen said.
"Within a couple of months of hiring Mike, he already collected more than we ever had before," she said.
Mr. Colombo is from Brooklyn, but moved to New Jersey in his teens. He got into the business after leaving college and taking a clerk's job in the new collection department at PaineWebber. He rose to divisional vice president and left in 1996 to create a collections department at Gruntal & Company. In 1998, he went to the GKN Securities Corporation, where, he said, he increased collection revenue from $12,000 to $5 million over two years.
Mr. Colombo said that as his reputation grew, and as firms began asking him for advice on collecting their debt, he decided to pursue an old dream of working for himself. Firebrand Financial, which owns GKN, provided initial funds for StreetWide and owns 80 percent of it.
Does he ever feel sorry for the brokers he goes after?
"I'll be the first guy to say that it's tough for brokers right now," he said. Even so, the biggest concession he will make is to work out a payment plan with those who owe his clients money. 
"Of course, the knee-jerk reaction to a collection agency calling up is very guarded, or 'Go take a walk, I'm not paying,' yadda yadda yadda," he said. "I say: 'Listen, I'm not calling to argue with you. This is what you owe.' Sooner or later they'll get the message."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael S. Colombo, chief of the StreetWide Asset Recovery Group, collects money owed by investors and brokers to Wall Street firms. (Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Village Is More Global, Language Is More Vital 

BYLINE:  By MARCIN SKOMIAL

 BODY:
GNIESZKA OSSOLINSKA-JASKOWSKI didn't have work experience in the legal field. She didn't have any important contacts in the legal business. And she didn't yet have a diploma from Montclair State University in New Jersey, where where she was studying to be a paralegal.
 What she did have was fluency in Polish. And that was enough to get her a job at Brand, Brand & Burke, a personal-injury law firm in Manhattan. 
 "I thought I was at a disadvantage because I had been in the United States only for a couple of years at the time," said Mrs. Jaskowski, who is 29. "But my Polish background actually gave me an edge."
Brand, Brand & Burke, in fact, had recently begun a push to win more clients in New York's growing Polish population, and had placed an ad in Nowy Dziennik, the city's biggest-circulation Polish-language newspaper, specifying mastery of Polish as a requirement for a new position as a liaison with Poles.
Mrs. Jaskowski's familiarity with legal issues helped her candidacy, the firm says, but it was her bilingualism that clinched the job.
"A few years ago, the Polish community was underserved by the legal profession, so we decided to hire a few employees who could speak Polish," said Ronald Burke, a partner at the firm. "We were open to hiring a native speaker of English with fluency in Polish, but we preferred an immigrant who would be more sensitive to the needs of other immigrants. Agnes never worked as paralegal before, but we thought that she would rise to the occasion with on-the-job training."
In the current stumbling economy, job seekers are leveraging every qualification they can think of to sway potential employers. And with immigrants continuing to flood into New York, long the city of immigrants, and its suburbs, speaking a second language is a talent that matters in almost any field.
Take nursing. The hiring managers at the Presbyterian Hospital in New York, which employs people from 88 countries, say they consider mastery of a foreign tongue a strong plus. "The closer you get to delivery of care, the more critical is a second language," said G. Thomas Ferguson, senior vice president and chief of human resources. "A nurse who can talk to a patient in a native language is very important."
It helped Merari Sanchez-Vega get her job there three years ago. Ms. Sanchez-Vega, a registered nurse who was born in the United States but whose parents immigrated from Puerto Rico, is the only nurse of 18 on her floor who can speak Spanish. And even though most Hispanics who are admitted speak English, they feel more at ease when she talks to them in Spanish, she says. "It is their primary language, so they naturally prefer to use it rather than English," Ms. Sanchez-Vega said.
In New York, real estate is another field in which it helps to have multilinguists on the payroll, especially at firms active in neighborhoods with large ethnic populations.
"I'm hiring from different language groups because we are serving customers of many nationalities who sometimes can't speak English," said John Mo, president and owner of Century 21 Milestone in Jamaica, Queens. The 62 agents at his firm speak a host of languages that include Spanish, Chinese, Russian, Urdu and Italian, he says. 
Mr. Mo, who himself immigrated from Hong Kong, said many of his customers were newcomers to America who spoke little or no English. About a month ago, a Hispanic couple came to his office, and though they couldn't understand English, kept repeating the phrase, "We want sell home."
"I looked around, but it was late in the day and everyone was in the field," Mr. Mo said. He ended up paging one of his Spanish-speaking agents and summoning him to the office.
In the global economy, American companies increasingly are realizing the benefits of a multilingual work force. Mark Levit, a managing partner at Partners & Levit, a Manhattan advertising agency, says that while the firm has overseas clients and creates ads aimed at specific ethnic groups in the United States, his only requirement for hiring a bookkeeper used to be accounting skills.
Then, one day, his bookkeeper, a Russian woman, told him that in her view a Russian translation that she had seen of a Partners & Levit brochure was better than the original. That and other incidents, he says, convinced him that a familiarity with a foreign tongue would be an asset in any employee. "In the future, we are planning to make a second language a hiring criterion because we realized that it is so useful," Mr. Levit said.
Mrs. Jaskowski, who immigrated to the United States in 1997 and started as a teacher of Polish at a weekend school in New Jersey, got the job at Brand, Brand & Burke two and a half years ago. Her knowledge of the law was increasing but still deficient, she said, and her new employer started her off slowly, letting her pick up her new duties at her own pace.
"They spent a lot of time just showing me how to do things," she said. "At first, my job was sort of like an extension of school."
Early on, the pay was low, but the fact that she was gaining experience at a personal-injury law firm at a time when some of her classmates in the paralegal certification program at Montclair had not yet started looking for a job was more important to her than money.
During the first few months, she acted more as an intermediary for the lawyers in the office and their Polish-speaking clients than a full-fledged paralegal. Her tasks included informing Polish clients about the status of their cases and translating documents. She even went along with some clients to the doctor's office, serving as a translator.
After a year, however, Mrs. Jaskowski's job started gaining new dimensions. Although her main focus remains working with Polish clients, her additional tasks, like making drafts of legal papers, require a greater understanding of the legal system. Mrs. Jaskowski is also responsible for deciding whether a case is good enough for the firm to pursue -- and that means she has to make trips to accident sites. "It takes some patience to do this work when I have a crowd of people staring at me and wondering who I am and why I do it," she said.
There is other work, too. Mrs. Jaskowski arranges advertising in Polish media and attends events sponsored by her firm in Polish neighborhoods. When the residents see her in a business suit, she says, "It makes them rethink the image of a typical Polish nanny and a construction worker."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Agnieszka Ossolinska-Jaskowski is a legal assistant for Brand, Brand & Burke. (Matt Moyer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: LIFE'S WORK; 
Do Women Lack Drive? Or a Wife?

BYLINE:  By LISA BELKIN; This column about the intersection of jobs and personal lives appears every other week. E-mail: Belkin@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
FIRST, meet Kate Reddy, a high-powered, ambitious achiever, who is also conflicted, exhausted and stressed. She is the mother of two, and when we first see her she is in the kitchen (at 1:30 a.m.) beating store-bought pastries with a rolling pin to make them look homemade for the school Christmas party.
 Next, meet Dawn Lepore, also high-powered and achieving, but only mildly conflicted about it. She also has two children, and when I last saw her she was dining on glazed chicken prepared by her husband, Ken, who stays home and runs their life. 
 Kate Reddy, I should explain, is a fiction -- she's the heroine of "I Don't Know How She Does It" (Knopf, 2002), the book every working woman is likely to devour within the next few weeks. The novel, by the British writer Allison Pearson, is a sensation in England. It is a hysterical look -- in both the laughing and crying senses of the word -- at the life of Supermom as she tries to be both a mother and a financial whiz.
Dawn Lepore, on the other hand, is very real. She is the vice chairwoman of Charles Schwab in San Francisco, and one of Fortune Magazine's 50 most powerful women. One third of those 50 have husbands who stay home with the children, and Ms. Lepore is a member of that club, too.
It has long been an open secret of the business stratosphere that couples, particularly couples with children, do not get to the top together. Someone -- traditionally the wife -- stays a few supportive steps behind. Against that background, Ms. Pearson's book and Fortune magazine's statistics provide two opposing answers to a central question: Are there so few women at the top because women don't have the drive? Or is it because they don't have wives?
Ms. Pearson suggests that it's often the former. Women are talented and educated enough to run the world, she says, they just aren't willing to give up all that is required to master the universe. Her book was born when she read a survey that found that working mothers were constantly starved for time and felt they were neglecting their husbands, their children and themselves. This makes women different from men mostly because the women care. Successful men don't have time for their families either, Ms. Pearson argues, but for generations that has not really bothered them.
Women, she says, are just programmed differently. "They carry the puzzle of family life in their heads," she says. "When a man is walking into a client meeting, he is not also going to be thinking, 'Did I buy the right gym shoes for the playground? Did I get the lace-up kind or the pull-on kind? And did I take the lasagna out to defrost?' "
"I live with a very evolved man," she says of her husband, the New Yorker writer Anthony Lane, "and it would not occur to him to wonder whether it is time to go buy more paper towels. I don't know where he thinks they come from."
In the end -- warning: I'm giving away the plot line here -- Kate Reddy gives up her job as a fund manager and moves to the country for a simpler life (where she finds a small factory in big economic trouble and can't resist the challenge of turning its finances around). "That might not be the ending that some people might have preferred," she says, "but if I made her live happily ever after while staying in that job, it would have been a fairy tale."
Instead, Ms. Pearson says, the Kate Reddys of the world are doing what her character eventually does -- finding ways to work on their own terms. "Women are rejecting the corporate world and starting their own businesses," she says. "They work just as hard, but if they have to duck out because the hamster dropped down off the back of the couch and they have to sneak home a new one that looks just like the old one, that won't be seen as frivolous."
The Fortune numbers, however, hint that while this may be true of many, or even most, women, it is not true of all, and those who have reversed the equation are beginning to say so aloud. About three years ago, I tried to write about the phenomenon of highly successful women with stay-at-home husbands, and Ms. Lepore was the only person willing to talk for publication. 
Relying on one spouse to look after the home front while the other advances at work is the way men have been doing things for years. And maybe in an ideal world, we decided over her husband's delectable dinner, every partnership would include one who preferred to be home and one who preferred the office, regardless of sex.
Yes, she said, she'd felt pangs of regret, knowing her husband had the luxury of down time with the children whereas she often sandwiched that into a crowded schedule. But, she added, "knowing Ken is home doing what he does makes me comfortable being where I am doing what I'm doing."
In other words, everybody needs a wife.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
With Land Scarce, Million-Dollar Condos Flourish

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
WHEN a rare patch of vacant land appears in Fairfield County's upscale towns or a few parcels seem ripe for cobbling together, usually by knocking down a building or two, it is likely that a new condominium project will soon rise, with units starting at $1 million and selling like ice cream in August.
 Lately, the right elements for high-priced condos have come together in several parts of the county: small scraps of land unsuitable for much of anything else, interest rates at a seductive low, the wealthy older crowd wanting to get the cumbersome mansions off their backs, the two-income couple in Manhattan seeking an impeccable address but unable to afford a multimillion-dollar house. 
 Park Slope, an archetypical high-end 13-unit complex nearing completion on 1.1 acres, was formed from four parcels in New Canaan overlooking the lake in Meade Park. With units listed at $1 million to $1.5 million, it is within a block of the train station and one to three blocks from shopping, restaurants, movies, Town Hall, the library and a post office; and it is a child's bike ride from South Street Elementary School. 
Meade Park is a town-owned bonus for Park Slope residents. Covering 28 acres, it has eight tennis courts, a large baseball field, two lighted Little League fields, a playground, horseshoe pits and a lake with ducks and an occasional blue heron. 
Developed by the Fieber Group, Park Slope is indicative of a trend toward putting such enclaves in downtown neighborhoods of upscale towns, satisfying a demand for urban convenience mixed with suburban haut monde. Five units have sold or are under contract since sales opened in June. One buyer invested an additional $250,000 in customizing, $150,000 of it in media systems that include five plasma television screens (one over the master bathtub). "Buyers," said James Fieber, managing director of the company, "are paying cash. So far there are no mortgage contingencies."
These are hardly the condominiums of 15 years ago, when bare-bones units were a stopover on the way to a house or were considered a hot investment as rental property. When the economy slumped, rose and slumped again, the units often wound up worth less than their mortgages.
"Condos picked up a bad rap," said Barry Rosen, director of new homes and land at Prudential Connecticut, "but they have been strong for more than two years now, with the rate of sales outpacing single family homes. They appreciate like single family homes and that makes them a good investment, but investors are not about to buy a million dollar condo in New Canaan and then rent it out. People who buy them live in them." 
With the high-end market driven by a generation of active or retired older people scaling down from large homes, developers are responding to buyers who choose to stay in the same area, maintaining social and business connections. They still want large, luxurious, conservatively styled homes and quality construction that holds its value. So condos must replicate as much as possible the ambience the buyers are leaving behind.
THE 13 Park Slope units are in five buildings: two free-standing houses, two buildings with three units each and one five-unit building. All units have large center halls with mahogany-railed stairways and archways embellished with detailed wood moldings that offer views into the living and dining rooms, wainscoting throughout the first floor, high ceilings, Italian marble fireplace surrounds and marble master bathrooms, equipped with spa tubs and stall steam showers. (Two additional bedrooms and bath are slightly less luxurious.) 
Each 3,500-square-feet unit also has woodwork details on mantels, a mahogany-paneled library, an enormous walkout family room, a laundry room, mahogany-paneled elevator and a maid's suite with walk-in closet and bath. 
Other desirable characteristics include maintenance-free landscaping; large rooms accommodating lifelong acquisitions of furniture, antiques, books and paintings; an optional home office or exercise room; and a spacious kitchen equipped with prodigious cabinetry, granite countertops and Viking appliances. 
Joanne Carroll, publisher of Connecticut Builder magazine and past president of the Fairfield County Home Builders Association, noted, "Some builders who had not been doing condos for a while are back doing them, because land is at such a premium you can get more housing on less land by doing small lot detached or attached housing, and they are appreciating at a faster rate than single-family homes."
Park Slope is a third generation project of the Fieber Group, a family company founded by Sol Fieber, a general contractor in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens early in the 20th century. Carried on by his son Norman Fieber, who moved the business to Stamford 30 years ago, it is now run by Norman's three sons: James, 48, managing director; Robert, 46; and William, 42.
They are currently developing plans for a 59-unit complex of million dollar-plus condos on Long Ridge Road in Stamford, on a 30-acre tract their father bought 30 years ago. In partnership with Steve Hoffman, who sold the Hoffman family's Stamford fuel business to Chevron, and Clay Fowler, a well-known Stamford developer, the Fiebers will submit their proposal to the city's planning and zoning boards in December or January.
Among several other developers focusing on Fairfield County's high-end condo market, Jerry Effren opened sales on 2,000-square-foot units on Hamilton Avenue in Greenwich in April, and 15 of the 16 units have been sold. Priced from $800,000 to just under $1 million, they have attracted mostly city-oriented commuters who can walk to the train station and downtown Greenwich and who regard the location, tucked into a street lined with modest 1930's two-family homes, as a nonissue. He expects to open a similar 16-unit complex in six buildings on LeGrand Avenue in Greenwich next spring, starting at $875,000. 
Spectrum Skanska of Valhalla, Westchester County, and Sterling Properties of Livingston, N.J., have joined to build a gated community in Westport to be called Terra Nova. The vacant 15-acre property is on Route 1 at the Norwalk border and is "all rock," according to Mitchell C. Hochberg, chief executive of Spectrum Skanska, a unit of Skanska, a Swedish company. 
The project, an attached town house complex of 54 units measuring 1,800 to 3,000 square feet in 16 buildings, will be geared for empty-nesters. With starting prices in the mid-$700,000's, the units will offer ground-floor master suites, lavishly equipped kitchens, two and three bedrooms, two-car garages and walk-out basements, which can be finished at extra cost as home theaters, offices or other uses. Like most of the new developments meant for older adults, each unit will have an elevator. 
Terra Nova will also have a private outdoor pool and cabana. A sales office will open at 190 Main Street in downtown Westport next month.
The Danbury office of the Ginsburg Development Companies of Westchester, whose principal business is creating condominium communities, has been building in Connecticut in the midprice range. Redding Woods is a completed enclave of 23 free-standing condominiums in Redding, and Woodland Hills in Danbury will eventually contain 252 condominium homes of 1,400 to more than 3,000 square feet in 81 buildings. More than 90 units have been sold, with 70 to be occupied this year. Prices range from the high $200,000's to $400,000 without options, and some buyers have been investing up to $40,000 for extras. The company recently received approval for 92 units in Newtown, restricted to households in which one member is 55 or older.
Other Fairfield County towns that would seem appropriate for million dollar condominiums, including Darien and Wilton, have them, but because of zoning restrictions and lack of available land no new projects have been built for at least five years, according to planning and zoning officials.
The concept of million dollar condo complexes was born in Greenwich in 1989, when Johnson Lee, who had been building homes for Fortune 500 executives in Fairfield County for years, sensed a new high-end market for condominiums among Greenwich's wealthy older residents seeking a simpler lifestyle and freedom from home maintenance. He built an elegant project called Waterford overlooking Cos Cob Harbor and astonished the real estate community by charging $1.5 million and more per unit when the market high was about $500,000. He had breached the million dollar mark in the state for the first time. 
There is now a waiting list of potential buyers for Waterford's 24 units. One three-bedroom unit of 3,500 square feet is on the market for $2.695 million.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The 13 homes at Park Slope in New Canaan, complete with elevators, will cost $1 million to $1.5 million. (Photographs by George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THEATER; 
In the Scuffed Shoes Of Women Scraping By

BYLINE:  By MARC WEINGARTEN; Marc Weingarten writes about popular culture for Entertainment Weekly and Slate.com.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
THE stage adaptation of "Nickel and Dimed" begins with a frantic whoosh of coffee shop bustle, as uniformed waitresses sprint from table to table, barking out orders and quips.
 At first, this frenetic tableau looks like a remake of the old Linda Lavin sitcom, "Alice." One of the characters even has the temerity to tell a co-worker to "kiss my sticky buns." For those readers who have made Barbara Ehrenreich's book from last year, "Nickel and Dimed: On (Not) Getting By in America" (Metropolitan/Holt), a best seller, that light-hearted scene might strike a discordant note. Is this the same "Nickel and Dimed" that turned an empathetic eye and ear to the lives of women on the lowest rung of the socio-economic ladder? 
 But the episode is just a sly feint, a diversion before the devastation sets in. What finally emerges from Joan Holden's adaptation of Ms. Ehrenreich's first-person account of the working poor is an examination of the lives of women who were shoe-horned into the labor market in 1998, post-welfare reform -- a number that exceeds four million.
Directed by Bartlett Sher, the artistic head of the Intiman Theater in Seattle, where the play originated, "Nickel and Dimed" is currently playing, through Oct. 26, at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, where it has generally received positive reviews. The Los Angeles Times praised Ms. Holden for her faithful adaptation, which "softens the agitprop by taking nonpolitical pleasure in a wide range of human behavior on view," while The Hollywood Reporter found the book's "interplay of irony, humor and desperation" present and accounted for in the play. (A separate production will be presented by the Trinity Repertory Company in Providence, R.I., from Jan. 31 through March 9.) 
At first blush, the book would seem a poor candidate for theatrical treatment. In 1998 Ms. Ehrenreich, a well-known essayist and social critic who was on assignment for Harper's Magazine, went under cover without middle-class appurtenances -- no cell phone or 401K, just some clothes and a little start-up money -- to see if she could survive as a member of the working poor. She toiled as a waitress in Florida, cleaned houses in Maine and clerked at a Wal-Mart in Minnesota. Along the way, she encountered women living quietly desperate lives as they tried to scrape together enough to eat and provide a roof, any roof, over their own and their children's heads. From her experiences emerged the Harper's article, and the book, which was published in May 2001. 
It is hardly the stuff of a feel-good commercial hit. Even the author was skeptical about a theatrical production. "I don't know much about theater," Ms. Ehrenreich said from her home in Key West, Fla. "It sounded a little flaky to me. I couldn't imagine how anyone would make the book a play."
But Mr. Sher was convinced that "Nickel and Dimed" would resonate with the same theatergoers who made, say, "Mamma Mia!" a blockbuster. His epiphany came one day while driving to work. "I heard Barbara Ehrenreich talking about the book on NPR one morning, and it basically turned my head inside out," Mr. Sher said. "As an artistic director, so much of my time is spent courting wealthy donors, and here was this women telling me that the working poor subsidize our lives. It was a breakout idea for me."
A native of San Francisco, Mr. Sher called Joan Holden, whose original productions for the San Francisco Mime Troupe over 30 years blended fanciful artifice with socially conscious subjects. Ms. Holden, who is also a translator of playful social critics like Dario Fo and Moliere, seemed the ideal writer to transform Ms. Ehrenreich's working-class picaresque into something that would entertain yet still prick the prejudices of middle class audiences. 
Ms. Ehrenreich's caustic narrative voice seemed ideally suited for the stage, and much of the play's dialogue is lifted from the book. The set pieces that make up the three acts are loosely connected by monologues provided by the Ehrenreich character, played by Sharon Lockwood, a Mime Troupe veteran.
But for Ms. Holden and Mr. Sher, having Ms. Ehrenreich comment on the action was not enough. The author had to become engaged, to endure the hardships as she chronicled them. For the Taper production, Ms. Holden took her cue from the Seattle critics. They had felt the play did a poor job of making the Ehrenreich character theatrically dramatic, so she emphasized Ms. Ehrenreich's internal conflict between dispassionate objectivity and moral outrage.
"There is always the problem, in plays and in the movies, of the reporter being a detached observer," Ms. Holden said. "The reporter is essentially a witness, and the motivational drive isn't that compelling. But what I found, in reading the book, is that there are many allusions to Barbara's working-class forebears. She is doing it for her ancestors. Elite education and privilege have not made her blood run thin."
In the play, Ms. Ehrenreich's simmering indignation slowly rises to the surface. During the second act, while toiling for a housecleaning service, she tries to organize a work stoppage when her supervisor, played by Kristin Flanders, injures her foot on the job. By the third act, Ms. Ehrenreich, fatigued and beaten down by her job as a retail clerk, realizes the limits of her good intentions. Homeless and nearly broke, she walks back into her real life just before falling off the precipice of her invented one. 
According to Gordon Davidson, the artistic director of the Mark Taper Forum, Ms. Ehrenreich's emotional journey is the play's crucial connective tissue. "That was something Joan wanted to work on in Seattle before the play came to L.A., and I encouraged her," Mr. Davidson said. "Barbara's perspective had to be sharpened."
Ms. Ehrenreich's anxious sense of cultural dislocation is mirrored by Mr. Sher's kinetic staging, in which perpetually moving bodies seem to be mortally afraid of what repose might to do their weekly wages. To hear Mr. Sher tell it, his direction of "Nickel and Dimed" was influenced by Pina Bausch and "I Love Lucy," with a dash of Kafka's "Trial" thrown in for good measure. 
Despite the harsh lessons the Ehrenreich character learns about the struggles of the working poor, it is unclear if audiences will care enough to give the play's issues much thought once the house lights are turned on.
"I think most people who see it will not organize living-wage campaigns," Ms. Holden said. "But I can't see how it will not make them stop to consider the working poor. Plus, if it makes people a better tipper and they pay their cleaning ladies more, that's accomplishing something."

Nickel and Dimed
Mark Taper Forum, Los Angeles.
Through Oct. 26.

Sharon Lockwood, at left, portrays the author, who held a series of minimum-wage jobs. (Ryan Miller/Capture Imaging); (Craig Schwartz)

HEADLINE: Festival's Highlights Tinged With Unease 

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN

 BODY:
FOLLOWING on the heels of better-known events in Toronto, Telluride, Colo., and New York, the Hamptons International Film Festival, now in its 10th year, has always had a hard time snagging splashy premieres or grabbing headlines. With the debut in May of the heavily publicized TriBeCa film festival, the competition for intriguing discoveries has become even more intense.
 Unlike the Sundance and TriBeCa festivals, the Hamptons festival does not have a Redford or a DeNiro to give it high visibility. But despite its relatively low profile, the festival, which runs from Wednesday through Sunday, seems to have no trouble attracting audiences, drawing heavily from the East End's population of second-home owners. Last year, 22,000 tickets were sold, said Denise Kasell, the executive director of the festival. 
 Ms. Kasell said that many of the 70 feature films this year had a common thread. "They are serious films that are intellectually challenging," she said. "They deal with issues we might find a little uncomfortable, but they are in no way sensational." 
The festival opens with "Rabbit-Proof Fence," a drama by Philip Noyce about the forced relocation of aboriginal children in Australia. It closes with a German hit, "Nowhere in Africa," that tells the story of a family that emigrates to Kenya to escape the Nazis.
The Films of Conflict and Resolution series also deals with weighty themes, with documentaries about the threat of nuclear war between India and Pakistan, genocide in Rwanda, hunger strikes in Northern Ireland and the role of personal video recorders in exposing human-rights abuses. "Secret Lives: Hidden Children and Their Rescuers," by the Oscar-winning filmmaker Aviva Slesin, focuses on people who risked their lives to shelter Jewish children during the Holocaust.
For those who want a break from such sober subject matter, there will be a lot of other choices. Among the films vying for the annual Golden Starfish award is "Kiss the Bride," a comedy by Vanessa Parise. The View from Long Island category, films by local filmmakers, will feature "You Stupid Man," a romantic comedy directed by Brian Burns and starring Milla Jovovich. Another in that series is "The Real Hamptons," Jeff Dell's response to the recent nationally televised documentary that enraged local residents.
The films were selected by Rajendra Roy, the new programming director, who was previously the manager of the film and media arts program at the Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan. Bringing in Mr. Roy, 30, and adding programs at Southampton College's Avram Theater represent an attempt to broaden the festival's appeal to younger filmgoers, said Stuart Match Suna, the festival chairman and the president of Silvercup Studios in Queens. 
Films will also be shown at the United Artists Theaters in East Hampton, the Sag Harbor Cinema and the Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center.
In past years, some festivalgoers have complained that the theaters were too spread out, making it hard to schmooze between films. This year a tent will be set up on Main Street in East Hampton to serve as a gathering point, Mr. Roy said. Eugene Hernandez, editor-in-chief of Indie Wire (www.indiewire.com), an online daily newsletter, will lead a discussion each afternoon.
Begun in 1993 as a memorial to the Time Warner chairman Steven J. Ross, the Hamptons festival has always had two goals: to showcase independent films and to give a post-season lift to local businesses.
"It's very good for our economy," said Marina Van, the executive director of the East Hampton Chamber of Commerce.
Some people in Hollywood dismiss the Hamptons festival as local boosterism that lacks both cachet and artistic merit. But Tom Bernard, the co-president of Sony Pictures Classics, places it in the second tier of festivals, on a par with those in Chicago; Seattle; Santa Barbara, Calif.; and Miami. "If you put your movie there," said Mr. Bernard, "you're going to get name awareness." 
Sony Pictures Classics' "Love Liza," starring Philip Seymour Hoffman, will have its East Coast premiere at the festival on Saturday. "We felt there are a lot of Academy members out there," said Mr. Bernard. "It's a way to kick off an Oscar campaign."
"Love Liza" is one of this year's hot tickets, Ms. Kasell said. Other films that were selling out quickly included "The Safety of Objects," starring Glenn Close; "Roger Dodger," with Campbell Scott and Isabella Rossellini; and "Ripley's Game," based on a novel in a series by Patricia Highsmith.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Films in the Hamptons International Film Festival include, clockwise from above, "The Real Hamptons," "Love Liza" and "You Stupid Man."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Office Vacancies Continue in Rise in Parsippany

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

DATELINE: PARSIPPANY 

 BODY:
THE commercial real estate market in New Jersey continues to "reach for new depths," according to Cushman & Wakefield's third-quarter report, and Parsippany is a perfect example of some unfortunate trends. On the other hand, this city -- northern New Jersey's third-largest submarket -- exhibits qualities that experts say position it well for a rebound, including excellent highway access, diverse kinds of commercial space and no overbuilding. 
 Sales of commercial property to investors continued at a good pace, even as vacancy rates continued to rise. The vacancy rate for commercial space went up 22 percent in Parsippany during the third quarter, compared with 19.2 percent one year earlier, C.& W. reported, and for all of northern New Jersey, the vacancy rate rose to 15.8 percent from 12 percent the year before. In central New Jersey vacancies reached 20 percent for the first time since 1995. Statewide, the rate is 17.9 percent, compared with 12.4 percent 12 months ago. 
 The highest vacancy rate by far is in Franklin Township, where AT&T and Merrill Lynch moved out and put large blocks of space on the market. The town's vacancy rate, 42.4 percent, is more than double the rate of 16.9 percent at the same point of 2001.
A plethora of space available for sublease continues to inflate vacancy rates -- in Parsippany, in Franklin and statewide. This is a result of the wave of corporate downsizing and consolidation and also the unprecedented quantities of space that were put on the market after Sept. 11, 2001, to meet an expected heavy demand that never materizalized, market specialists say. 
In Parsippany, 45 percent of the commercial space on the market is sublease space. The Hudson waterfront and Newark real estate submarkets are larger, but Parsippany has the most sublease space available, 1.17 million square feet, C.& W. said.
The two biggest spaces available in Parsippany are the 317,000-square-foot office at 5 Wood Hollow Drive that American Express occupied temporarily after Sept. 11 and 270,000 square feet at Morris Corporate Center IV leased long term to Aventis.
Aventis moved out of Parsippany more than a year ago. The company recently announced it would reoccupy 70,000 square feet at Morris Corporate Center. But the 270,000-square-foot block of space is being kept on the market for sublease.
The Morris Corporate Center has the most available space currently on the market, C.& W. reported, and it noted that new blocks have also opened up at the Mack-Cali Business Park and the Waterview Corporate Center. On the other hand, a total of 900,000 square feet has been leased in Parsippany so far this year.
While the uncertain economic climate has led many companies to hold off on planning to take more space, according to brokers around New Jersey, some deals have been made in Parsippany. Cendant expanded within the Mack-Cali Business Park at 7 Sylvan Way, taking 145,983 additional square feet. VoiceStream leased 106,000 square feet at 4 Sylvan Way to consolidate operations, and EchoStar Satellite took 67,000 square feet at the Montville East Corporate Center. At 1633 Littleton Road, the engineering firm Sardoni Skanska sublet the entire 52,000-square-foot building from ConAgra.
Still, the pace of leasing is far from what it was in the boom times before the current economic slowdown, said C.& W.'s Dennis McDonnell. However, he added, "It is not that far off the one million square feet leased annually in Parsippany during the period 1991-1996.Mr. McDonnell, a senior director who works in the company's Parsippany offices, described conditions in that time period as comparable to this one.
"I believe that the current activity level is a positive sign that the market still has the basic components it needs to survive," Mr. McDonnell said. "I remember in '91," he continued, "the slogan was, 'Survive Till '95.' Now, I guess the question is, 'What are we looking to survive till?' "
DESPITE the high vacancy rates, asking rentals have not declined significantly, he noted. The asking rate per square foot for Class A office space here remains about $30, among the highest in northern New Jersey.
Only one new office building is under construction in Parsippany. Ground was broken in the summer for a new 45,000-square-foot building at the Parsippany Crossroads Office Center. On the Hudson waterfront, by contrast, the vacancy rate nearly tripled in the third quarter because almost 650,000 square feet at newly constructed buildings at the Harborside office complex came on the market.
As for sales of commercial property in Parsippany, the market remains stubbornly healthy, as is generally the case in New Jersey -- particularly for buildings leased for five years or longer.
Earlier this year, Deutsche Bank bought One Campus Drive, the 377,000-square-foot building where Cendant has its headquarters, for $81.1 million, and the 280,000-square-foot Lanidex Plaza office center changed hands for $27.6 million.
Last month, TA Associates acquired a 100,348-square-foot office building at 339 Jefferson Road from Crow Holdings for $15.3 million. 
And earlier this month, Gatehall II, part of the Gatehall Corporate Center complex, was sold for $101.4 million in one of the largest suburban office deals this year. The 404,517-square-foot office building is fully leased, long term, to two stable tenants: the KeyBank Corporation and Gemini Technology Services, a division of Deutsche Bank.
CB Richard Ellis brokered the sale of the building, which had been owned as a joint venture by Morgan Stanley and the Gale Company, to Wells Operating Partnership. Jeffrey Dunne of CB Richard Ellis, who handled the sale, said, "As we weather the storm, going through this period of high vacancy, low demand, most sales that we see will be like this one" -- with long-term and stable tenants.
Mr. Dunne, an executive vice president with CB Richard Ellis, cited a property currently being marketed by C.& W. -- 200 Kimball Avenue in Parsippany -- as another "transaction that will happen." The sale involves a newly constructed building, 90 percent leased to a division of Novartis Pharmaceuticals for 10 years.
Mr. Dunne said those buying commercial property currently expect a lower yield on their investments, 8 to 8.5 percent, as opposed to 9.5 percent a year ago. "That will be true until interest rates go up, and the return on alternative investments goes up," he said.
Like Mr. McDonnell at C.& W., Mr. Dunne said Parsippany's commercial real estate market would endure and eventually recover. "Look at the geography: the superb highway access; the fact it's in Morris County and has lots of inexpensive housing," he said. "It is going to remain a viable office location."
Situated in the heart of an area with numerous shops, restaurants, hotels and other amenities, Parsippany is near the Interstate 80 and 287 convergence. Routes 46, 10 and 22 are easily accessible.
Mr. McDonnell said Parsippany's market also has diversity in the size and class of its commercial buildings. "The market is not driven by one specific industry," he observed, adding, "I'm a big fan of Parsippany in the long term."

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
It Must Be Picture Day

BYLINE:  By MERRI ROSENBERG

DATELINE: BEDFORD HILLS 

 BODY:
WENDY CROWELL knelt in front of a small girl with a nimbus of ringlets, gently combed stray tendrils into place, and guided her back into the line of other well-scrubbed, dressed-up children here at the Bedford Hills Elementary School.
 With the girls attired in dresses or matching skirt and sweater-sets and shiny black patent Mary Jane shoes, and many of the boys wearing unfamiliar jackets and ties, it was clearly Picture Day. 
 The photographers from Lifetouch -- part camp counselor, part psychologist, and part child wrangler in their efforts to cajole a smile from a shy child, or contain an overly exuberant one -- shepherded each child through a sitting for an individual portrait and the group class photo. P.T.A. parents like Mrs. Crowell, chairwoman of the school's picture committee, moved through the lines of waiting children, fixing hair with disposable combs and adjusting clothing. 
School pictures, which mark a child's time line as much as the pencil marks scratched to mark his or her height on the kitchen wall, are big business. National companies like the Minneapolis-based Lifetouch are seeking market share from local, family-owned companies like Davis Studio in Mamaroneck, Images School Photography in New Rochelle, or Irvin Simon in Elmont, Queens, which, like Davis, also has an extensive regional business. Other national photography companies include Herff Jones Photography Division of Lewiston, Minn., and Inter-State Studio of Sedalia, Mo.
Steve Miller, president of Irvin Simon Photographers, a 56-year-old business founded by his grandfather, said, "We're big enough to be competitive and nimble enough to care."
A smaller business like Images School Photography, however, finds that "it is hard to compete with the national companies," said Joan McGrath, owner of the company, who mostly works with the schools and athletic leagues of New Rochelle.
Since pricing isn't the main source of competition, those who select the photo studios cite other reasons for choosing a national company over a local one. "They're easier to work with," Mrs. Crowell said. "They seem to keep the children under good control."
School pictures embrace the entire spectrum of the school experience, from nursery school to high school proms, along with athletic teams, band programs and dance studio recitals. The photos are offered in more sizes and shapes now, too. In recent years, as more elementary and middle schools have produced school yearbooks, previously the domain of high schools, the school-photo studios have provided images for use in those publications. Many companies also provide CD-Rom's, bar coded photos for school identification cards and other services to the schools. There are items like photo key chains and refrigerator magnet frames, bookmarks and Christmas ornaments, even giant posters of an entire group.
The increased use of digital photography permits more personalization and customized service, with companies like Lifetouch able to offer class photos with each child's name printed on them. 
Although the peak of the school pictures business traditionally takes place between September and December, with the expansion into other kinds of photo opportunities, many photo companies are now busy year round. 
Given the heightened awareness of any business that comes in contact with children, these companies conduct criminal background checks on their photographers. Lifetouch's photographers, who are full-time employees, not freelancers, undergo training sessions on how photographers should work with the students. 
The school picture market, for grades kindergarten through 12, is about $1.5 billion a year, according to Tom Crawford, director of corporate communications at the Professional School Photographer's Association, which is part of Photo Marketing Association International, the trade group based in Jackson, Mich. According to a recent survey by the Photo Marketing Association International, the average school picture package purchase last year was $29 (the average for high school senior photos was $256).
With school picture packages starting about $20 -- most purchases are $20 to $25 -- and going up to about $60 for the full treatment -- photos enough for two sets of grandparents and the extended family -- the market is lucrative. Even an uncertain economy doesn't appear to have much impact. As Steve Smith, the Newburgh-based Lifetouch representative for Westchester, Rockland, Putnam and Orange Counties who works with 65 schools in Westchester, said, "Everybody loves their children."
School pictures, which are generally arranged by P.T.A., committees, are also fund-raisers. Depending on the size of the school and the participation rate, school pictures can generate anywhere from $1,000 to close to $10,000 for a school. The price of the picture packages usually reflects the 20 to 25 percent that the photo companies return to the P.T.A.'s as a fund-raiser.
While elementary and middle schools usually have a better than 90 percent participation rate by families buying picture packages, not surprisingly, the percentage slacks off by high school to about 50 percent. It picks up again for senior year formal portraits and prom pictures.
To help parents whose budgets are already stretched, the Thomas Edison Elementary School in Port Chester recently developed a sibling picture program. If a family's children are all students at the elementary school, parents can opt to have their children photographed together. 
For the schools, picture day is a worthwhile event, despite the distractions and interruptions. "I set up a schedule, but parents are in charge," said Maureen Zygmont, the principal of the Bedford Hills Elementary School. "We combine picture day with dress-up day, and the children come out of class for a very short period of time, and go right back to class, so it's not a big deal."
Even among "too cool for school" teenagers, the disdain with which many high school students view school pictures may be only a pose. 
"This shows how many years you've been in the school," said Bhumica Patel, a 16-year-old junior at Alexander Hamilton High School in Elmsford. "It's important. You want to look good, and see how different you turned out from when you started." 

GRAPHIC: Photos: Sophie Silverman, above, first grader at Bedford Hills Elementary School, getting her picture taken. Zoe Belasco, far left, poses at Bedford Hills. Brandi Evans and other students at Hamilton High School in Elmsford wait to be photographed. (Photographs by Susan Farley for The New York Times)
