HEADLINE: Pond Proud 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON

 BODY:
THERE is something rather God-like about ordaining a body of water to appear on your land. And in creating an Eden-like garden setting where plants and animals will thrive.
 Whether it is a God complex or just good old home-improvement obsession, the craze over garden ponds in the county continues unabated. The pond industry reports a climb in the numbers of homeowners putting in water gardens, defying logical obstacles like drought, West Nile virus warnings and economic downturns. 
 At Shemin's Nursery in Greenwich, a leading seller of aquatic plants, sales have increased over the last two years, said Josh Scruggs, the customer service manager in Shemin's greenhouse. 
Rob Dietter, a Connecticut pond installer who has many clients in Westchester, said, "We have way more business than we can handle."
Mr. Dietter, who owns Dietter's Water Gardens in North Haven, the largest aquatic nursery in Connecticut, said that his pond business had grown 30 percent over last year in sales, installation and maintenance.
"Interest rates are down and people are improving their homes and investing in their backyards," said Mr. Dietter, who is certified as a master of ponds by the National Pond Society.
A garden pond can enhance a property's value, but not always, said Walter Davis, a real estate broker at the Coldwell Banker office in Bedford.
"If you have an acre or more, a nice pond adds grace and charm, and generally adds value to a home," he said. "But if you have a small plot, it can encroach upon your space. It really depends on the perception of the buyer. Someone with young children might avoid it for fear the children could drown, but others might feel it would amuse the kids."
Even the most basic suburban ornamental pond serves as an aquatic chill-out spot. Robert Hayes, 49, of North Salem, has a Jacuzzi-size pond next to his front door. It is a starter pool, 8 by 11 feet and 18 inches deep. It cost about $5,000 to buy and install. It has a natural-looking waterfall, terraced ledges of boulders and underwater lights. He decorated it with a two-foot tall cement pagoda and some stained-glass pink flamingos. There is also a small bench and three slates on the ground with these words engraved: "Live, Laugh, Dream."
Mr. Hayes built the house 17 years ago when his son was a baby. Now the boy is off to college. Mr. Hayes's wife died three years ago in an automobile accident. They always wanted their own waterfall, and he built it in her memory with the insurance money from her accident. Clearing the spot several years ago, he pulled up an azalea bush that he and his wife had planted. He found her wedding ring, which they had long ago given up for lost.
Just the sound of the pond brings him peace, said Mr. Hayes, who repairs and operates industrial boilers for a living. He spends hours puttering around it and sitting near it. He has named his goldfish. There's Petey (a black eye like Little Rascal's dog), Casper (all white) and Michael Jackson ("He's got amazing moves.").
"All you have to do is feed 'em and you're their best friend," Mr. Hayes said. "It's very peaceful. It's like you're in another world." He adjusts the waterfall to be quiet or noisy by shifting the rocks. 
The pond was built by Pete Woytowich, a local landscaper who runs his own pond business, Premier Ponds. Business has really taken off since he started it three years ago, he said, and his pond supply trailer, with its familiar smiling frog on the side, can be seen careering around the bucolic roads of the Salems as he services clients.
As ponds have gotten more popular, pond owners and creators have gotten more discerning. Michael Mushak, a landscape architect in Norwalk who has many clients in Westchester, has become a self-described pond snob, he said, because homeowners tend to hire their landscaper, "who'd be better off sticking to the lawn mower."
"I'm seeing a lot of water gardens now and I rarely see one that is well executed," he said. "You have untrained people who see an easy way to make a buck, but the ponds are failures in terms of design and ecology. They're plopped down in middle of the backyard like they landed from outer space. You have waterfalls in the middle of a mound in the backyard where you'd never expect to see one. People are getting status symbol fountains, and you can't get tackier than that."

Pond Karma
Tom and Dawn Christopher are no pond-design babes in the woods. Their house and gardens has a Japanese look. The previous owner made a Japanese pond garden out of a dried-up river bed outside the front door. There was a flat, simple wood-beam footbridge and a 40-year-old Japonica cedar about four stories tall.
"The space begged for a pond," Ms. Christopher said. 
Mr. Christopher, a painter, has spent time in Japan and studied design there. He and his wife read books on Japanese gardens and architecture, from which they glean the appropriate place for still water versus moving water, or learn that at a curve in a stream, there are better vibes on the inside of the curve.
In their garden, water now falls down a grade into a long, narrow pond. Fish glide in long laps up and downthe river pond. The waterfall runs west to east, a bad thing in the realm of household karma.
"They say you should never have water running west to east, or it releases the dragon into your home," Mr. Christopher said. "I guess we have to live with that."
There's another problem: the pond has attracted snakes, and they are eating the frogs. Recently, a snake ate one whole, right in front of their two sons. So Mr. Christopher took a garden spade and chopped the snake in half. Now he wonders if that action has brought the subsequent bad luck: his mother injured herself in a fall and he fell victim to debit card fraud.
Frogs are stirring up the lily pads and Ginger, the Australian sheepdog, is zipping around lapping the water. The dog and the children run roughshod around the pond, which keeps things rugged.

The Price of Ponds
A spiffy pond will attract accolades from neighbors and house guests, but it will also attract more kinds of wildlife than most people ever knew roamed the suburbs. There are the predictable visitors, like butterflies, dragonflies, snakes and frogs. But people also must watch out for raccoons, possums, snapping turtles, muskrats and geese. Fish must be given deep enough water to avoid predators, and plants can be protected from getting chomped by putting them in wooden boxes or putting wire around the roots.
A professionally designed and installed pond starts at about $3,000 to $5,000. But a handy gardener can install a pond for as little as $1,000, for an 8-by-12 footer, including pump, plants and starter fish. Stiff plastic basins come in various shapes and sizes. Or just dig a hole and spread out a rubber liner, which costs about $1 per square foot.
After digging the hole, drop in the liner and surround the pond edge with stone, which is called the coping.
An untended pond can pose more than an aesthetic problem. It can contribute to the spread of West Nile virus. Mosquitoes are considered a main carrier of the virus and stagnant water is a prime hatching spot for mosquito eggs. 
County Health Department officials urge homeowners to minimize instances of standing water on their property, from birdbaths to hot tubs to blocked storm drains. 
Dr. Joshua Lipsman, the county's health commissioner, said that the West Nile virus has been diagnosed in two county residents this year and that "the virus remains a threat until the first sustained frost."
"A backyard pond is clearly a thing of beauty," he said. "But if you're not able to tend it, then you should empty it."
County health officials say that there is little concern with ponds with healthy ecosystems because birds, frogs and fish would feed on mosquito eggs.
And owners and maintainers of ponds argue that properly maintained ponds, especially those with recirculated water do not attract mosquitoes.
Matt Horn, who owns Matterhorn Nursery in Spring Valley, the region's largest supplier of pond equipment, plants and fish, says that it is best to keep water moving with an electric recirculating pump, since stagnant water attracts mosquitoes and algae. Aerating the water helps fish and bacteria but is less good for waterlilies, which prefer still water. Direct sunlight breeds algae, so it is best to keep about 60 percent of the water surface shaded with plants.
Mr. Horn dismissed claims that ponds increase the possibility of the spread of the West Nile Virus. Mosquitos need still water, and most ponds have their surface disrupted by a water feed, he said.
People tend to favor "natural" waterfalls to channel the water back into the pond. Some ponds do not need filters, Mr. Horn said, but they are essential for ponds with many fish, to clean waste, and for ponds in sunny spots, which tend to get algae. Successful pond owners say that the properly made pond requires very little maintenance. But there are no shortage of nightmare pond stories, with owners forever scooping frothy scum from their ponds, tinkering with pH values, searching for liner leaks and de-gooping their filters.

Pond Population
Choosing the right combination and quantity of fish and plants is crucial for a successful pond. The most popular aquatic plants are floating lilies and lotus plants, and submerged plants like grasses.
Water irises bloom in the spring and so does floating water hyacinth. Papyrus reeds bloom after summer. The plants come in tubs, which go underwater. Plants can only be grown in shallow water. Plants can range from a few dollars for a basic water lily to $200 for special lotuses.
As for fish, the basic pond fish are simple goldfish or the Japanese imperial koi, the shiny carp that look like large, fancy goldfish. They come in bold colors, often orange, black and white and combinations thereof. Both breeds are hearty fish and they hibernate in the winter at the bottom of the pond.
Regular comet goldfish cost about $5 a fish. Koi can range from $80 for an eight-inch fish to $3,000 for a nice butterfly koi. Exotic collectible koi can cost up to $10,000 and there have been prices for koi for hundreds of thousands of dollars.
Mr. Horn, sitting on the edge of the large holding tanks for fish, patted the head of an albino koi with no scales, which is selling for $7,500.

The Perilous Pond
It was a beautiful Sunday morning, but things were going badly for Dick Button at his North Salem home. His three-legged pet pig was lost and he feared she would go into the pond and drown. So he brought his visitors a pot of coffee and set off look to for his beloved beast.
"Today's not my day," Mr. Button, 73, said. Mr. Button, the figure skater and two-time Olympic gold medalist, still has the taut legs and energy of a teenager. But he has a pond problem.
He has two ponds, actually. The good one is a circular pond, about the size of a manhole cover, cut into the thick slate patio. It contains two large koi and a bubbler in the middle. It was a gift from his daughter, and as soon as he installed it, he wanted a larger one. There is no filter, so Mr. Button cleans it as it it were a fish bowl: takes the fish out and changes the water.
Down below on the 50-acre property is a large pond once used to harvest blocks of ice. It's great in the winter. The pond freezes deep black and Mr. Button loves to skate on it. He spent a lot of money building a stone dam for it and has twice stocked it with fish. But it has overflowed during storms, and Mr. Button really has not been able to make it the bucolic nature grove that he envisions.

The Pond in the Woods
The Wardens' estate in Bedford Hills has ponds upon ponds. Behind the house, there is a cluster of three that seem to feed into one another. But that is just an illusion, one cleverly produced by some fancy pump work and camouflage with plants and boulders. A weeping cherry tree presides over the ponds, and there is a lilac tree pruned into a perfect sphere. An atlas cedar droops and a squat Japanese maple holds its own.
"It's a work in progress," said Phyllis Warden, standing with her hands on her hips evaluating the plants. "You've got to keep editing it."
Mrs. Warden, in her khakis, turtleneck and broad straw hat tends the vegetation on her sprawling property full time, along with several workers. Her Pomeranian, Lucky, is never more than a few feet away.
Water is a crucial part of any garden, explained Mrs. Warden, who has seemingly managed to squeeze entire ecosystems into her 12-acre plot. There are arid pine forests and hot, sunny plains of wispy grasses splashed with purple lavender, and there is moist, buggy swampland. The estate is a former apple farm, and the family of artists that lived here kept a small pond, which Mrs. Warden expanded.
Mrs. Warden's husband, John, was the lead trial lawyer for the Microsoft Corporation in its battle against a federal antitrust lawsuit. She can be just as ferocious as her husband when fending off briar and underbrush.
In a small clearing in a woodsy area, a stone's throw from the croquet court, lies another large pond system, formed with huge slabs of rock brought in by tractor. Mrs. Warden estimated the cost between $100,000 and $200,000. Here in the pool she calls Black Pond, she keeps her prize foot-long koi. They have flowery fins that flow behind them like a bride's dress. She has learned the hard way that, if the fish are kept in water too shallow, the raccoons can catch and eat them.
What is it about a pond that relaxes you like a drug? To sit beside a pond fed by water gurgling and trickling down a rocky stream bed -- it all combines to turn the most frantic of minds blessedly blank and succumb to what Keats called "a drowsy numbness."
Anyway, Mrs. Warden's woodsy Walden was working its wonder, inducing relaxation like a narcotic. The watery idyll bestowed a sense of calm like a well-deserved martini.
James and Susan Henry, of the Waccabuc section of Lewisboro, describe themselves as "pathological gardeners." They make wine from their own small vineyard, and honey from their own beehives. 
In the early 1970's, they had a large garden pond put into a low point of their six-acre plot. The pond takes up about a quarter-acre and is fed by several nearby springs and water drainage from the surrounding area.
Mr. Henry was unable to get trout and bass to survive in the lake, but the carp he put in are thriving and keep the water clean enough to maintain without a filter. Mr. Henry, 72, a lawyer who runs a nonprofit organization for lawyers, said that the pond cost about $5,000 to build.
"Best investment I ever made in terms of enjoyment," he said.
The Henrys skate on their pond in winter and watch the deer and birds (wild turkeys, herons, and migrating water birds) that visit the lake.

The Impulsive Pond
There are several common mistakes in pond-building, Mr. Horn said. One is putting in plants too early in the season; another is continuing to feed fish too late, specifically after the water drops below 50 degrees and their metabolism slows down. 
Another mistake is to crowd too many fish and plants into one pond.
"I tell people to build as big a pond as you naturally can afford," he said. "They always wind up wishing for a bigger one, once it's in."
That was the case for Ken Sposato, of White Plains. His pond came about as an impulse purchase at Home Depot. He saw a tub for sale for $65 and he grabbed it. He got a $4 book on garden ponds and he was off. The 6-by-8-foot tub holds about 200 gallons. He spent about $200 on a filter and pump, and another $200 on decorative stones.
He dug a hole in his backyard garden, next to his detached garage and put the pond in. He got a half-dozen 10-cent goldfish from the pet store and tossed them in. Now they're huge. They help keep the pond clean by eating algae and insects.
The next year, he installed a waterfall, and then an electric fence because a raccoon ate his biggest fish.
"It's a perfectly manageable pond that anyone could do," said Mr. Sposato, an antique clock dealer. He showed off his floating iris and spike rush, and his biggest fish surfaced and puckered and blew a bubble and plucked a food pellet off a lily.
Mr. Sposato has not named his fish, he said, as he sat on the patio and talked about the bigger pond he wants to put in next year.
"I'm not that intimate with them yet," he said of his fish. But his wife, Karen, gave him away: "He's out there communing with them every morning," she said.

HEADLINE: CITIES; 
Taking Stock In Hoboken

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN MILLER

DATELINE: HOBOKEN 

 BODY:
IT has, at times, seemed as if this city with its row after row of tree-lined streets was being consumed by girders and cranes and dust. That alone makes the bustling city on the Hudson an oddity in a state with more than its share of industrial dinosaurs.
 Stranger still, in an effort to stop a building boom that other cities in the state can only hunger for, Hoboken has gone so far as to sue itself to stop a sustained burst of growth that has left it swollen and uncomfortable -- what one planning board member described as a "free ride for developers." 
 The suit -- seeking to halt construction of a 17-story apartment complex that had won approval under the previous administration -- has become a symbol of the city's excesses. But to Mark Villamar of the Pegasus Group, a company that manages 600 apartments here, the city is acting too rashly. 
"I've been in Hoboken 30 years, and when I first came to town, the city welcomed development any way, anywhere, because people were leaving," said Mr. Villamar. "The pendulum has swung now against development."
That is what the voters asked for last May when David Roberts won a four-year term as mayor. In the year since Mr. Roberts was elected on a platform that called for a slowing of development, he has begun to change the city's planning laws.
In the most significant moves so far, Mr. Roberts has signed into law new restrictions on the height of apartment buildings across much of the city, placed allies on the planning board and the zoning board and reopened the master plan for the 1.3-square-mile city.
"When I moved here, things were a little scruffier" said Augusta Przygoda, a long-time activist who has lived here since 1976, "but it was in many ways an easier place to live. There's less and less places you can see the sun, or the sky, for that matter."
For people like Ms. Przygoda, however, there may be a break in the clouds. The city has joined a suit to try to halt construction of two 17-story towers on the city's less-developed west side. In August, a state Superior Court judge allowed construction to go forward, but the city quickly appealed; so far, there has been no decision.
Though developers were caught off guard by the city's newfound vigor to slow construction, they are now beginning to organize. In November, Mr. Villamar and about 50 other property owners who were concerned about the city's direction formed the Mile Square Taxpayers Association with the goal of "enhancing the quality of life in Hoboken and protecting property owners' rights."
For all of the recent growth in Hoboken -- a magnet for young professionals priced out of the New York housing market -- there are relatively few amenities. As Mayor Roberts and many of his supporters have contended, those living here have little in the way of parks, swimming pools -- or just plain open space.
Still, talk of stopping development sometimes sounds incongruous in a city where new construction sites seem to spring up as quickly as a rubber ball on a trampoline. In the last year alone, said Fred Bado, director of community development, about 750 new apartment units have been approved for construction.
Aside from Hoboken's most obvious asset -- its proximity to Manhattan -- several other factors have helped to lure residents and shed its image as a tough industrial port. For one thing, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School for Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, Hoboken -- which saw its population rise by 5,000, to 38,500, from 1990 to 2000 -- is blessed with an abundance of solid brownstones, and the PATH and two bus lines provide easy access to Manhattan. "A lot of cities would love to have their problem," said Mr. Hughes.
And despite his campaign platform, Mayor Roberts contended that he was not trying to kill the golden goose and then toss it out of the window.
"I don't want to give anyone the impression that we're not for economic development," he said, but insisted that "smart growth" was the way to go.
As an example, he cited a project near the city's train terminal on a tract owned by New Jersey Transit. The state wanted to build about 200 apartment units there, but the mayor said he thought he had persuaded the builders to look at constructing office space instead.
"There's an overabundance of rental apartments that's gone beyond the community's ability to rent those apartments," Mayor Roberts said.
On that point, real estate agents and developers disagree with the mayor, though they concede that the housing market there is not as feverish as it once was.
"We do not have a glut," said Norma DeRuggiero, vice president of Robert DeRuggiero Inc. Realtors.
While Ms. DeRuggiero did not have estimates of vacancy rates, she conceded that prices had dropped. "We used to have buildings that used to be rented in a minute that are taking a little longer now," she said.
That has not stopped developers from looking toward the western edge of the city away from the waterfront, once a heavily industrial area.
"These people waited 30 years to get development to the west side," said one developer, George Vallone. When the city changed its laws and limited buildings to three floors -- down from five -- property values dropped 25 to 30 percent.
But politicians and some resident groups say there is a reasonable explanation for the height restrictions: a project called The Gateway, situated among high-rise housing projects, train tracks, and auto body shops. With the light rail system expected to reach there by next year, the area has leapt from an afterthought to wildly desirable.
"At first everybody really wanted the construction because there were a lot of dead zones and blighted zones," said Elizabeth Markevitch, a Hoboken activist who helped create a group called the Hudson County Alliance, which originated the suit in July that the city later joined.
"It became clear you didn't need to encourage development anymore," Ms. Markevitch said. She and others saw the project as a potential flood hazard and pointed to a consultant's report that suggested the area could be prone to sewage problems.
But Sanford Weiss, president of the Manhattan Building Company of Hoboken, which is putting up The Gateway -- where 17 floors have already gone up on one tower, and 11 on another -- said he was certain that the legal action was a ploy to placate the masses. "It's a total political football that politicians are using to get voter approval," said Mr. Weiss said. "They're using this project as a scapegoat."
But opposition has also been building over a proposed 1,000-unit apartment complex on a 14-acre waterfront site of the former Maxwell House plant. In response, developers sweetened the deal by agreeing to donate a four-acre pier park to the city.
Despite the headaches, lawsuits, drawn-out hearings, and new laws, almost every developer here attests to the strength of the real estate market.
"I'm one hundred percent bullish on Hoboken," said Michael Barry of Applied Companies, the largest landlord in Hoboken.
And in the end, the city could reap an unintended consequence to the skirmishing: developers could speed up their plans to beat any new laws.
"There's always a race to beat the new ordinance deadline," said Mr. Hughes of Rutgers.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COLUMBUS CIRCLE; 
The Traffic Goes in Circles, But the Plan Marches On

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE

 BODY:
Columbus himself would have gotten lost. For 15 years, the city has been trying to unravel the traffic knot that is Columbus Circle, where pedestrians compete with six lanes of traffic around a tight rotary.
 The city unveiled a redesign last month to restore order to the circle, and to allow pedestrians to rediscover the statue of Columbus. But the proposal, which the city's Art Commission is poised to approve on Tuesday, has raised a few questions. 
 The $15 million plan by Olin Partnership, a noted landscape architecture firm, shows a lush circular island ringed by tall trees, fountains and a landscaped berm to muffle traffic noise. The inner circle, which is reached by three walkways, is lined with benches. 
The 13-foot-high marble statue of Columbus, installed in 1892 for the 400th anniversary of Columbus's landing in the New World, remains in the center, atop a 26-foot granite column. 
"This restores Columbus Circle as the great civic space that it was intended to be in 1868, as part of the original Olmsted and Vaux design," said Douglas Woodward, an urban designer with the Department of City Planning, referring to the architects of Central Park, who created the traffic intersections at each of its four corners. "The fountain will add white noise, so you'll have a sense of repose."
The overall design was generally well received by the three community boards that border Columbus Circle, but some members said the proposed trees would obscure the monument. They also asked that the crosswalks be paved in contrasting brick, rather than painted asphalt, to create a more distinguished effect. And they disliked the use of standard-issue lampposts. 
"This great circle deserves more," said Ethel Sheffer, a member of Community Board 7.
In response, the city has agreed to plant yellow buckeyes, which are shorter trees, around the circle. But city officials said the long-overdue project should not be held back by the other concerns. 
"Columbus Circle has been neglected for a very long time," Mr. Woodward said. DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Fuel Gauge Is Near 'E' For the Big Three

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
SINCE 9/11, major auto companies have relied heavily on zero percent financing to bolster sales.
 Worried that such methods have hurt profit margins, however, investors have bid down prices of auto company stocks and bonds. Stephen J. Girsky, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, has been bearish on the group since the summer. Last week, he discussed his reasons. Following are excerpts from the conversation. 

Q. Why are you worried about zero percent financing for cars?

A. Every month, the Federal Reserve publishes consumer credit data that include terms offered at automobile finance companies. This past Monday, the August numbers came out, and they showed that interest rates being charged by the auto finance companies are the lowest in history, that maturities on auto loans are the longest in history and that the loan-to-value ratio is the highest in history.
So, the auto companies are pulling out all the stops to keep consumers at the party. But in August, car sales were 18.5 million, at an annual rate. In the fall of 2001, sales were running at a 21.5 million annual rate. So despite better terms, they are selling fewer cars. And it is costing Detroit more money to prevent the market from eroding even further. The stock market is saying that Detroit is running on fumes.

Q. What other factors trouble you about the auto companies?

A. At the start of the year, expectations for demand were very low, at around 15 million to 15.5 million units. We will probably end the year at around 17 million. But around midyear, gasoline prices started to go up, consumer confidence started to wane and restructuring efforts, which Detroit seemed serious about, slowed down.
All of which leads us to where we are today: the Big Three's competitive position is no stronger and may be weaker than it was a year ago. 
In addition, we estimate there are about 1.1 million to 1.2 million units of foreign capacity that will be added in the United States next year. That is about six points of market share, and every point is about $1 billion in variable profit.

Q. Is the auto market deteriorating elsewhere in the world?

A. European demand is starting to weaken, Latin America could be weakening and Korean demand is weakening. Japan is still stable but at low levels. And the problem is that when demand weakens elsewhere, everybody wants to send their excess production to North America.

Q. Why is there excess capacity in the auto industry?

A. It is expensive to close down plants. Meanwhile, while the costs of closing capacity are going up, various states in the U.S. are throwing incentives to increase capacity. When General Motors and Chrysler responded to their overcapacity problems in the early 1990's, they were in crisis.
Companies are facing some tough decisions about capacity, not just in North America but in Europe and Japan as well. 
As far as the demand-supply situation is concerned, there is demand for about 60 million to 70 million cars globally. There is capacity to make 85 million to 90 million cars. So capacity would have to be cut 20 percent to 25 percent to restore firmness to prices.

Q. What would make you more optimistic about the Big Three?

A. A number of things would make us more positive, including evidence the consumer is getting rejuvenated and that companies are attacking their costs more aggressively. There seems to be a disconnect between what people in Detroit are thinking and what the stock market is seeing.

Q. Ford Motor debt securities are trading as if the company were on the verge of a financial crisis. How bad is the situation?

A. The auto company has plenty of liquidity, at around $10 billion. That is not a problem. The probability of a financial crisis in the next couple of years is relatively low. Worries that this company is going to have a liquidity crisis are unfounded, unless there is a crisis with the consumer.

Q. Which stocks do you favor?

A. We would like DaimlerChrysler if the stock price were lower, and on a valuation basis we would rather be with a company like BMW, which does not trade A.D.R.'s in this country. We do like Honda Motor, which does have A.D.R.'s. They are doing well here and in Japan, are gaining share and have some of the highest margins in the business. That is a name we like.
The suppliers could be a better story, because while they are volume-driven, their fixed-cost structure is generally lower than that of the auto makers. If demand weakens, they are usually cash-flow positive. And they have a diversified customer base. In general, companies like the Lear Corporation or the Magna Corporation are better places to be than the car companies.

HEADLINE: The Ballpark of Memory 

BYLINE:  By DAVID MARGOLICK; David Margolick, a contributing editor at Vanity Fair, is working on a book about the Joe Louis-Max Schmeling fights.

 BODY:
EVERY month they gather on the Upper West Side, and no matter what the season, the subject is always the same: baseball. 
 It may be the game last night, or the 1941 All-Star Game, or Game 6 of the 1947 World Series. Bouncing as naturally as a friendly hop to short between John J. McGraw and George Steinbrenner, from Casey Stengel to Jerry Lumpe to Derek Jeter, they spout statistics, exchange yarns and disgorge oddities, always in the peculiar Esperanto of the sport, sprinkled with odd abbreviations and obscure names and defunct teams. All speak this language fluently, some from memory, others from lifetimes spent mainlining The Baseball Encyclopedia and the backs of baseball cards. 
 There's nothing like an agenda, but the topics are usually historic; the Yankees' recent demise would surely warrant some comment, but no one would dwell on it. Thus at one recent gathering the topics discussed included how The New York Herald Tribune helped expose the racism on the 1947 St. Louis Cardinals, how much Babe Ruth's bat weighed, and how, while everyone remembers Bill Mazeroski's famous home run that day, few realize that no one struck out in the seventh game of the 1960 World Series. On a loftier level, they pondered the classic conundrum of the true New York baseball fan: What would you do if you had Hitler, Stalin and Walter O'Malley (for the uninitiated, the man who moved the Brooklyn Dodgers to Los Angeles) standing before you, and had only two bullets in your gun? Actually, it's not all that difficult. You save them both for O'Malley. 
Ernie's, at Broadway and 75th Street, is an empty aircraft hangar of a restaurant, at least during a weekday lunchtime when most gainfully employed neighborhood residents are toiling a few subway stops south. But crowded around one table toward the back not long ago were such consummate New York baseball chroniclers as the biographers of Babe Ruth (Robert Creamer) and Lou Gehrig (Ray Robinson). Even in this illustrious company, though, Lawrence S. Ritter stands apart.
Mr. Ritter doesn't hold the career record for triples, as does Wahoo Sam Crawford, who played from 1899 to 1917. Nor did he win 34 games in a season, like Smoky Joe Wood in 1912. He did not drop a fly ball in the World Series that year, like Fred Snodgrass, nor turn an unassisted triple play in the 1920 World Series, like Bill Wambsganss. Nor is he in the Hall of Fame, like Crawford or Goose Goslin or Rube Marquard.
But if historians of the sport were eligible for Cooperstown, Mr. Ritter would be elected unanimously the first time out. More than 40 years ago, determined to do for baseball what John and Alan Lomax did for vernacular American music, he began interviewing ballplayers who'd been active in the early years of the 20th century, including Crawford, Wood, Snodgrass, Wambsganss and 29 others. (Chief Meyers, who played for both the Giants and Dodgers, told him, "I started playing ball when Dewey took Manila," and it was actually true.) 
Five years, 75,000 miles and two hernias later -- the ancient Tandberg reel-to-reel tape recorder he lugged around weighed 27 pounds -- Mr. Ritter turned the interviews into "The Glory of Their Times: The Story of the Early Days of Baseball Told by the Men Who Played It" (MacMillan, 1966).
The Brooklyn Dodgers and the Yankees' announcer Red Barber called it the greatest baseball book ever written. The novelist Nelson Algren predicted the book would "be around as long as baseball," and so far, he's right. If you doubt its continued popularity and the astonishing impact it still has on people, just check the reader comments about it on Amazon.com. What makes Mr. Ritter's achievement all the more remarkable is that he was not a sportswriter at all, but a professor of economics and finance at the New York University School of Business, where he taught from 1961 to 1991.
"I didn't think this whole thing would amount to anything," Mr. Ritter, who turned 80 a few months ago, recalled recently in his apartment on West End Avenue. Initially, that was true: every publisher that saw the book spurned it. MacMillan eventually bought it for $3,000, and since then it has sold some 375,000 copies. True, another of Mr. Ritter's 10 books -- "Principles of Money, Banking and Financial Markets" -- has sold more. But for some reason, people never embraced it in quite the same way.
NEW YORKERS love attributing their success to their New Yorkness -- which, they believe, gives them half a step on everyone else. And Mr. Ritter is very much the New Yorker. He grew up in Hollis, Queens, graduated from Boys High School in Brooklyn, and made all of the usual pilgrimages to Yankee Stadium and Ebbets Field and the Polo Grounds. He attended his first ballgame with his father, a principal of Public School 139 in Rego Park, Queens, in 1931. The Yankees were playing the Philadelphia Athletics. (Mr. Ritter still swears that Ruth, Gehrig and Jimmie Foxx hit home runs that day, though years later, when he searched the box scores, he could find no such game.)
But he knows that New Yorkers can just as surely put people off, and believes that his ballplayers talked so candidly because his years away from the city -- wartime service in the Navy, plus long spells studying and teaching in places like Bloomington, Ind., and Madison, Wis. -- had obscured his New York origins. "If it had come up, in a number of cases, there would have been a lot less warmth," he recalled. "I was a Midwesterner. They liked that. I wasn't a New York Jewish person, so it was a whole different ballgame." 
His obvious love of the sport also helped, as did his uncanny ability to listen. "These people for 30 years had never talked about this stuff," he said. "Their grandchildren ran away when they saw them coming, because they were afraid of being bombarded by more bull about old-time baseball." In several cases, what began as interviews turned into lifelong friendships.
Reading "The Glory of Their Times" -- a phrase from Ecclesiastes -- is a rite of passage for serious baseball fans. Many, like the broadcaster Bob Costas, who, like other broadcasting celebrities -- Ralph Kiner, Ernie Harwell -- stops by Ernie's periodically for the baseball lunch, first read it as teenagers, and never forgot it.
For Mr. Costas, a St. Louis native whose torrent of anecdotes at one recent lunch helped turn what is generally a two-hour affair into a 15-inning marathon, the book colorized a world that, until then, had existed for him solely in fuzzy, sunless black and white. "It made these guys come to life," he said of the early ballplayers. "It was like hearing baseball's Mount Rushmore, with more than four heads talking. It humanized them and gave them texture, which made them -- from my perspective as a kid -- all the more heroic." 
Mr. Creamer, a veteran Sports Illustrated reporter and the author of books on Ruth, Stengel and Mickey Mantle, agreed. "All these fabulous names that I heard about all my life became people," he said. 
When, two years ago, several hours of Mr. Ritter's original audiotapes, now housed at the Hall of Fame, were released on tape cassettes and compact discs, the book took on new life, and power, and charm. Its stories are even more winning when heard aloud, spun by weathered voices with archaic accents ("Cincinna-tah," "Eye-o-way"), with cars backfiring, chairs creaking, matches igniting, wives scoffing and pop bottles popping in the background.
Men who died decades ago -- the last of Mr. Ritter's subjects, Smoky Joe Wood, passed on in 1985 -- suddenly leap back to life. Few things can summon the dead more quickly than hearing them laugh -- and, discussing the game and their youth, these old men laughed a lot. The charmless, plutocratic superstars of today only enhance the old-timers' appeal. (But if it's any consolation to them, Mr. Ritter's interviewees regarded the ballplayers of the 1960's as pampered crybabies, too.) 
In Mr. Ritter's materials, legends like Walter Johnson, Ty Cobb, Christy Mathewson and Cy Young are no longer figures off bronze bas-reliefs and eBay collectibles, but teammates, adversaries, human beings. Mitts and salaries shrink to nothing. Dead balls and emery balls and shine balls and coffee balls and paraffin balls and mud balls fly around once again.
So, too, do spikes, though gashes are treated with chewing tobacco rather than the unguents of roly-poly, obsequious trainers. There is only one umpire on the field, the American League is still an outlaw enterprise, the Yankees are still the Highlanders. And the World Series is still the best of nine.
IT is a rite of reportage: young people interview old people, frantically rescuing their recollections from oblivion, and, if they're lucky, or talented, or durable enough, someone someday will interview them, too. Mr. Ritter is now the age of the ballplayers he interviewed. He speaks with difficulty, a result of a stroke last year. The words are all still in him, but they can be slow to emerge; phrases as hard-wired into his soul as "Pittsburgh Pirates" and "Wahoo Sam Crawford" sometimes take a while to percolate up. But Mr. Ritter's personality, simultaneously astringent and sweet, has survived. While his tongue may no longer be so nimble, it is still tart. "I always said that when I turn 80 I wanted to be shot, but no one's volunteering," he said. 
Mr. Ritter says "The Glory of Their Times" came out of a complex web of desires: to capture voices before they were stilled (Ty Cobb had just died when he began in 1961); to pay homage to his father -- his "Daddy," as he always calls him -- also recently dead; to cleave more closely to his own young son, whom he saw only on weekends, and with whom he shared little but a love of the game. So he hit the road, journeying from Baywood Park, Calif., to Milwaukee to Port Jervis, N.Y., to Bridgeton, N.J., avoiding players who'd been interviewed to death, seeking those good enough to have had long careers but obscure enough to have been largely forgotten.
Heard rather than read, "The Glory of Their Times" is more than a peek into a lost world; it is a clinic for anyone who ever wants to learn anything from anyone else. Mr. Ritter's questions are occasional, succinct, gentle, open-ended. "You saw some mighty good pitching, didn't you?" "What was McGraw like as a manager?" "How'd you get along with Connie Mack?" "What were the parks like in 1903-04-05?" Some weren't questions at all: "You must have seen Joe Jackson play, too." 
Asking no more than he had to, Mr. Ritter listened, even when nothing was being said. He had to banish his then-girlfriend, who can be heard in some of the early interviews, because she was too prone to break the reverie. "It takes a long time and a lot of luck to get somebody to be living in 1912," he said. "So I wanted those silences. But she couldn't overcome her social graces."
His knowledge was deep -- "Where'd you come up with all these things?" Goose Goslin asks him, amazed -- but he did his homework. Still, feigning ignorance worked better than flaunting his smarts.
His manner with the elderly was natural and respectful, neither falsely familiar nor excessively deferential. He treated them like people, not as relics. He could be awed -- listen to him pick up Chief Meyers's 48-ounce bat or punching the pocket of one of Ruth's old mitts -- but he was no groupie. Broaching potentially sensitive matters, like the games in which Goslin hit into four double plays or Snodgrass made his famous flub, he was empathetic. When his subjects embellished or dissembled, he let them be.
Mr. Ritter, who describes himself as an orthodox Keynesian, left New York University 11 years ago, after Reaganomics had taken over the place. "I couldn't stand my students, and I certainly couldn't stand my colleagues," he said. "I started to feel as though, 'Oh, Jesus, I've got to get out of this place.' " Even though there's a room there named for him, he's never been back. 
Besides, by then "The Glory of Their Times" had started him on his literary career. In another of his books, "East Side, West Side," published in 1998, he tracked down many of the vanished landmarks of New York sports. The book, he admits, is weighted toward baseball -- like Washington Park, where the Brooklyn Dodgers played before Ebbets Field -- and boxing (the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City, Jack Dempsey's restaurant) and gives short shrift to other sports: racing, hockey, basketball. To him, the explanation is simple: his Daddy never took him to see the horses, the Rangers or the Knicks, so they simply don't count.
MR. RITTER was always a bit of a recluse. When his mother pushed him out of the house, he recalled, he invariably got no farther than the front stoop. Now illness has made him still more of a homebody. He has moved to a smaller apartment a few floors below his old place; it doesn't have any of the random clutter that people of normal mobility usually leave in their wake. The shelves look pruned and bare; Mr. Ritter has given away hundreds of baseball books. Nowadays he gets his baseball -- at least one game every day they play -- from television. "I don't like the players, I don't like the umpires, I don't like the owners," he said. "But I love the game."
His principal forays outside are to the sportswriters' lunches, which began about a dozen years ago. At the most recent meeting, one of the regulars, Lee Lowenfish, wore an Orioles T-shirt and a Giants cap. "Ah, a tribute to Foster Castleman," said Marty Appel, another regular and a former publicist for the Yankees, referring to an otherwise forgotten third baseman who'd played for both teams in the 1950's. 
The reference wasn't lost on anyone, including Mr. Ritter, who laughed knowingly. And gratefully: he'd missed several sessions after his stroke. With the help of Evelyn Begley, a baseball maven who helps tend to him, he returned, tentatively but triumphantly, three months later. "Evelyn said they all loved me," he said quietly. "I didn't know that, but she could see in their faces something that I couldn't see."
For all his outwardly curmudgeonliness, Mr. Ritter is a sentimental, generous man. Unlikely as it seems now, at a time when every autograph costs, none of the old ballplayers ever asked him for anything. Even so, for 20 years he split all royalties with them and their survivors; each ended up with about $10,000, no small sum for people without pensions. For Snodgrass, who played center field in the Polo Grounds, Mr. Ritter dug up and sent off some turf shortly before the place was demolished. For Hans Loeber, a one-time Phillies third baseman (and perhaps the first major leaguer ever to bat against Babe Ruth), who was living out his days in a fleabag hotel, he bought a television set so he could watch ballgames.
For 30 years Mr. Ritter hadn't listened to his tapes. "I didn't like myself. I didn't like the nasal sound." But hearing them again four years ago, when they were released commercially, he was pleased. "I thought, 'Wow, what great interviews these are,' and I lost all self-consciousness," he said. "I think all of it is bound up with the love I had for all of the people involved."
One of those people was Jimmy Austin, the Yankee third baseman whose rear end dominates the classic Charles M. Conlon photo of Ty Cobb sliding into third. In his interview with Mr. Ritter, Austin recounted how he'd hit a homer off a half-drunk Rube Waddell one day in 1909 or 1910, and how Waddell fell on his own behind as Austin rounded the bases. "I will never forget it as long as I live," Austin joyously recalled. 
Within a year, Austin was dead. Except, that is, on Larry Ritter's wondrous tapes, where he can still be heard, living, breathing, reminiscing. And laughing.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
Waiting for a Big Rebound in Profits? Wait Longer

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
CORPORATE profits season goes into full swing this week, but results for the third quarter -- and the outlook for the fourth -- are not likely to be upbeat.
 Expectations are being lowered by loan problems at banks and the weakness in the foreign earnings of American companies. The dollar, surprisingly, is not helping, either. 
 A few months ago, third-quarter reports from companies like Intel, Charles Schwab, Coca-Cola, Bank One, Bank of America, Caterpillar, Citigroup, General Motors, Johnson & Johnson and Motorola were expected to confirm that a long-awaited rebound in corporate earnings had arrived. Analysts hoped that this earnings surge, coming after five consecutive quarters of profit decline and one of minimal growth, would finally help lift the stock market. 
But earnings expectations for the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index are now falling for both the third and, more important, the fourth quarter. Taking their toll are a weaker-than-expected economic recovery, problem bank loans, the falling stock market, the threat of a war with Iraq and the fear that consumers may be slowing their spending.
Wall Street analysts are now predicting earnings growth of 4.7 percent for the S.& P. 500 for the third quarter, compared with the year-earlier period, according to Thomson First Call. That is down from a forecast of 16.6 percent on July 1. For the fourth quarter, the current consensus is 19 percent, down from 27.7 percent on July 1 -- and there is plenty of time for more downward revisions.
The new forecasts are especially disappointing because the third and fourth quarters were supposed to be easy ones for profit growth. That is because they hardly have tough acts to follow: earnings declined 22 percent in both the third and fourth quarters of last year.
Financial companies in the S.& P. have a big effect on earnings. That is because they are the largest sector of the index, accounting for 81 of the 500 stocks and 23 percent of total profits. According to Thomson First Call, the forecast for profit growth for this group in the third quarter has fallen to 25 percent, from 39 percent at the beginning of July, and to 27 percent for the fourth quarter, from 35 percent.
Earnings expectations were reduced after J. P. Morgan Chase increased write-offs and reserves for bad loans. Bank of New York then said loan losses cut its profits by $260 million in the third quarter. More bank losses are likely because banks have the most bad loans on their books in a decade, according to federal regulators. The loans include those made to troubled companies like Enron, Adelphia Communications and WorldCom.
The frantic pace of the estimate downgrades can be seen in the number of profit revisions at some individual banks. In the last 30 days at J. P. Morgan alone, there have been 16 negative revisions for the third quarter and 15 for the fourth quarter. Bank of New York has had 16 for the third and 13 for the fourth, while Citigroup has had 7 for the third and 7 for the fourth, according to Thomson First Call.
ABOUT 20 percent of earnings for the S.& P. 500 companies index come from abroad. Analysts at Morgan Stanley estimate that these earnings declined by 2.8 percent in the second quarter and that they are unlikely to rise very soon.
And while the dollar has fallen 7.6 percent against the euro in the year ended Sept. 30, it is stronger against many other major currencies. That means that gains from abroad will be reduced -- or losses increased -- when they are translated back into the dollar.
A third negative, the port closings on the West Coast, may be limited by President Bush's move to reopen them using the Taft-Hartley Act. Still, billions of dollars have been lost. The actual cost to fourth-quarter profits will depend on how quickly the ports can unload their backlog, said Richard Berner, chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley.
But any way you slice it, a meaningful revival in corporate earnings may have to await the new year.

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF; 
Diamonds,Money and Madness In Brutal African Wars

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL

 BODY:
THERE is a grim resolve to the quest of some reporters to reach the dark core of their story, their personal addition to the canon established by Joseph Conrad.
 In "Blood Diamonds" (Westview Press, $26), Greg Campbell, an American freelance journalist based in Colorado, finds his apocalypse in the Sierra Leone town of Kailahun, a place so brutalized by civil war that the only impulse left is the desire to escape. The field hospital is a nightmare, a parody of its own name. The victims are no more than flotsam, beached by the receding tide of one of Africa's cruelest rebellions. Those who witness their plight -- the author included -- end up seized by the same wish to flee that grips those whose destiny is to remain. But while the rebellion's outcome was cruel, so was its cause: the greed for diamonds that fueled sub-Saharan wars in the 1990's. 
 This swashbuckling account of smugglers and warriors, of child soldiers and crazed victims, draws the stark contrast between the gem business on 47th Street in Manhattan and the lives of amputees who were victims of a war over access to diamond fields. (The struggle was so brutal that human limbs were routinely severed to send a message of terror.) It is also the story of how De Beers, the South African-based giant that built the world diamond industry, saw the dire threat from so-called conflict diamonds -- gems that are used to finance the acquisition of arms or enrich warlords -- and switched course to cast itself as the standard-bearer of probity after decades of opacity.
In the book, Mr. Campbell reminds us that there is no longer any such thing as an isolated regional conflict that governments and corporations can ignore with impunity. The illicit diamond trade in Africa, after all, may have been used by Al Qaeda to launder millions of dollars. Remote conflicts -- wars fought over resources, wars the world overlooks -- attract those who thrive in lawless environments.
Mr. Campbell's narrative turns on a 1999 report by an British advocacy group, Global Witness. It produced evidence that De Beers had been buying diamonds from Unita, a rebel movement in Angola that reaped an estimated $3.7 billion from diamond sales from 1992 to 1997 and used some of the proceeds to buy weapons. The evidence, which included remarks by a De Beers executive acknowledging that at least some Unita diamonds had found their way into the company's inventories, convulsed the diamond business because of fears that the gems themselves might be stigmatized, just as the fur trade was after the publication of photographs showing trappers bludgeoning baby seals.
De Beers, with its formidable public relations and corporate resources, went into top gear, reinventing itself as a crusader for clean diamonds. Governments, advocacy groups and the diamond industry -- De Beers included -- all pitched in to produce a code of behavior called the Kimberley Process (named for the South African town where De Beers first made its fortune), aimed at creating a global certification system for diamonds. At the same time, wars in Angola and Sierra Leone finally wound down.
End of story? Not quite.
The solutions came too late to save huge areas and vast numbers of people. Africa's diamond-fueled wars killed 3.7 million people and displaced 6 million, Mr. Campbell writes. Some of the most notorious smugglers who organized the diamonds-for-arms trade are still at large. Many of those who suffered during the wars have been condemned to lives of destitution.
But there is a paradox. For much of the book, Mr. Campbell regards the diamond trade in general and De Beers in particular with something between suspicion and contempt. He takes dismissive note of what he calls the "megalomania" of Cecil John Rhodes, the British colonialist who founded the company, and he reports acerbically on the company's conversion from shareholder ownership back into private hands in May 2001, when South Africa's Oppenheimer family and the Anglo American mining colossus jointly took control of the company. "According to the script drafted by Cecil Rhodes more than 100 years ago, De Beers is officially accountable to no one," he writes.
SO it comes as something of a surprise that when Mr. Campbell turns to contemplating likely solutions for Sierra Leone's woes, De Beers comes in on the credit side for the role it has played in countries like Botswana and Namibia, where its stake in the diamond mining business is enormous. "The company's partnership with the government of Botswana, which has the fastest-growing economy in the world, should be viewed as a shining example of what properly organized and regulated industry can do for the good of a country," Mr. Campbell writes, suggesting perhaps that as much as De Beers may have played the exploiter, it can also redeem. 
Some people may think that optimism disingenuous. De Beers is an unusually complicated company. Its long history is built, as Mr. Campbell recounts, on the magical imagery of diamonds, which draw value exclusively from their carefully nurtured mystique. As much as De Beers is under pressure in a modern business world to be transparent, the central pillar of its business rests on maintaining this quasi-religious mystery.
True, De Beers's contribution to the economies of countries like Botswana is impressive, but it still faces an antitrust investigation in the United States and it still controls two-thirds of the world's rough diamonds. Mr. Campbell does not seem to explore this ambiguous blend of cultured beauty and business brawn as deeply as he might.
He recounts a meeting with suave middle-ranking De Beers executives in London, coincidentally on Sept. 11, 2001, contrasting the calm at De Beers's offices with the mayhem in New York and Washington. He goes on to chronicle ties that were subsequently drawn between Qaeda terrorists and the illicit diamond business in West Africa. But to do so, he draws on -- as he acknowledges -- reporting in The Washington Post, without offering his own corroboration. That is a disappointment.
Yet there is a lesson in this narrative, and it is one that advocacy groups have taught big multinational oil companies like Shell or BP and mining companies like Anglo American: They can no longer simply breeze in and out of weak countries as it suits them. They bear a responsibility not only to their stockholders but to the broader array of stakeholders. Greed can no longer thrive as its own justification. In light of Enron or Tyco, however, it seems that not everyone has learned the lesson.
Mr. Campbell tells this complex tale from a personal, feet-on-the-ground perspective. His conclusions are drawn from direct contact with the guerrillas and hungry diamond miners who drive his narrative. In the seedy bars of Freetown, Sierra Leone's capital, the reader smells the heat and tastes the cold beer.
This was a dangerous project, of course, but Mr. Campbell seems far more interested in highlighting the plight of victims than in boasting of his own courage. Indeed, he says that at times, when offered a ride to the front line somewhere in the jungle, he demurred. 
Those who have followed the news about blood diamonds will find no great new disclosures or glaring errors in this sad saga, but Mr. Campbell does bring home a powerful emotional message.
Consider, for example, his concluding line as he mulls the ubiquity of armless beggars in Freetown, people who lost their hands, and thus their futures and livelihoods, in a war over baubles for other people's fingers. These are not just beggars, Mr. Campbell seems to suggest, for even the receipt of gifts is a challenge for them.
"When giving money to the amputated," he writes, "you must put it directly into their pockets."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; 
Ruby Kam, William Woo

 BODY:
Ruby Ying Kam, the daughter of Shuet Fong Kam and Hon Kwong Kam of Burlington, Mass., was married yesterday to William Cheung Woo, the son of Dr. Wanho Cheung Woo of Roslyn Heights, N.Y., and the late Se Hyung Woo. 
Sue A. Anderson, a justice of the peace, officiated at the Ritz-Carlton in Boston.
 Mrs. Woo, 29, and Mr. Woo, 36, met in Boston in 2000 at a party for incoming Columbia University students. Both graduated from there, she summa cum laude. 
 The bride is a candidate for an M.B.A. at Harvard. Her father is a senior mechanical engineer in Seabrook, N.H., with the nuclear division of Northeast Utilities. Her mother is the office manager for a dental practice in Boston.
The bridegroom is a partner in TSG Equity Partners, an investment company in Stow, Mass. He manages fund-raising and investments. He received an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania. His mother retired as a medical director in New York for the Public Health Service. His father founded and owned Current Economics, a business that gave financial executives management-training seminars in New York. He was also an economics professor at Nassau Community College in Garden City, N.Y.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2003 Hyundai Tiburon; 
Hot Date That's Willing To Make a Commitment

BYLINE:  By DAN NEIL

 BODY:
FOR 20-year-olds with 20 grand to spend on a sporty coupe, life keeps getting better. In this intensely competitive class, where "best of" titles fall as quickly as Hollywood's summer box-office records, the Hyundai Tiburon GT V-6 has come out of nowhere -- actually, out of South Korea -- to run with the best competitors that Japan and America can muster.
 For added emphasis, Hyundai offers a five-year bumper-to-bumper warranty and a 10-year powertrain warranty -- twice as long as most of its competitors'. That has gone a long way toward enhancing the credibility of Hyundai, a company that has not historically been synonymous with quality in the way that the Taliban were not synonymous with frat parties. But a decade-long powertrain warranty in this segment is audacious, since these sporty cars are likely to be wrung out mercilessly by many of their fast-and-furious young drivers. 
 Hyundai is also using its warranty to mend fences. The company recently said its horsepower ratings had been inflated for several years, blaming an internal accounting error similar to those that are all the rage on Wall Street. To soothe customers, the company will extend roadside assistance until 2004 for 1999 cars. Owners of 2000 and later models will have a choice of a 5-year roadside-assistance extension, to 10 years; a year's extension (to 6 years) of the new-vehicle limited warranty, or a 2-year extension of the powertrain warranty, to 12 years or 120,000 miles.
The Tiburon is a front-drive fastback with 2-plus-2 seating -- define that as two adults in the front and two bags of groceries in the spine-compressing back seat. Its like-sized competitors include the precociously refined Acura RSX Type S, the whippetlike Toyota Celica GT-S and the Mitsubishi Eclipse RS.
The Acura's strength is its unstinting list of standard features, including automatic climate control, power moonroof, CD player and lots more, all for a base price of $20,450. But the Tiburon GT V-6, with a price of $18,494, measures up nicely.
The Celica GT-S, at $21,555, is the dentist's drill of sporty hatchbacks. Its in-line four-cylinder engine has advanced variable valve timing that helps to wring 180 horsepower from a mere 1.8 liters of displacement. The Toyota is also a bantamweight, tipping the scales at 2,500 pounds. The trade-off is that the Celica's twin-camshaft engine produces peak horsepower at a screaming 7,600 r.p.m. and peak torque (130 pounds-feet) at 6,800 r.p.m., which means that everyday drivers must constantly stir the six-speed shifter to get the most out of the motor.
The Tiburon V-6, in contrast, has a larger engine (2.7 liters with twin overhead cams) that produces a hearty 170 horsepower at 6,000 r.p.m. and 181 pounds-feet of torque at a relatively low 4,000 r.p.m., so the car requires much less shopkeeping. With the ample torque available at lower engine speeds, the transmission ratios of the five-speed manual are more than adequate, even if you accelerate hard in a too-high gear. (A six-speed manual and a four-speed automatic are both optional.)
With its abundant torque, the Tiburon bolts to 60 m.p.h. in 7.1 seconds, according to Car and Driver magazine, a bit quicker than the Celica -- which is actually 500 pounds lighter.
In this segment, customers are more likely to worry about hair-gel consumption than gasoline use, so fuel economy isn't a deal breaker. Still, the Tiburon's V-6 is quite a bit more thirsty (19 m.p.g. in town, 26 on the highway) than either the small-displacement Toyota (23/32) or Acura (24/31).
Compared with the first Tiburon of 1997 -- as overstyled as a debutante's hairdo -- the new design is clean, simple and refined, with classic hot-hatch proportions over a settled stance on 17-inch alloy wheels and Michelin Pilot tires. Sassy details abound, from the body-colored rear spoiler to the chrome-tipped dual exhausts and crystalline fog lamps, all standard on the GT edition. The intent is to wow them on La Cienega, but the inspiration is direct from Italy. The Tiburon bears a passing resemblance to the Ferrari 456 GT, with its Coke-bottle waist, rising beltline and dueling scars behind the front wheels.
The interior is similarly handsome and restrained, with a gimmick-free layout of instruments and controls in a palette of black plastic and dense rubberized panels on the dashboard and doors. Bright trim is limited to bezels around the shifter and gauges and drilled aluminum pedals.
Drivers will like the GT's Infinity stereo, with a 36-watt amplifier, six speakers and a window-rattling subwoofer. Suburban neighbors may be less impressed.
The Tiburon feels substantial and solid; the leather shift knob and steering wheel fill the driver's hands nicely. The GT has leather bucket seats with deep side bolsters that hold you firmly in place while you put the car through its paces.
Such exercises are highly recommended. This car loves to run. Its foundation, a steel unit body shared with no other models, exhibits a strength and stiffness well above expectations. Underneath, the MacPherson strut front suspension and multilink rear suspension are attached to transverse subframes that further reinforce the body.
The GT's sport-tuned suspension has larger antiroll bars and stiffer springs and shock absorbers; combined with the low-profile tires it can make the ride a little crisp, but still civil enough for the young backsides that will find their way into this car.
The overall drivability of the engine and transmission package is excellent. The Tiburon surges in each gear with conviction and ease, accompanying itself with the mellow, husky timbre of its exhaust.
The rack-and-pinion steering offers fine road feel and progressively heavier feedback. The oversize tires really grip the corners, and the suspension keeps the "body roll" within agreeable limits. When it comes time to stop, the four-wheel antilock brakes (optional in all but the highest trim level, alas) halt the car with measured authority. I'm not sure why Hyundai is so stingy with its antilock system. In a car with so many standard features, it seems peculiar to ask people to pay extra for an important safety device.
What a swell car. With all of its attributes, and a price that will make many skeptics suspend their disbelief, the Tiburon looks to be a shoo-in on some "best of" lists. But that can't last, can it?
Perhaps not. But years from now, long after the latest, greatest hot hatchback has superceded the Tiburon, Hyundai service departments will still be doing free warranty work on the car. In the auto business, that's a sort of immortality.

INSIDE TRACK: Korean chic.

HEADLINE: A Promise to Love, Honor and Bear No Children 

BYLINE:  By JILL BROOKE

 BODY:
TO the women he dated, Jeff Gundersen was all things wonderful. He was handsome, athletic and successful, a Wall Street headhunter who lived in a garden apartment on Gramercy Park. At 50, Mr. Gundersen, a divorced father of three, wanted to remarry, but there was a catch: he didn't want more children.
 "I was dating women in their 30's, and for many it was a deal breaker," Mr. Gundersen said. "I had already done the diapers, the weekend soccer games and the late nights with the kids' homework. I had been there and was happy to have my own life back." 
 When he met Lorraine White, who was a decade younger, Mr. Gundersen laid out the negotiables and the nonnegotiables. Before marrying two years ago, she agreed not to start a second family. 
"I realized we loved being together and had so much in common that it became O.K. not to have kids," said Ms. White, who founded and oversees Future Possibilities, which provides services to poor New York children. "What's more important? A great relationship or a child?"
"Men," she added, "like to be the child and taken care of. They don't want you to be distracted by a baby."
More than a decade ago, Fortune magazine coined the term "trophy wife" in a cover article to describe the lovely younger spouse, often with an impressive career, who is matched up with a titan of business on his second or third (or fourth) marriage. In this age-old but newly explored frontier in relations between the sexes, both parties were seen to benefit: the man gets a beautiful younger woman who provides affirmation of his status and sexual prowess; the women gets a life of ease and social access that would otherwise be out of reach.
One part of the bargain, however, is almost never mentioned: successful men who have raised children with Wife No. 1 often insist that their subsequent, younger spouses must forgo having children. Matrimonial lawyers say the arrangement, though legally dubious, is increasingly being written into prenuptial agreements.
Men who are "on their second or third marriages with two sets of kids are saying they're done and don't want to do it again," said Janis Spindel, the owner of Serious Matchmaking, a company in New York that charges $15,000 to introduce its clients -- mostly men making upward of $250,000 a year -- to suitable potential mates.
"In return, they offer an incredible lifestyle to their partners," Ms. Spindel said. "Even if you are financially secure, kids are expensive and demanding of time. Now these men have the freedom to shower their trophy wives with gifts from Harry Winston and spur-of-the-moment trips to Paris. You can't do that with a crying baby."
Lest one think that the women who agree to such conditions resent it, many say they are quite happy. Ms. White -- not a trophy wife in the conventional sense, since Mr. Gundersen is not quite a mogul -- is among them.
"We feel like we're newlyweds and on a date all the time," she said. "There's nothing to distract me from focusing on Jeff, and Jeff on me. Our relationship is so fantastic that I have no regrets."
Last year, Somers White, a mainstay of the black-tie benefit circuit, became the third wife of Jonathan Farkas, an heir to the Alexander's department store fortune. He was about 15 years her senior and made it a condition of marriage that they have no children, Mrs. Farkas said. She, too, reports no regrets. "I get two wonderful stepchildren, and I have more time to spend on Jonathan," she said. "This way, we get to be kids together."
Mrs. Farkas also has more time to devote to charitable causes, particularly the Audubon Society, than if she were raising a family, she added.
Mitchell Schrage, a matrimonial lawyer in New York who handles prenuptial agreements for couples that generally include at least one partner with considerable wealth, said that no-child provisions are becoming more frequent. "Ten years ago, we had one every other year," he said. "Now it's four or five."
"What you often see is the man who's worth $10 million saying that there's no negotiations," he added. "These women are often younger and want to get married, so they acquiesce."
Some legal experts said that prohibitions on children in prenuptial agreements are not enforceable. A 1959 court ruling in New York said such arrangements "violated public policy and the notion that part of marriage is having children," said Louis Newman, a matrimonial lawyer. The prenuptial agreements that Mr. Schrage draws up include an acknowledgment that the provision may not hold up in court. He said that none of his clients have ended up in litigation over the matter, and that the prenuptial language was primarily to "set the expectations" of the marriage. 
Sylvia Ann Hewlett, whose book "Creating a Life: Professional Women and the Quest for Children" caused a stir this year with its finding that 42 percent of professional women have no children by the age of 40, said that one reason was that those women marry men who already have children and don't want more.
"It was kind of a condition that the marriage had no children," Ms. Hewlett said. "In many cases, the women really craved children, but it was a trade-off they made."
That describes Lori Glicksman, who signed a prenuptial agreement in 1998 not to have children, and has come to regret it. She was 40 and working as a computer executive for a financial services company in New York. Her husband, who had a child from a previous marriage, insisted on the arrangement, she said. Ms. Glicksman said she agreed because she loved him, and also because life with a high-powered husband, whose name she asked not be published, was seductive.
"He's an Ivy League-educated, handsome, powerful man, and that was a great aphrodisiac," she said. "You have this great lifestyle, and he treated me very well and loved me."
But gradually the situation became painful, Ms. Glicksman said. "Suddenly I would see all these strollers on Madison Avenue and be pulled towards every baby," she said. "For two years this went on, and I couldn't let it go. I thought that if he loved me, he wouldn't take away my opportunity for motherhood, especially since he was already a parent."
"I thought I'd change his mind," she said with a sigh. "I didn't."
Ms. Glicksman and her husband are now separated. She recently became pregnant through artificial insemination, by a sperm donor. "I lost a husband, but will be a mother," she said. "I'll be a single mom by choice."
Joan DeMarco is also divorcing her husband, whom she declined to identify, over his refusal to have a child with her. Ms. DeMarco, who described her husband as 14 years her senior and twice divorced, said that she, too, agreed not to have children. "We've been together for 10 years, but now, at 41, I want a baby," she said.
Why did she accept the no-child prenuptial provision in the first place? "I had gone out with so many jerks, and here was this man who was loyal and wonderful, trustworthy and good to his word," she said. "He was originally hesitant to get married. I wanted to get married. People told me to be happy with what I have.
"We then got a standard poodle. But after I got the dog, it brought out more maternal feelings."
The men who insist on not raising a second family cite a variety of reasons, including the costs of children and a desire for a more romantic relationship with their new wives. One man -- a high-ranking investment banker at a prestigious New York company -- said he didn't want to subject a second set of children to a possible divorce.
"I could afford another family, but not the emotional turmoil my kids endured because of my divorce," said the man, 45, who spoke on condition that he not be identified. "I don't ever want to go there again."
Having broken up with several younger women who wanted children, he has now changed his dance card: he is is dating only women over 40.
Of course, many couples of all ages and economic status debate having children, and some decide against it. They include a small portion of those marrying for the first time in their 20's and 30's. When divorced men and women with children remarry, the presence of stepchildren invariably influences the decision whether to add to the brood.
The doubts can be as deep for women who remarry as for men. Lauren Howard, a New York psychotherapist who is divorced and has two children, said she did not want to start another family following her breakup at 37, and she parted ways with one suitor who wanted children of his own.
"I asked for the divorce and exposed my kids to a lot of pain," she explained. "I didn't want them to ever feel displaced or replaced. New children offer new hope, and I didn't want their status diluted."
The situation of the older, successful man and the trophy wife is different, however, because in the debate over whether to have children, the two sides often wield unequal power. No matter how deeply in love a couple may be, the ability of a wealthy man to dictate the terms of a marriage is undeniable.
David Patrick Columbia, who chronicles the bon ton on a Web site, NewYorkSocialDiary.com, said wealthy older men expect to be adored by their second spouses and don't like to share the attention with a baby. At the same time, he said, "the younger woman wants a baby, because in case of a divorce, she has more of a legal claim on his assets."
Jeannette Lofas, president of the Stepfamily Foundation in New York, who counsels members of stepfamilies, said the expectations of men and women who remarry can be strikingly different.
"You have to convince the man to recognize that this relationship is different from his previous experience, and that children will add to their marriage," she said. "I'll often tell men that the woman will end up hating them if she's denied the child. And it will ruin the marriage. Most give in, but not all."
Ms. Lofas said she has known women who told their husbands, "Oops, I'm pregnant."
"In most cases," she said, "the man is happy and becomes a doting dad." But for the exceptions, the pregnancy can lead to divorce.
Lorraine White, who agreed to a no-child policy before marrying Mr. Gundersen, agreed. "If a man gets snookered, he'll resent you," she said. "I've seen men who cheat on their wives and eventually leave them. You have to have integrity and trust in a relationship. No means no, for men and for women."
