HEADLINE: New York's Homeless, Back Out in the Open 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN and KEVIN FLYNN

 BODY:
During his routine of supervising the McDonald's in Pennsylvania Station each day, Julio Velandia, the assistant manager, says he sees more homeless people than he did a year ago. "Those kind of people bother the customers," he said, "and they have a bad smell."
 Mr. Velandia is not alone in noticing an increase along the city's avenues and in its doorways. These days, merchants around Union Square, soup kitchen operators and commuters are buzzing about ghosts of the city past: street dwellers. 
 Homeless people, whose presence seemed to decline in the flush years of the Giuliani administration, are suddenly more visible, napping on park benches and camped out under scaffolding, possessions in tow. 
Neither the city nor the groups that advocate on behalf of the homeless actually survey this transient population, so it is impossible to say with certainty that their numbers are growing. City officials insist the problem is more one of perception than of reality, and plan to begin conducting an annual census of the street population this winter so that real data will be available.
"No one knows for sure," said the city's commissioner of homeless services, Linda I. Gibbs, "but we are hearing from both the Police Department and our outreach folks that it is not an increase in the number of street homeless, but a change in the pattern of street homelessness." 
Advocates for the city's poor, on the other hand, insist that the weak economy and a growing lack of supportive housing for the homeless who are mentally ill have led to an increase in the number of people sleeping on the streets. They point out that the average number of single adults in city shelters is 7,728 per night -- the highest since 1991. They also say that the city's soup kitchens and feeding vans are reporting crowds that they have not seen since the late 1980's, when the number of homeless in New York peaked.
No one is suggesting that Bryant Park and Union Square are becoming the homeless epicenters they were in the 1980's, but reports of increasing homelessness have alarmed business coalitions and city officials.
Last month, police commanders in Manhattan below 59th Street were told by their supervisors to draw up plans to address any homeless encampments swiftly. In an interview, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said the directive resulted from increased reports of homeless people in several Midtown locations.
Mr. Kelly, Ms. Gibbs and a few service providers who have contracts with the city say that the homeless are more visible because of the displacement they suffered on Sept. 11. Before then, many homeless people were entrenched in the subterranean passages beneath the World Trade Center and in many other locations in Lower Manhattan. This dislocation, officials say, has been compounded by security concerns, causing the police to begin patrolling beneath bridges and beside waterways, disturbing enclaves that had been oases for the homeless.
Bloomberg administration officials said there had been no change in policy in dealing with the homeless, and no lesser effort to disperse them from the streets than under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. In 1999, after a man thought to be homeless attacked and seriously injured a young woman on a Midtown street, Mr. Giuliani announced that the homeless could either move on when prodded by the police or face arrest.
Mr. Kelly said that he did not believe the homeless had the right to sleep on the sidewalks, and that officers had been instructed to tell them to move along or to make an offer of shelter, and to arrest them if they violate public-nuisance laws. The number of homeless people arrested for such offenses this year has increased by more than 300 percent, Mr. Kelly said, although police officials attributed part of that to a change in how arrests are recorded.
At the same time, however, the Police Department, whose ranks have been thinned by attrition and stretched to deal with the threat of terrorism, has had 20 percent fewer contacts with homeless individuals so far this year compared with the same period in 2001. A contact can range from a call for aid to a simple encounter in a park to an arrest.
One homeless man in Midtown who gave his name only as John said last week that the officers he encountered these days were not as zealous as they were a few years ago. John, who was panhandling at 11th Avenue and 43rd Street, said that a few years ago anyone caught drinking beer from a paper bag was sure to get a summons, but that now officers use more discretion. "The cops are still out here," he said. "But they are not busting chops like that."
Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials said the police at Penn Station had noticed a slight increase in the homeless in the early morning hours. They said they used police patrols and outreach efforts to try to ensure the homeless do not disturb commuters during the day.
Many nonprofit agencies also say they have seen marked increases among the homeless in recent months. And the city itself reports that the number of clients using drop-in facilities grew to just over 1,000 in June 2002 compared with fewer than 900 a year earlier. The executive director of the Center for Urban Community Services, Tony Hannigan, said that in August workers at the homeless drop-in center the group runs on 126th Street recorded roughly three times as many new faces as in August 2001.
Advocates for the homeless say the main reason for any increase is a shortage of housing designed specifically to support the homeless who are mentally ill. Studies show that people with severe disorders like schizophrenia are particularly at risk to end up on the streets, compared with poor people who are not mentally ill and who tend to handle institutionalized shelter better.
"The major structural cause is that there is a reduction in the supply of supportive housing," said Patrick Markee, a senior policy analyst for the Coalition for the Homeless, "and you can trace the increase in street homelessness pretty directly to a decline in vacancies for these supported beds."
The population of single adults in homeless shelters fell to its lowest point in 1994, he said, soon after several thousand new units of government-financed housing for the homeless became available. Shelter vacancy rates at the time were around 9 percent. Vacancy rates at shelters are now at less than 2 percent.
Advocates for the city's poor also contend that the city's struggling economy and more demanding requirements for public assistance have combined to push some people into the shelter system.
The number of single adults receiving public assistance declined through the late 1990's, but has begun rising again. In the first week of October, roughly 10,000 more single adults were on public assistance in New York than during the same week last year, according to the Human Resources Administration. These people use social services that had previously gone to the homeless who are mentally ill.
"These working homeless can manage well in the system, but there is a tax," said Andrew Apicella, program director for the Bowery Residents' Committee's homeless outreach unit. "It means the guy on the street gets less attention."
Whether the rise in the homeless population is real or an illusion, almost everyone agrees that the city is better equipped to handle an increase than it was when the first crisis hit two decades ago under Mayor Edward I. Koch. City officials are now under court order to provide shelter to anyone who seeks it, and despite their public reputation as being unsafe and dirty, the shelters, which are run by nonprofit agencies and monitored closely by the courts, provide levels of security and cleanliness that make them a model for cities across the country.
Having survived the homeless crisis of the 1980's, the city's business leaders are determined not to allow a repeat. "Any increase is an issue because there is a fear of going back to what was," said Joseph Tango, head of operations for the Union Square Business Improvement District and Local Development Corporation.
And New Yorkers in general seem more inured to, than annoyed by, the the homeless in their midst.
"As complaint central," said Jonathan Greenspun, commissioner of the mayor's community assistance unit, "I can tell you that as of today people care more about vendors, graffiti, transportation and noise than the homeless."
In a few dozen interviews across the city in the last week, residents said repeatedly that they were more saddened than angry or concerned for their own safety when they saw a homeless person.
Robert Stone, an electrician from Marine Park, Brooklyn, said he had noticed an increase of homeless people "lying about" on the Q train. "Like this morning, I got on and the first thing I noticed was the stench," he said, before adding, "I got that old sinking feeling, like there is nothing I can do to help."

HEADLINE: With Rebels on Attack, Ivory Coast Leader Fires Defense Minister 

BYLINE:  Agence France-Presse

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Oct. 12 

 BODY:
Rebels went on the attack in the west of the country today as President Laurent Gbagbo removed his defense minister and a Senegalese mediator made a last-ditch effort to avert all-out civil war.
 President Gbagbo took personal control of the army by leaving the Defense Ministry vacant and appointing Bertin Kadet, a junior security minister, as a minister attached to the presidency responsible for defense and civil protection. 
 That means that Mr. Kadet will take his instructions directly from the president, who will become de facto defense minister, said Mamadou Koulibaly, the president of the National Assembly. 
The ousted defense minister, Moise Lida Kouassi, whose reputation suffered because of false claims that the army had captured the central rebel stronghold of Bouake on Monday, will become presidency minister.
The rebels attacked the paramilitary camp outside the western town of Daloa this morning, and the battle was continuing as night fell, local residents said. 
The insurgents, army mutineers and soldiers who have returned from exile, staged an uprising on Sept. 19 and now control the predominantly Muslim north of Ivory Coast and key towns in the west, center and east.
The United States says it fears a "meltdown" in the west African country, once a beacon of stability and prosperity in a violence-wracked region. The United Nations is warning of a looming "large-scale humanitarian crisis" spreading beyond Ivory Coast's borders.
Daloa, 230 miles northwest of Abidjan, is the capital of the cocoa-producing western region.
Ivory Coast is the world's largest producer of the bean, growing 40 percent of the world crop. Fears that the imminent harvest will be disrupted have pushed prices to 17-year highs.
Meanwhile, Senegal's foreign minister, Cheikh Tidiane Gadio, held two hours of talks with rebel negotiators in Bouake.
He told reporters afterward that no agreement had been reached but that discussions would continue on Sunday.
The minister said he had submitted new proposals from Senegal's president, Abdoulaye Wade, the chairman of the 15-nation Economic Community of West African States, or Ecowas, but gave no details.
Master Sgt. Tuho Fozie, the rebel spokesman and one of their negotiators, said there was "nothing new" in the proposals.
But he added, "We have always said that we are prepared to find clear and fair solutions" to the crisis.
Ecowas mediators proposed a cease-fire pact last week, but that deal fell apart last Sunday when Mr. Gbagbo reneged on a pledge to sign it, saying the rebels had to lay down their arms first.
The African Union called in a statement released overnight for "an immediate ceasefire."
In Washington, the State Department urged the nearly 3,000 Americans in Ivory Coast to leave the country. "Our people are stressing the advisability of departing," one official said on Friday.
The United Nations World Food Program said it was suspending its normal feeding operation for more than 300,000 people in Ivory Coast -- mostly children -- and setting up a regional emergency program for those displaced by the turmoil.
Several countries are evacuating their citizens, or planning to do so, after attacks against the 4.5 million West African immigrants in Ivory Coast.

HEADLINE: YACHT RACING; 
Last Place Aside, Underdogs Relish Roles

BYLINE:  By WARREN ST. JOHN

DATELINE: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Oct. 12 

 BODY:
Xavier De Lesquen, the bespectacled 40-year-old administrative judge who heads the French America's Cup team -- which has yet to win a race -- is finally smiling.
 For the first time since the Cup challenger races began two weeks ago, his team, Le Defi Areva, left the dock and returned in the afternoon without a loss. The reason? The wind died and racing was canceled. 
 "Today we have been lucky," De Lesquen said.
For all the attention being paid to the big budgets and the big egos competing for No. 1 -- and a chance to challenge New Zealand, the America's Cup holder, in February -- there is another compelling story here, in the fierce battle not to be last. Nine boats are competing in the first of two round robins. At the end of October, the top eight will advance to the next round. One will go home, leaving Auckland and the world's attention behind. 
Besides the French, the competitors for that eighth slot are the British GBR Challenge and the Italian syndicate Mascalzone Latino. Their backers entered the America's Cup the way Steve Forbes enters presidential campaigns: with slim prospects of winning and the knowledge that losing will cost millions.
"When we got here, my team was saying: 'We're here to win. We're here to win,' " said Vincenzo Onorato, a fourth-generation Neopolitan shipper behind the Mascalzone Latino. "I'm not here to win. My goal is not to be the first eliminated. I'm here to get experience."
Well, experience and maybe a bit of something else, too. Few sporting events can match the aura of history, glamour and rugged masculinity attached to the 151-year-old America's Cup. The contest evokes names like Vanderbilt and Lipton, Endeavor and Courageous, and simply sailing in the race entitles skippers to claim a bit of that majesty themselves. Even so, leaving will not be easy. With photographers and cameramen swarming by on helicopters and boats, being on an America's Cup yacht is akin to being on a runway in Milan.
The most humble person would have difficulty not feeling, at least temporarily, like a superstar. And to anyone with the gadget gene -- and everyone on an America's Cup boat has the gadget gene -- leaving Auckland will mean an end to the strange sense of purpose derived from countless hours of tweaking, reconfiguring and redesigning their yachts in search of speed.
Despite the possibility of their eminent demise, the underdogs have been the Cup challenge's main sources of levity. For the real competitors, after all, sailing is serious stuff.
Ernesto Bertarelli, the Swiss pharmaceutical heir behind the Alinghi syndicate, is seldom seen in public and does not give interviews, even shooing away a television crew from home that came to wish his campaign good luck. Team Prada fired its head designer after a single loss. Oracle-BMW asks visitors to sign confidentiality agreements at its base. The underdogs, by contrast, have open compounds, will invite practically anyone over for dinner and have staked out a defiant stance: the America's Cup will be fun.
"Sailing is not our job," Onorato said. "We do it for pleasure."
So what motivates someone to chase for -- and to spend for -- something they know they won't get? The combined budgets of the three underdogs is roughly $80 million, $5 million less than the budget of Larry Ellison's Oracle team, but not exactly chump change. For Onorato, the Italian, the idea was a lark. He was drinking beer and watching television with some sailing buddies on a windless day three years ago when it came to him.
"I said, 'Why don't we do the America's Cup?' " he recalled. "All my friends said: 'This is madness. You must be sick.' "
For Peter Harrison, the cheerful British technology entrepreneur who sold his companies at the height of the bull market and who rides in the back of his boat during races in a plastic chair with the legs sawed off, the motivation was patriotism.
He said he had been complaining to friends that despite founding the America's Cup, the British had never won it. In fact, they had not sailed in the Cup challenge for 15 years. He ponied up $30 million of his fortune, buying seven shipping containers of yachting gear from the defunct Japanese Nippon Challenge -- the equivalent of an "America's Cup starter kit," he said. "I decided to walk the talk." 
The French had America's Cup experience -- they made the semifinals of the last challenge series in 2000 -- but unlike the other two underdogs, they did not have a big money backer. 
"We had a good team and a good boat, but we had a single problem," De Lesquen said. "Absolutely zero euros in our pockets."
The project limped along on $2 million here and $2 million there, before landing an unlikely sponsorship from the French nuclear power company Areva, which pledged $15 million. 
For all the underdogs, not stopping means raising more money. As every weekend sailor knows, boats can do more damage to a bank account than a nasty gambling habit. Onorato said his Cup effort had cost him 30 percent more than he had planned, and he is still spending. "You keep thinking you can do a little bit better," he said. "The meaning of a little bit better is more money."
The need for cash explains why the French painted the hull of their boat a neon yellow the color of anti-freeze. "If you want sponsorship," De Lesquen said, "you have to have a boat that can be recognized."
Harrison has been searching for partners in Britain while simultaneously arguing in Auckland that what the Cup needs is the yachting world equivalent of salary caps.
"I said I wouldn't do it alone," he said. "For the good of the Cup, we should have others coming in so it's not determined by individuals. If it becomes the $100 million campaigns of Ellison and Bertarelli, then the person who spends the most wins."
What the teams lack in money, they try to make up for with esprit de corps. The French run their base camp like a kibbutz, with even the team's financial officers rotating cleaning and cooking duties. The crew of Mascalzone Latino eats pasta together each night, to build the team bond. Harrison said his team was a nautical version of the three Musketeers. "It's one for all and all for one," he said, but with an additional mandate: "Have fun."
Forming a bond may be easier for some of these crews than their faster competitors. Bertarelli, Ellison and the OneWorld Challenge backers Paul Allen and Craig McCaw have hand-picked professional, multinational crews from past Cup champions like New Zealand. The underdog boats are crewed by fellow countrymen, some of whom have sailed together for years. 
"We are friends," Onorato said. "I don't want to buy some great talent that makes your boat not your own."
Harrison took the idea a step further. He went in search of young British sailors, specifically exempting crew members from the 1985 and 1987 British Cup teams, with an eye toward building experience for future efforts. "I took the view they were the old guard," Harrison said. "It's an entrepreneurial, new economy effort."
Races today went some of the way toward clarifying who will end up in that ninth spot. After losing its first four races, the British scored a major victory over Larry Ellison's Oracle-BMW, to win its third in a row. Unless it falls apart in the second round robin, which begins Oct. 22, chances are good it will survive to the quarterfinals in November.
Mascalzone Latino and the French met in one of the closest races so far in the series. When the Italians crossed the line a boat length ahead of Le Defi, Onorato said his teammates cried. He is planning a party if his boat survives to the next round, and he says he knows what he will do there. "I will get drunk in the night," he said.
The French have nine more races ahead of them, including a rematch in late October with Mascalzone. A single victory and they are back in it.
"We are not at the level of the best team, that's for sure," De Lesquen said. "But we have improved a lot. If we stay alive, it's more than perfect."

HEADLINE: Bombing at Resort in Indonesia Kills 150 and Hurts Scores More 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND BONNER

 BODY:
A powerful car bomb detonated in front of a discotheque on the popular Indonesian resort island of Bali late last night, killing at least 150 people and wounding more than 200 others, Indonesian and Western officials said. 
 A hospital official in Bali said today that 75 percent of the dead were foreigners. It was one of the worst attacks on civilians in Southeast Asia in many years. 
 The nightclub where the car was parked, the Sari, and an adjacent one engulfed by the flames, were popular with Western tourists. Officials said many of the dead and injured were foreigners, most of them Australians and Europeans. An American official said there were Americans among the casualties, though he did not have the number or names. 
Members of a football team from Perth, Australia, were at the Sari Club, Australian officials said. 
"The place was packed, and it went up within a millisecond," Simon Quayle, the coach of the football team, told Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio.
Mr. Quayle, whose team was visiting Bali and at the resort at the time of the blast, said that he made it safely out of the building but that 8 of his 19 players were missing.
The blast left a crater large enough for three cars, an American official said.
Bloodied and mangled bodies were being removed from the carnage into the early morning hours, and fear gripped the serene island, where Hindus and Muslims have lived in notable harmony. The airport was shut.
Shortly after the attacks at the nightclub in Kuta, there was a bomb blast near the honorary American consulate in nearby Denpasar, Bali's capital. No one was injured.
No group took responsibility for the attacks but suspicions immediately fell on a radical Islamic organization based in Indonesia, Jemaah Islamiyah. The group and its leader, Abu Bakar Bashir, have been linked to plots against Americans by an operative of Al Qaeda who was seized in Indonesia and turned over to the Central Intelligence Agency several months ago.
American officials described the bombings as terrorist acts, and said that they appeared to have been aimed at the United States. An F.B.I. team was en route to the bombing sites, a senior American official in Washington said last night.
The bombings are certain to have consequences far greater than the immediate death and destruction, which is what a terrorist group would intend. In a country reeling economically, tourism on the legendary island of Bali is certain to suffer, and foreign investors will stay away. 
The government of President Megawati Sukarnoputri may also have been a target of the attack, much as Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, has been a secondary target of terrorist attacks.
Indonesian attitudes and American-Indonesian relations may also be shaken by the attack.
The United States and its major allies in the region, Australia and Singapore, have criticized the Indonesian government for not acting decisively against suspected terrorists.
Bush administration officials say that Jemaah Islamiyah fits all the criteria to be listed as a terrorist organization, but the United States has refrained from doing so for fear of destabilizing Indonesia politically and making life more difficult for President Megawati. Mr. Bashir has a significant following among Indonesian Muslims, and has been warmly embraced by the country's vice president, Hamzah Haz.
"If anything is needed to convince Indonesians that they have terrorism on their doorstep, this is it," Sidney Jones, director of the International Crisis Group in Indonesia and an expert on Jemaah Islamiyah, said in a telephone interview from Jakarta, Indonesia's capital.
The Bush administration's frustration with the Indonesian government's reluctance to recognize the extent of terrorism in the country boiled over with last night's carnage.
"We hope this sends a message to the Indonesians that terrorism is not just an American problem, but an Indonesian one as well," a senior administration official said.
The motive for the attack in Bali "wasn't a local commercial dispute," the official said scornfully.
In September, after a grenade exploded prematurely inside an automobile in a central Jakarta residential area, not far from the home of an American diplomat, the Indonesian police dismissed out of hand the suggestion that it was aimed at Americans. The police said the assailants were using the grenade to collect a debt from a person who happened to live next to the American. 
Ten days ago, the American embassy in Jakarta took initial steps to evacuate certain nonessential personnel and dependents of embassy officials because of threats of attacks on Americans, an American diplomat said. The diplomat declined to discuss the nature of the threats but said they were specific in nature.
The Bush administration went to the Indonesian government with another plea to provide more security.
In early September, the American Embassy in Jakarta was closed because of specific terrorist threats. It remained closed for several days while the Bush administration sought to convince the Indonesian police of the seriousness of the threats and urged it to provide increased security at the embassy.
Eventually, the police erected heavy barriers on the busy street in front of the embassy, and assigned more policemen to patrol the area. Embassy windows have been covered with bulletproof steel.
The move has angered many Indonesians who refuse to accept that terrorism is a threat in their country and see the American effort against terrorism as basically anti-Islamic. 
In an effort to convince the Indonesians that they must take the terrorist threat more seriously, President Bush telephoned President Megawati in September, then sent a top Indonesian specialist at the National Security Council, Karen Brooks, to deliver the message in person.
American officials said Ms. Megawati has now come to accept that the problem is serious, but she is not a strong or decisive leader and has not brought all of her top security officials on board.

HEADLINE: When a Smoking Ban Limits Freedom of Choice 

 BODY:
"Last Call for a Smoke" Oct. 6 states that "economic arguments are colliding with increasing concerns about the health risks to workers exposed to secondhand smoke for long periods." What about the freedom and choices of the patrons and employees? Should not the restaurant and bar owners decide what rules apply to smoking in their restaurants and bars? Liberty, the most fundamental American ideal, dictates that all Americans and, yes, Long Islanders as well, have an inalienable right to open a restaurant or bar with rules allowing patrons to smoke and breathe secondhand smoke. 
 There are dozens of occupations, social and recreational activities that have far greater safety hazards than restaurants and bars that permit smoking. Educating the public to the ills of secondhand smoke has great merit and serves an important function in society. However, individuals can and should decide for themselves what risk they will endure. 
 The potential danger from secondhand smoke is not reason for the government to outlaw it; otherwise, the government would be prohibiting junk food, swimming pools, automobiles, alcohol (they already tried that), scuba diving, sky diving, working on offshore oil rigs, on and on. We must remember that the most important ideal to uphold is freedom of choice. I agree with Peter Schmitt, the Republican minority leader of the Nassau Legislature, who said, "This is moving in a very intrusive direction, soon they are going to move into the home." We are on a slippery slope. Let us stop this foolishness now.

CLIFFORD SONDOCK
Lloyd Harbor

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE INVESTIGATION; 
Signs of Revived Qaeda Are Seen In Latest Strikes and New Tapes

BYLINE:  By DON VAN NATTA Jr. and DAVID JOHNSTON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 

 BODY:
American officials say they fear that terrorist attacks in the past week and taped messages from leaders of Al Qaeda signal the beginning of a new wave of terrorist activity and possibly a large-scale attack.
 Senior government officials also say that an attack that crippled a French oil tanker near Yemen and another that killed a United States marine in Kuwait showed that the terror network had reconstituted itself, with smaller groups prompted to begin new attacks by inflammatory new messages from Qaeda leaders. 
 Kuwait's interior minister said today that a statement from the gunmen's leader suggested a link to Al Qaeda and that the group had planned other attacks. Page 17. But other officials said it was not known whether the attackers were operating under direct orders from Al Qaeda's senior leaders. 
The group's latest round of attacks may be a response to the Bush administration's Iraq policy, the officials said. An audiotape of Osama bin Laden's closest lieutenant, Ayman al-Zawahiri, threatened continued attacks on "America and its allies," and denounced American plans to attack Iraq.
"The campaign against Iraq has an objective that is far beyond Iraq to reach the Arab and Islamic world," Mr. Zawahiri said on the tape. United States officials said his message appeared to be an attempt to justify and incite renewed violence against American targets. 
Another audiotape, which officials say is of Mr. bin Laden, repeated Al Qaeda's threats against the United States. Both tapes were broadcast in the past week by Al Jazeera, the satellite channel based in Qatar, and one American official said the two messages might have been intended to be a green light for Al Qaeda to initiate large-scale attacks.
Officials said that in the past week intelligence analysts had received reports of a spike in reported threats against the United States and American interests abroad. 
"I'm afraid you'll see a lot more of this," said Senator Richard C. Shelby, an Alabama Republican. "We always warned that there would be more attacks because we have not finished off the Al Qaeda group. We've disrupted it. We've had them on the run, but they are still around."
The government's latest intelligence analysis is based in part on the tanker explosion off Yemen a week ago, and on the shooting of two American marines on an island off Kuwait on Tuesday, an attack that killed one and wounded the other. 
"The marines in Kuwait and the ship off Yemen -- those could be precursors of more to come," one senior administration official said. "We believe this is a serious development."
So far, the government's response to the two attacks has remained deliberately low key. On Wednesday, the Bush administration discussed whether to raise the color-coded threat alert warning level from yellow to orange. But after a White House meeting, officials decided the threat was not yet specific enough.
Instead, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Office of Homeland Security issued a threat alert to the country's 14,000 state and local police agencies, saying the recent messages showed that "Al Qaeda continues to plan major attacks against U.S. interests."
"The statements suggest that an attack may have been approved," the alert said, "while the specific timing is left to operatives in the field."
The threat warning said Al Qaeda had issued similar messages before the bombing of two American embassies in East Africa in August 1998. "The content of the statements and the context surrounding these threats reinforces our view that they may signal an attack," the message said. "One senior detainee maintains that Al Qaeda would only release such a statement after approving a specific plan for an attack."
Officials are also concerned that another large-scale attack, perhaps in the United States, could be imminent because it usually takes at least one year for Al Qaeda to organize an ambitious attack. Nearly a year separated the attack on the American destroyer Cole in a port in Yemen in October 2000 and the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks against the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. 
The latest wave may be linked to earlier attacks this year. In June, a suicide bomber blew up a truck outside the American Consulate in Karachi, Pakistan, killing 14 Pakistanis. Since then, the authorities have linked Al Qaeda to at least five attacks or thwarted attacks, though none in the United States.
Even if terror groups do not initiate another large and concerted strike, officials say, the concern is about small groups of Qaeda members carrying out attacks in the United States that are similar to the recent ones in Kuwait and Yemen.
"There are remnants that are still out there somewhere, and they still have all that training," one senior government official said. 
For months, senior officials have feared that Al Qaeda would emerge after its members' escape from Afghanistan as a more dispersed but deadly network that would be far more difficult to contain. They worried that the network's old hierarchy, led by Mr. bin Laden, had been replaced by tactical operatives with makeshift alliances to militant groups in countries like Pakistan, Egypt, Algeria and Yemen.
The issue of whether Mr. Zawahiri survived the war in Afghanistan seemed to be settled by the release of the recording with references to recent events, like the Iraq debate. But the absence of video images of Mr. Zawahiri suggested to some analysts that he had been injured or had somehow changed his appearance to elude capture.
In the taped message, Mr. Zawahiri also takes credit for several recent terrorist attacks, including several against German and French targets in the Middle East. One goal of American policy, he said, was to make Israel the dominant power in the region. Another objective, he said, was to divide Saudi Arabia into four regions, with its oil fields under the direct control of the United States.
Intelligence officials said they thought that the voices on the audiotapes were those of Mr. bin Laden and Mr. Zawahiri. But they said that only the Zawahiri tape appeared to be recent, possibly recorded within the past month and no later than last summer, officials said.
Greater skepticism surrounds the bin Laden tape, released on Oct. 6 by Al Jazeera. In it, he refers to the Sept. 11 attacks as having already occurred but does not cite any other specific events that could be used to date the recording.
Mr. Zawahiri said in his tape that Mr. bin Laden and Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban leader, had survived the war. But the tape provided no evidence to support that claim, and officials remain divided over whether Mr. bin Laden is alive. But they say that Mullah Omar survived the war and is in hiding.
The tape thought to be of Mr. bin Laden contained an anti-American message that is familiar from his previous video and audio messages. "Let America increase the pace of this course of conflict or decrease it," it says, "we will retaliate in kind, God willing, and, God is our witness, that the men of Islam are preparing for you what would fill your hearts with terror, and they will target the hinges of your economy until you stop your injustice and aggression or either one of us dies first."

HEADLINE: A World to the Wise 

BYLINE:  By Steve Garbarino; Steve Garbarino is a contributing editor of Vanity Fair.

 BODY:
Looming over Savannah's East Taylor Street from the veined pink marble steps of his 1869 Second Empire town house, the 6-foot-7 map dealer, shopkeeper and unofficial town historian John Duncan scratches his Confederate-era white beard, shrugs the midafternoon drizzle from his seersuckered shoulders and glances around Monterey Square, canopied by live oaks heavy with Spanish moss.
 Duncan is explaining the more genteel interpretations of the local turf. "In Savannah, we don't call them alleys," he says in a soft Lowcountry accent as insinuating as Vincent Price's. "We call them lanes." "Alleys" would be just too profane a word even for the potholed service roads behind every historic Savannah street, where the garbage is taken and "the help" sits peeling shrimp. 
 To Duncan, who is 65 and a 12th-generation Charlestonian transplanted to Savannah, it's all about where you are, how you got there and what happened when you did. His is a sepia-toned and watercolored world, one that unfolds and unravels in V. & J. Duncan Antique Maps, Prints and Books, nestled in the mansard-roofed, birthday-cake-ornate, three-story double town house that John runs with his wife, Virginia (Ginger to intimates). 
For more than a decade, map collectors from all over the world 2/3 even map-mad Britons 2/3 have been finding what they're looking for in the unassuming, low-ceilinged shop, crammed with more than 4,000 maps, most of them dating to the 18th through 19th centuries, depicting all points of the globe -- not to mention outer space. Celestial maps, mostly dating to the 17th to 19th centuries, including astrological formations and mythological gods, share space with weathered, frame-worthy botanical, animal and marine-life prints.
"The world of map collecting is a very small one," John says.
But the locked box that is the cartographer's world may not hold long, considering that current events have kicked off a new groundswell of interest in maps, borders and foreign soils. The lines of demarcation -- between India and Pakistan, for example -- have never been thinner. And from a psychological standpoint, it could be argued that people have never felt more lost. Maps, the Duncans believe, can provide a sense of security for the displaced.
"We've found that mostly men collect maps, but also that most collectors come from broken homes," says Ginger, 56, who next to John appears as diminutive as a porcelain doll. "My father died when I was very young. I think that my own displacement led to my attraction to maps," says Ginger, a Georgia native, patting her Cavalier King Charles spaniel, Rosie. "Maps are comforting. They are for people searching for their past, for direction. Since Sept. 11th, I think they can help to provide a sense of place."
Italians were the first cartographers, in the 1400's. The 17th century was owned by the Dutch. The 19th century was America's moment in the cartography world. Ginger favors maps that depict "spheres and globes, pretty and decorated, somewhat primitive-looking ones," like those by the 18th-century German cartographer Herman Moll, who hand-colored most of his maps. John, who calls maps "enticing and sexy," prefers "flat maps with terrain and detail," particularly those by the 18th-century French hydrographer Jacques Nicolas Bellin.
But both look for peculiarities in their searches around the globe. Translation: maps with inaccuracies, often calculated ones. "It's like the postage stamps that show an airplane flying upside-down," John says. "Maps with mistakes are always more rare and sought after."
Though mapmakers are "generally honest," John says, since the late 19th century, they have often added a fictitious street to the top right corner to guard against forgers. When appropriators copy them, they "get nailed" since the streets don't exist. "The going rule," he says with a conspiratorial smile, "is that if there's a mistake, it's not a fake."
Freak details, which sometimes fall under the category of mistakes, can include nonexistent borders. Often, in those, the cartographer has inscribed "parts unknown." Pulling out a 17th-century map of New Guinea, John says: "See how the borders simply disappear? They are mysteries." Mistakes are also caused by laziness, ignorance and overzealous territoriality.
Take California, which was first depicted as an island in 1622 by the cartographer Antonio de Herrera. In 1701, it was proved that California was indeed connected to the mainland, but some maps continued to depict it as separate. Ginger says, "Obviously, the mapmakers were lazy, and used old engraving plates."
And old maps were often as biased as propaganda posters, serving the needs of those who made them and the countries they came from. Egotism, politics, elitism, racism and economics all played a part in their makeup. Many pre-1700 maps have a tendency to diminish the size of unexplored lands. John displays a woodcut world map by Sebastian Munster dated 1588. It depicts South America as almost box-shaped and far smaller than it should be. "Size is always defined by a European interpretation."
Similarly, the basis for standard time has until recently been anything but standard. While Greenwich, England, is the universal solar meridian today, in earlier times, countries showed degrees of longitude east and west of their capitals. "French maps used Paris," John says, "and shortly after American independence, American atlases used the capital of Philadelphia as the prime meridian. It's all very political."
For collectors, Ginger says, "bigger is always better." And shape is a selling point. Florida is always popular, she says, not just because of its exotic, bootlike shape, but because maps "sell where the population is growing."
"It may be a slight exaggeration," she says, "but in 10 years, the popularity of Florida maps has nearly equaled its percentage of population growth." Map collectors tend to favor places of refinement, and ones that are flush. "Middlesex, England, will sell way more than, say, northern Scotland," John says. "In the 60's and in the 90's, maps of Japan were in great demand, even in Savannah. But the downturn in its economy in recent years has reduced the demand and the price greatly. It's fair to say the demand and price of maps are directly related to the economy of the area depicted."
Maps of states are perennial favorites, especially those of the "island" of California; Texas as an independent republic; Oklahoma as Indian territory; North and South Dakota before they were divided; and Georgia and North and South Carolina with borders extending to the Mississippi River. And, John says, demand rises for locations "where anything bad, or in the news, is happening."
In recent years, the Duncans say, map collecting has broadened from its incestuous, tightly knit world to include people simply purchasing maps as substitutes for art in their homes, and even in some currently fashionable New York boites -- a practice pooh-poohed by map purists (but one that seldom curtails a sale).
"The first thing someone does when they walk into a room with a map hanging on the wall is try to locate where they're from," Ginger says. Such collectors are drawn to the more "olde"-looking maps that have gone through "toning," the changing of watercolored greens to blues on maps dating back 200 years or more.
Maps with fanciful cartouches are also in demand. Cartouches are details often bordered by an oval in a corner or at the top of a map. The most popular details include palm trees, exotic birds, American Indians, monkeys, alligators, even unicorns on some English maps. John shows a 1757 map of South Carolina, its cartouche featuring figures of slaves producing indigo.
"What is shocking, really, is how reasonable these old maps are" in price, he says. And while undervalued, they can be a solid investment in times of market volatility. One can buy a smallish map print dating to the 1500's for as little as $200. But a map of the Southeast that John bought in the 70's for $20 now sells for $500. A very rare map of historic Savannah showing the first four of the city's 24 squares was bought by John in the 1980's for $1,500. A few years ago, he was offered "the price of a brand-new Jaguar."
The Duncans, who like as much history in their environs as in their maps, have kept the Thomas-Levy House (named for its first two owners) as close to its late 19th-century look as possible. They bought it in 1976 for $36,000. Recent estimates place its value closer to $1 million. "We've spent a lot of money trying to make it look as old as it is," John says, although the Duncans do recognize a deal. Among the gilt mirrors and portraits, glossy patinas and parquet floors are lobby carpets bought for $1 from turn-of-the-century hotels.
When the author John Berendt went to Savannah to research his best-seller "Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil," John Duncan acted as his tour guide, introducing him to the local characters and architecture. But even with this breadth of knowledge about where things are, both in Savannah and around the globe, John and Ginger often find themselves at a loss as to their immediate surroundings. "I think we started collecting maps," Ginger says, dead seriously, "because we're always getting lost -- even on our on streets."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In their Savannah shop, John and Ginger Duncan have more than 4,000 maps depicting all points of the globe, from South America (1792), top left, to what is now the Georgia coast (1591). (Amy Eckert for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: IN PERSON; 
You Can Go Home, And Write About It

BYLINE:  By DEBRA NUSSBAUM

DATELINE: FREEHOLD 

 BODY:
WHEN Kevin Coyne is sitting in his home office surrounded by walls of novels and history books, you do not immediately notice the similarities between him and Freehold's most famous son, Bruce Springsteen.
 But as Mr. Coyne's story unfolds, it is clear that the two share common ground. Both attended grammar school at St. Rosa Lima. Both left Freehold, became successful and returned with their families to raise their children in the area. 
 Mr. Coyne, a writer who once pitched an idea for a book about Mr. Springsteen, lives here with his wife and three children, two of whom attend a public school. The Springsteens live outside of town and send their children to private school in Rumson. 
Mr. Springsteen has said that it was important to him for his children to walk on the streets his father walked on, and Mr. Coyne, 43, wanted the same for his children. "Subconsciously, in the back of my mind, I always wanted my kids raised here," he said. 
They both write about their hometowns -- Mr. Springsteen in song and Mr. Coyne in articles and a new book. And both contribute to the town where they were raised. A fire engine paid for by Mr. Springsteen has "Born to Run" emblazoned on its side. He still performs fund-raising concerts here, and last spring he spoke at the dedication of a local park, where Mr. Coyne met him for the first time.
Mr. Coyne, a member of the City Council, is also the historian for this two-square-mile town of 11,000 residents in Monmouth County. He is commemorating his hometown in a book, to be published by Viking Penguin in February, about six men who left Freehold to fight in World War II and then returned to spend their lives here.
In the book, "Marching Home -- To War and Back With the Men of One American Town," Mr. Coyne writes that of the 16 million Americans who served in World War II, about 900 came from this small town.
He spent four years researching and writing the stories of the six men, about their experiences in battle and the lives they made when they returned to Freehold. They came home to a town that, after the war, grappled with the closing of a major factory, racial conflicts and a deteriorating economy. In recent years, though, Freehold's economy has improved and ethnic and racial tensions have eased. 
Mr. Coyne said he saw Freehold as a "laboratory" of America, a microcosm of towns and cities across the nation because of its long history of racial diversity and an economy based on both farms and factories. He noticed, he said, "how accurately the town mirrored the changes in America." 
In the early 1960's, for example, Freehold witnessed a battle over whether prayers should be allowed in public schools, before the United States Supreme Court ruled that state-sponsored prayers were unconstitutional. And Freehold, like so many other towns, struggled with economic setbacks. In 1961, the Karagheusian Rug Mill, which provided employment for many of the borough's residents, closed, and Mr. Coyne said the town took nearly two decades to begin recovering from that economic blow.
Mr. Coyne is a member of the sixth generation of his family to live in Freehold. His ancestors came here from Ireland before the Civil War, and he is an avid collector of memorabilia. On one wall of his home is a framed bill from his great-grandfather's blacksmith shop, showing that a man named Frank Wilkins was charged $39.49 for work done between 1909 and 1912. A new shoe for Mr. Wilkins's horse cost 25 cents.
His collection also includes time cards from the mill and framed posters of rug advertisements. He also has a poster from an April 18, 1973, Springsteen concert at Christian Brothers Academy. Tickets were $3.50 and $4. 
Mr. Coyne, who became the borough's historian in 1999, has never lost his fascination with the place that was one of New Jersey's three original towns and the site of the single largest land battle of the Revolutionary War in 1778. Family members farmed, worked at the rug mill, or owned businesses, among other occupations. His father, Bud, who died in 1999 at the age of 65, was a pharmacist here and his mother, Anne, 67, still works as a bookkeeper. 
"My father never lived more than three blocks from the church where they had his funeral Mass," Mr. Coyne said.
But that was not the plan the author originally had for his own life. 
After graduating from high school in 1977, Mr. Coyne left Freehold to attend the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. He graduated in 1981 with a degree in history and English, then spent a year putting out a small weekly newspaper in the Jersey Shore. He and his wife, Jane Kaye, then moved to Massachusetts, where she was raised. Living in Manchester, he worked as a reporter for a small newspaper during the 1980's. He said in the late 80's he had an interview with The Boston Globe, but suddenly realized that he did not want to spend his life as a reporter.
"I had this epiphany that I really wanted to write books," Mr. Coyne said.
In his first attempt at a writing project, Mr. Coyne prepared a a proposal for a book about Mr. Springsteen and Freehold. His agent could not interest any publisher in the concept, but an editor at Random House asked for other ideas. The concept that sold developed into a book about the 10 million Americans who are awake at 3 a.m. every night. The book, "A Day in the Night of America," was published by Random House in 1992. It was "well reviewed," Mr. Coyne said, and sold about 20,000 copies. 
In 1995, Mr. Coyne published a second book, "Domers -- A Year at Notre Dame." He spent much of the 1992-93 school year at the college attending classes, going to football games, and interviewing more than 400 staff members and students. Mr. Coyne said his goal was to describe "how Notre Dame became the Vatican of Catholic America." The book sold about 30,000 copies and also received good reviews, Mr. Coyne said. 
While getting ready to research and write the Notre Dame book, Mr. Coyne decided to return to Freehold. He and his wife had just had their first child, and Mr. Coyne's mother was visiting them in Manchester. While Mr. Coyne was taking a picture of his mother holding his infant daughter, he realized he did not want this to be an unusual event, requiring a long-distance visit. 
"There was a whole world here waiting for us," Mr. Coyne said of Freehold. The Coyne family moved here in 1992 and bought a house built in 1926, less than a mile from the house where Mr. Coyne grew up. "I needed a sidewalk between my house and a place where I could buy a newspaper," he said. Mr. Coyne and his wife have three children: Laura, 11; Alice, 9; and Richard, 3. 
Mr. Coyne, like the men he wrote about in his new book, said he returned to Freehold because it offered a sense of place. "It's a genuine community," he said. "You do things for someone other than yourself. I'm largely here because six generations of my family are buried in the cemetery here."
Nolan Higgins, 45, a childhood friend of Mr. Coyne's, said he was not surprised that his friend had returned. They grew up four blocks from each other and Mr. Higgins's father, Jim, is one of the veterans featured in Mr. Coyne's book. "I always thought he'd be back," Mr. Higgins said. "His roots are here. He's very dedicated to the town."
While working on the book about the veterans, Mr. Coyne spent three years as a part-time reporter at The Asbury Park Press. He left the paper in 1999 when he received the J. Anthony Lukas Prize, a grant of $45,000. The prize is given to authors who are working on nonfiction projects that show promise. 
Mr. Coyne is now working on a historical narrative set during World War I. Even though he may not write about Freehold again, he said he was content to stay here.
One of the best things about coming home, he said, is that he is able to keep up with the people he has known since childhood. A fellow council member and his barber, Mike DiBenedetto, was a classmate from kindergarten through high school.
"As a reporter and a writer, it's fascinating to get to see how the stories come out," Mr. Coyne said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kevin Coyne at home in Freehold, with his new book, to be published in February, about six residents of the town who fought in World War II and then returned home to stay. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
Envisioning a New Jersey Triangle

BYLINE:  By JAMES E. McGREEVEY; James E. McGreevey is the 51st governor of New Jersey.

 BODY:
IN 1861, on the way to his inauguration, Abraham Lincoln addressed the New Jersey State Senate and spoke about the spirit of Trenton. He was referring to the Battle of Trenton, the turning point of the Revolutionary War -- an event that had burned itself into his consciousness when he was a boy. 
 While New Jersey was once at the crossroads of the American Revolution, we are now a state at the crossroads of an innovation revolution. 
For years, New Jersey has been laying the groundwork to move from a manufacturing economy to a high-tech economy. Today, we have one of the world's strongest pharmaceutical and biotech clusters, some of the nation's largest telecommunications companies, strong universities and more than our share of groundbreaking small businesses. 
However, to make a successful transition to the information and innovation economy of this new era, we need an entirely different paradigm to guide us. We must establish an innovation triangle of partnerships between the private sector, the research university community and the State of New Jersey.
We have reconfigured Prosperity New Jersey with William C. Weldon, chairman and chief executive of Johnson & Johnson, and Dr. Shirley Tilghman, president of Princeton University, as its leaders. They will create a partnership between the private sector, the research university community and the state to leverage New Jersey's strengths and develop the Garden State as the Innovation State.
Prosperity New Jersey is working to ensure that New Jersey businesses have a corps of highly educated and highly skilled workers who can meet the demands of our new economy. The business and university communities must identify and address New Jersey's work force needs by developing and supporting innovative approaches that will better educate and train the state's workers for the jobs of the future. 
To meet this challenge, we must be committed to changing the structure of the university system to improve research and education, particularly in medicine and biotechnology.
New Jersey has several excellent schools and a strong research presence from pharmaceutical companies. We have the infrastructure; we should have one of the great health education centers in the United States.
With this in mind, I signed an executive order in March creating the Commission on Health Science, Education and Training. Working under the direction of Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, retired chairman and chief executive of Merck & Company, the commission will provide for synchronization between the education and health care industries.
At present, Rutgers University and New Jersey's health care education institutions are operating independently of one another. We must provide the necessary level of synergy to create a world-class, research-based university to complement the efforts of the private sector to develop intellectual property.
Most importantly, the state must undertake the necessary actions to fortify the structure of the new paradigm, namely a vibrant private sector, a research university premised upon excellence and a supportive state government.
Dr Vagelos's commission is critical to the state's economy, particularly in terms of developing job opportunities in the information and innovation economy.
As Prof. Michael Porter of the Harvard Business School has stated, New Jersey has more patent development in the private sector than in the public sector. We have corporate giants within economic sectors of innovation, yet companies yearn for a research university partner that will complement research and development efforts.
New Jersey also is supporting the spirit of innovation through such programs as the Spirit of Trenton Council and Lecture Series, which provides a showcase for the extraordinary cultural and scientific talent that is leading the innovative spirit now evident throughout New Jersey. 
As part of this program, Dr. Wise Young of Rutgers University and Dr. Dennis Choi of Merck & Company, two of the most distinguished researchers of spinal cord injuries in the country, spoke recently about their work in regenerating nerve tissue. Their research gives hope to those who are paralyzed by spinal injury. Dr. Young and Dr. Choi are two of a growing community of scientists who look to the state to provide for the necessary link between pharmaceutical and rehabilitative therapies, clinical trials and the development of marketable products that will improve human lives.
In addition, the state's biotech industry is flourishing. A study conducted by the Rutgers University Graduate School of Management for the Biotechnology Council of New Jersey found that the industry contributed nearly $4 billion to New Jersey's economy in 2000, employing 7,500 people in 110 companies throughout the state. 
New Jersey also offers a series of incentive programs that provide financial assistance and other resources for businesses and educational institutions. 
Furthermore, our state is fully committed to enhancing research and development efforts as well as securing the protection of intellectual property. 
Today, through such initiatives as Prosperity New Jersey and Dr. Vagelos's commission, we are keeping alive the innovation of Edison and the idealism of Wilson -- both New Jerseyans -- as well as the spirit that inspired Lincoln. These programs continue to provide the foundation for innovation that will ensure the long-term competitiveness of the State of New Jersey.

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for DEAN R. O'HARE; 
How to Tally the Costs of War?

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
 WITH President Bush threatening to attack Iraq, former Secretary of State James A. Baker III, an old friend of the president and his father, expressed his solidarity in a speech last week to the nation's property-casualty insurers. He cautioned that a war with Iraq could be long and costly, but he received a warm response from the insurers, gathered at a conference in White Sulphur Springs, W.Va. One of those applauding was Dean R. O'Hare, chief executive of the Chubb Group of Insurance Companies, an insurer of businesses, homes and cars. Mr. O'Hare talked later about the business and economic implications of a war. JOSEPH B. TREASTER

Q. Why do you favor attacking Saddam Hussein?

A. This is an evil guy who is intent upon destroying us. And I think we need to extinguish him before he gets us. As for my fellow C.E.O.'s in the industry, I think you're going to find there are some people pretty much in favor of a pre-emptive strike and others who are not. Generally, I think the consensus of the people at the meeting, at least the people I spoke with, was that President Bush is doing the right thing.

Q. What impact do you foresee on the economy and the insurance business?

A. You've got to look at it as a negative impact. I don't think the impact is going to be enormous. But it's obviously going to have an impact on oil prices. We've lived through things like that before. I wouldn't even try to quantify it. But you can't view it as a positive. I think you could conceivably see us go from very small growth to a very, very small decline. I don't see anything more at this point. If there's a slowdown in the economy, obviously you're going to see a slowdown in certain lines of insurance coverage, workers' compensation, for example.

Q. Don't you worry about the possibility of counterattacks by terrorists in the United States?

A. That certainly is a possibility. But I don't think this is going to be a long and costly war. I think it's going to be quick and dirty. I think you need to talk in terms of months. But I think that in three months you have him out of power. I don't think you're going to have the level of retaliation here in the United States that some people are forecasting. There's always the potential for it. But I don't think we're going to have a situation where you have multiple occurrences. This is going to be a very high-tech war, and very one-sided.

Q. Since insurance coverage for terrorism has been withdrawn from most policies after 9/11, what effect would a new terrorist attack have on insurers?

A. A lot of policies have terrorism insurance included, but they don't have the same level of coverage they used to have. The 9/11 attacks will probably end up costing the insurance industry something in the neighborhood of $50 billion. If we had another one like that, my guess is that the amount of insured losses would be in the neighborhood of $15 billion. But there has been no lessening of coverage for terrorism in terms of workers' compensation insurance. If workers are injured or killed as a result of terrorism, the insurance companies would have to pay. Trying to control our possible losses, we're all being very careful in terms of insuring big groups in any one location. Before 9/11, no one ever thought you could have an attack where 3,000 people would be snuffed out. Now, we wouldn't dream of insuring 1,500 or 2,000 employees in a high-profile building in a major city. It's the possibility of the aggregate loss. People can get the coverage, but not from any one insurance company.

Q. You took the lead in calling the World Trade Center attack an act of terrorism, which at the time was covered in most insurance policies. In a war with Iraq, would you regard any counterattacks, for insurance purposes, as terrorism or as war, which is not routinely covered?

A. Any retaliation, I think, would come under the heading of war, not terrorism. Workers' compensation coverage would not be affected. The coverage is there regardless. But as far as property here in the United States or multinational holdings, they would definitely have a war exclusion. If you had a war and somebody dropped a bomb on a plant -- here or anywhere -- and destroyed it, you wouldn't have any coverage.
